content:
11, 2016
												I'm recommending this game for one reason: MultiplayerTropico 5 nailed the multiplayer aspect.Being able to play alongside my friends is the reason I love this game.It's the best multiplayer city building game out there. I have not come across any other like this.Tropico 5 lets you build next to players or with them. Cooperative or Competive, whichever you prefer.SimCity can hardly compete since you don't build together, you build in seperate regions. Cities: Skylines is the best city building game on the market hands down, but no multiplayer.During a multiplayer game you can share money, roads, utilities and military forces.It's very satisfying to share the love of these games alongside people who also love it.There are a lot of hilarious moments, especially if you're playing with friends.The rebels have basically become a meme among my friends because they're idiotic and easy to joke about.The only downside is being forced to send backup when a friend is attacked. If you get attacked while your troops are in a friend's city, all you can do is pray. Also, mandate is bs. The game could give all the mandate to one player but not the other.Don't even get me started on roads. Roads suck. They're horrible.The multiplayer is great and I hope it sets the foundation for future games.The dream would be this multiplayer on Tropico 4, Cities: Skylines or SimCity.I personally feel like it still capted the same feel as Tropico 4, except it was watered down and made much more difficult.You will never truly defeat the rebels or please everyone, this game is best played as a warmongering oppressive dictatorship. It will give you the most satisfaction since your prize is blood and trust me, there's plenty so you might as well enjoy it.TLDR: Multiplayer mechanics are great, game is a downgrade, still enjoyable.Advice: Spam sugar plantations and rum distillaries.

number of helpful: 43 of 61 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												The game looks like its predecessor's poorer cousin. There is less of everything - including building models, music or customization options - compared even to Tropico 4 without any expansions and DLCs. Quality of the existing content also seems actually worse than in the previous installation.As for the gameplay, it seems more shallow. I'm not sure how happiness translates into popular support, because even with my Tropicans being pretty unhappy I never had problems with winning elections without fixing votes. You can rake serious debt without any repercussions and, with the amount of resources on the average island, it's easy to make obscene amounts of money without trying too much.The new features are underwhelming. The consecutive eras don't change much except building models and the amount of available buildings and technologies. The only exception is the Colonial Era - you advance by converting people from Royalist to Independence faction. This sounds like fun but actually isn't - most of the buildings, edicts and other game features are locked, so you pretty much build the same thing several times and pray that the game lets you pass to its more interesting part before the time limit expires.The family system also disappoints. From time to time, you get an another inhabitant of the island who happens to have the same last name as El Presidente. They can be sent to manage a building and may be useful during some events - and that's pretty much it. You can also let them run in elections instead of you, but you usually don't want to do that - most likely, your current president is more experienced anyway.To sum it all up - Tropico 4 is simply better than its supposed successor.

content:
12, 2016
												If you’ve never played a Tropico game, you may not realize the difference between this series and any other simulation game. You might not realize all the political parody that defines Tropico. If you follow along with campaign narration and read the additional commentary tucked into the corners of the game, you will no doubt laugh at the subtle — and not so subtle — jabs at things like communism, capitalism, certain famous figures in history, and cultures that might be found in such a fictional place as Tropico. In Tropico 5, it only gets better as you, El Presidente, bring your island up from Colonial times, wedged between other superpowers, through all the familiar eras of our planet’s history. The fun of this game comes from experimenting with the exact ways you can choose to run your little country. Seeing what you can get away with, or seeing just how happy and loyal you can make your citizens, is the real appeal of this game. Yes, you have to research new technology, make money with farming or mining etc., and construct housing for your citizens, but every one of those choices has its own weight on political aspects. You can construct churches to increase quality of housing in the area, but if you are an atheist country by your constitution, this may lower your approval rating. If your approval rating gets too low, you may not win the next election (if you have those), or a rebellion may threaten to overthrow your rule. One thing you can do to help your situation is create a dynasty. Each ruler, the first being customized by you at the beginning of the game, has a special trait. Eventually, the game prompts you to find a new heir (by ridiculous means like a singing competition or thumb-wrestling match), and that new person will be selectable as a candidate for any election. Also, if you upset one of them too much by not siding with them on other trivial matters, they can rebel and try to overthrow you. You can also send them off to do special tasks like spy on an enemy faction or get a fancy degree to add merit to your regime. This is a really unique gameplay mechanic that I have not seen before, and your dynasty even carries over to multiplayer and sandbox modes. The game feels more robust with such a lasting element that can possibly produce much varying gameplay.Another sneaky, new mechanic is your personal Swiss bank account. This is represented by two dollar signs in front of any amount that concerns your personal account. This is where you can really become a corrupt leader and laugh all the while. The purpose of this account is to get you out of tight spots in the campaign, or to level up your dynasty members. If you are lucky enough to discover a manager that siphons off a percentage of a building’s revenue to put into your account, saving up becomes easy. Combat is in Tropico 5, but to be honest it probably shouldn't be, at least not in this form. While almost everything else in the game feels smooth and refined, the battles are fiddly and tedious. When you're attacked, whether by a traitorous squad of rebels or by foreign powers, you'll see tiny squads pop up on the map. They'll head off to destroy your key structures, and whatever defences you possess, militia squads or your personal guard, will automatically rush over to ineffectually swat at them, often before waiting for backup. Pretty much all you can do at that point is sit back and wait to mop up the pieces. It's not too much of a problem honestly, because larger combats generally only happen when you've lost control of the situation completely anyway. The smaller skirmishes, like the occasional uprising that happens if you irritate one of the game's factions too much, thankfully don't last too long. Combat is the game's most obvious weakness, but it doesn't soil the rest of Tropico 5.The characters of Tropico are drawn in broad strokes, but the canvas they’re drawn on is broader. Everyone and everything is a caricature: your underling, Penultimo, is a dimwitted, unceasing bootlicker; capitalists and opportunists within your staff seethe with delight as they suggest profiting off other nations’ needs, while communist revolutionaries are naively passionate about their cause despite not knowing exactly what they’re fighting for. Entire political institutions are mocked; early in the single-player campaign, a Marxist reveals that the Russians are exporting the Communist Revolution as a buyable service.I won’t bother going through how the basics of a city builder work, as I think you understand most of it if you live in any civilization in real life. But I will say that they scope of Tropico 5, with the added intricacies of politics, makes this game much more fun and in-depth. That’s something other city sims don’t have. The parody in particular is especially entertaining. Once you progress out of the colonial era, you get to hear the perky ramblings of a girl who manages a tavern called the Jolly Rodger, which I think is supposed to represent pirate radio and a public truth-teller you cannot control. She has something to say about almost every new milestone, and she makes sure to embarrass El Presidente any chance she gets, like when you hire surveillance to warn you of any new rebel leaders. The voice acting is top-notch, mainly because it’s so spirited and spot-on for whatever person is being parodied. I appreciate that in a city sim. After all, why build up a regular ol’ society when you could be building one that makes fun of things that have happened in our actual history? Unlike previous games in the series, Tropico 5 includes multiplayer modes - and while these function just fine, they feel like they're missing something. Up to four players can compete or cooperate in pursuing a number of objectives, and the fact that everyone shares the same island elevates the pressure in some interesting ways. If there’s an oil deposit between two dictators, the first person to build a road to that resource can claim it and expand their territory at the same time. In a cooperative scenario, roads become friendly lifelines that players use to share teamsters or construction workers. The lack of an omnipresent scoreboard forces players to visually observe each other’s progress, but it also leaves them data-starved. Regardless of the mode or objective, players still need to tend to all of the responsibilities of a single-player game, which pile up fast. The lack of chrono controls, while inevitable, muddles the series’ traditionally relaxed atmosphere, and most players will eventually turn back to single player in order get the true Tropico experience. Visually, this game is stunning. On high specs it looks beautiful and the effects like wind and waves are really nice. A lot of detail is gone into the look of the game. Which is probably why the developers have opted for a hollow grid look for the best areas to place buildings as opposed to the filled in grid that came before. I really didn’t like this, it makes it far more difficult to read the lay of the land. This is about the only thing in the game I really didn’t like. Fives games in and the Tropico series has really found its feet, creating a cheery and relaxing ambience that sets it quite apart from other city-builders out there. From the music to the bright and colourful graphics and the irreverent wit of your various staff, it’s got a very unique character that makes the simple gameplay very addictive. Okay, so it holds your hand a little too much, and combat is a bit dull, but it’s certainly the high point of the series so far. A very good city management and political strategy game that’s got a relaxed attitude quite unlike anything else out there.

content:
er 8, 2016
												Tropico 5 is NOT Tropico 4, that must be made clear. Tropico 4 was pretty much a beefed up Tropico 3 after all.While I miss some aspects of Tropico 4 (apartment designs, some edicts, etc.), Tropico 5 is a truly great game in its own right.I never did much of ANYTHING with the trading interface in T3 and T4, and while some lament the 'over simplified' and 'dumbed down' new trade interface, I love it. I am actually using it now and I know exactly what I'dm doing. What they made easy in trading, they made more complicated in everything else. Getting 100% happiness in a T4 sandbox was ridiculously easy. Even with $100k in a T5 sandbox, save games will be your friend. ESPECIALLY in the campaigns.Factions are not the end all they used to be. While the people are easy to please, faction approval (and by extension the approval of their members) is not so easy. Happiness doesn't win elections. Approval does. Thus, you can be easily voted out if the largest faction doesn't like you for what ever reason. USE EVERY MINI-CHALLENGE YOU CAN TO PLEASE THE FACTIONS! Your life will be made significantly easier. Communists were easily appeased in T4 with food, housing and medical care. Now they don't give two hoots.A huge amount of new features have been added, and I love them. From edicts to buildings to other mechanics. The added variety of army units is very welcome. Building managers make no sense to me though, since appointing them for each and every individual building is a micro-managing nightmare.As a new edition of the Tropico series, I heartily approve. It is different, and a welcome challenge with many hours of gameplay fun (and frustration as you become accustomed to it). The game has that typical Tropico satire, parody and humour....and it is hilarious beyond what I thought T4 ever was.

content:
27, 2016
												I really love Tropico games and would not doubt if the entire team is tripping on LSD as they code it. The graphics are solid this time around. They have a much more polished feel over the others. The musics always solid and you can import your own into the game without much effort. With that being said I'll go into a few negatives. With this one you really do want all of the DLC as too much was withheld from the base game. Once you have everything it's a beauty.This time around you can't zoom out as far as previous versions. There is a script available to undo this but it doesn't work in multiplayer. So now they have multiplayer but it desyncs often which ruins the match. It's definitely playable but there aren't many people online. It helps to know someone with the game if you want all of the achievements because several are tied to multiplayer. I've been trying for a long time to get the final 3 I have left. At least they have it which is a step in the right direction. Then they removed some of El Presidente's previous features. Now you can't follow him around or engage in a shootout. Instead it's all about dynasty members which would be fine... if they let me follow them around, give my speeches, and shoot up the enemy. They must undo this in the next one as it removes part of the charm. I'll also argue that they made it way too difficult to be a ruthless dictator. You'll make money hand over fist being a swell guy, but if you so much as look in the other direction you're going to have a military mutiny. It doesn't matter how well prepared you are for your own troops toppling you. Sure, you deserved it but I invite you to try running a North Korean style of government on this game. You might even find yourself in awe of what that dictatorship has accomplished. It probably is more realistic in that regard but it's also almost impossible since most of the features that could make it a reality aren't available until much later in the game. There is so much to this game that I am overwhelmed by attempting to describe the positives. Teamsters and construction workers are no longer an achilles heal. The army doesn't wander off during a crucial battle. Traffic jams are no longer an issue whatsoever. Parking garages and metros have been nerfed to the point that there doesn't seem to be a penalty for not having them at all. I'd argue that they went too far but micro managing roads was annoying. The military additions, the espionage, industries, trade, and so on are all well done. You have people flying rocket powered gliders all over the place, blimps, airlines, and so on. It's no longer just micro managing a banana republic and more like you're running a western power. I'm really interested to see what they will do with Tropico 6. I hope they add more wildlife as they removed a bit too much this time, give us back control over El Presidente, and work on the different forms of government. If they do those simple things I'll be happy.I will place the script to edit music into the game as well as the camera zoom into the comments section.

content:
ber 4, 2016
												Tropico 5 is a okay game. Tropico 4 is much better in my opinion though.The following concerns the game at medium difficulty settings.The campaignThe campaign includes only 4 different islands. You start with two that you can (or need to) switch after each mission. Constructed buildings will persist between missions on each island. Thus you only really need to build a good economy once and you are done for all remaining missions. The campaign is also rather short.Game mechanics- General buildings: Several buildings grant additional advantages if they are build on higher terrain. However, 3 of the 4 campaign islands are completely flat.- Housing: Compared to the previous Tropicos, the housing system has been improved. Even small buildings make sense now.- Industry: Tropico 5 allows you to build larger industry production lines. You can start with a logging camp, then add a saw mill to generate planks and then use these planks to build furniture. That's quite a nice feature.- Population: You can change a policy (~ every 5 years) that controls the number if immigrants. However, I never noticed any big difference between the options regarding the number of people arriving on my island. With open borders I got about 20 immigrants per ship. This leads to a problem, because you really need a lot of people on the island. The only other option is to increase the number of births by building clinics and hospital (up to 50% increase in births). But that's still not enough and I constantly ran out of workers (~200 workers missing in a population of 1400 people). This wouldn't be so bad if you didn't need to build lots of healthcare, religous and entertainment buildings to keep your population happy.- Unrest: The unrest system appears to be out of control. For example, even if the military faction loves you, they just might start a coup to get rid of you. Also, I haven't found any reliable way to get rid of rebels (However, they only became annoying in 2-3 missions, thus it might be due to scripting).- Military: The military mechanics are just horrible. Certain buildings are marked as targets once rebells or other forces attack. All your armys will then start moving towards these targets, ignoring any enemy forces that they may encounter on their way. The enemy will shoot at you though! This often leads to several causalties before your army even starts fighting back.There is also an option to build an aircraft carrier that does not work at all, because the aircrafts won't fire if the enemy is close to buildings, which is usually the case. However, you can set it on "fire at will", which will make them shoot and set your buildings on fire. That would be perfectly okay, if the rockets would actually damage enemies that are moving, but it appears that they mostly do damage on stationary enemies.Tropico 4 gave you more control over the movement of your armies, which made it much better in this respect.- Dealing with criminals, rebels, etc.: Similar to the previous tropico you can banish, arrest or kill people that you don't like. Or... well, you can at least issue the order to arrest them. Apparently the police doesn't really care about it. It takes years for them to take them to the prison.All in all it's an okay game, but I wouldn't buy it again. Get Tropico 4 instead of Tropico 5.

er 29, 2016
												I am a huge fan of the Tropico series but I unfortunatly cannot recommend this game. Also I should add I have logged about 70+ hours in this game at the time of writing this review even though my account says like 90 mins or something, I played most of it in offline mode. Compared to Tropico 4 (which imo is the best Tropico in the series) this game just feels unfinished even with all the DLC. There was so much stripped from the game that I sometimes found myself spending time looking for something that was no longer present even though they were important features in previous games.My main problem with 5 compared to 4 is that you have less control over your island and its inhabitants.Here a few of my Likes and Dislikes Likes-Era and Research system was a good idea (poorly exectuted though)-Dynasty members was a nice idea and looking forward to a return in futrue Tropicos hopefully-Trade system was also a welcomed feature-Online mode is a great feature but not enough people use it, (good for with friends though)-New mining system-New farm system-Really liked the new combat system-Manager system was a good idea-Buildings look amazing (Best so far)Dislikes-New Almanac is just bad, lacks so much useful information (bring back the old one!!!)-Lack of the Rise to Power, Background etc options when setting up a new sandbox game-Where did all the trait options go?-Labour camp removed (easily on of my favourite buildings, I would have bet money on it making a return in 5. Sadly not though)-Lack of housing options-Shockingly small amount of decorations compared to Tropico 4-Grade school removed-New budget system which replaces the ability to set the wages and upkeep of the building individually.-Building options gone. (cants set schools to Military Education, newspapers to Word of God etc.) This was a huge disappointment for me.-Not enough Tourism and Entertainment buildings-Number of tourists allowed on the island capped-Lack of variety in tasks, after a few playthroughs they become too familiar-New Faction system is terribile (where did the loyalists go?)-Advisors and Faction Reps Removed. Only Penultimo and Oaksworth advise and offer tasks now.-Zoom levels reduced-Criminals replaced with crime lords that justt appear on your island-Election Speech removed (????)-Rebel yell, Immigrants out etc starting options removedI could list a few more but you get the idea. I will end this review saying that if you are thinking of buying this game. Don't do it and buy Tropico 4 instead.

												As someone who played Tropico 4, I was actually a bit disappointed with this. It has some features that are better than Tropico 4, and some that Tropico 4 doesn't have. However, it is also missing much of the stuff Troico 4 had. I'll do a little list:What Tropico 5 is missing that was in Tropico 4:1. Placeable statues of the Player Character2. Stupidly large golden statues of the player character3. Character customisation (to the extent it was present in Tropico 4)4. The ability to be a brutal Dictator, and stay in power5. Decent Political system6. The ability to sdjust wages, and rents on residences, in the same way as was possible in Tropico 4 (Only the simplified budget mechanic is there)7. The ability to play as famous figures from the period8. The ability to actually choose you characters name9. Cool DLC (As opposed to crappy cash grab DLC)10. Good Music (In my opinion the music in this is worse than in Tropico 4)11. A wide selection of buildings (there is a similar number of buildings, despite the fact that Tropico 4 takes place over 50 years and Tropico 5 over around 100)What Tropico 5 has over Tropico 41. Multiplayer2. Tanks, Military Aircraft and APC's (Although you need DLC to get APC's despite the fact they can be seen driving around in the main menu on the base game. This is what I mean about cash grab DLCs)3. Ability to control soldiers (Although they are discustingly clunky to control)4. A grid system for ease of placing buildings5. Random Map Generator6. Reasearch7. Different Era'sBasically, buy Tropico 4 unless you want to play with friends, I think it's better and so do so many others.

content:
13
												I wanted to like this game. I spent a great deal of time searching for a game just like this one, read reviews, and finally decided that it was the one I wanted. Dropped $50 for the whole collection, and I will likely not play it again after the 150 or so hours I dropped into it.GoodIt is world-building, political gameplay that I was searching for in a sense. Much of the game allows you to control all of the little details that make the world your creating exactly what you want--for a while. The various constitution options were interesting, and it was one of the options that I found to be the most exciting, being able to control the type of people who come onto your island, controlling the state of the government, and setting up the professionalism of your military are all excellent options that I think really contribute to the overall feel of the game.BadExecution of the above failed. The politics are largely one-way. You pick a side and can't really play the middle in any meaningful way if you want to complete a mission. In major-global conflicts, there is a political out if you are skilled enough. Not an option.The game provides a limited and hilariously unsatisfactory tutorial that fails to explain most of the important aspects of the game that determine approval rating, military tactics, and government effects of a number of aspects. Moreover, most of the constitution is written to be funny rather than informative (along with quests, objectives, and so on), meaning that it is impossible to tell the exact effect most actions or changes will have until it is too late. And I say too late, because you can only alter the constitution once every five years. At one point, I altered mine and my approval rating dropped nearly 30% rapidly.In regard to approval, it is almost a meaningless measure. Having an approval rating of 90+ is pretty safe, but as soon as you drop to 80 or so (keep in mind that U.S. Presidents largely have approval ratings of ~50%), rebellions happen constantly unless you are eliminating rebels (which is expensive). The further it falls, the more impossible it becomes to return the approval to the higher rating, largely because the constant threats result in rebellions, resulting in destroyed property, resulting in lacking the funds to rebuild the buildings that increase approval or eliminate the rebels that destroy them.The military aspect of the game is useless. You can build a powerful military, but it ignores half of the threats that you come into contact with throughout the game. I lost several games because I had military units who refused to defend the palace. In other cases, the military units associate the battle with a specific location, that may not actually be associated with the battle, resulting in buildings (like guard towers) which get destroyed because your military is off defending a building and refuse to march to the actual location of the fight.All and all, the game was goo for a couple of yucks, but ultimately is so frustrating to play, do to a lack of sufficient information from the game designer and buggy units that I cannot recommend it.

												As a bit of a Tropico addict (the combination of silly political chicanery, toy-town construction and comparitive simplicity compared to other city builders), Tropico 5 is a waste of time compared to 4 or even 3. A slight graphical upgrade, but less content and virtually every new feature has an incredibly irritating dark side. The eras system essentially locks off 3/4 of the game's content for no justification and makes your old building redundant. Politics has been dumbed down in the extreme, making pleasing factions essentially a random process. Trading route economics means tedious micromanagement. The greater military focus means huge outlays for rebels that cannot seemingly be appeased or defeated, constant battles with seemingly random outcomes and incredibly important upgrades hidden in rarely-accessed menus. The campaign's focus on four islands means a nice sense of investment, but as every mission has to be playable on one of two choices, say hello to incredibly bland islands with pretty much every resource - and sod if you can guess which island would be best to play the subsequent mission in each era on, because you can't play more than one mission in each era per island.

												Worse in pretty much every way to Tropico 4 other than slightly improved graphics.Get Tropico 4 instead.The console rot has finally infested this series.I literally do not get how you can make the UI worse.- It's less user friendly ingame (bulky and no favourites).- You're forced to cycle through options instead of having dropdowns (terrible in char creation).- Stripped out the decent sandbox creation features.- No difficulty rating.- No descriptive tooltips on settings, so I am sat here wondering how temperature will effect the experience.- Have to pay 1000 dollars to "explore" the fog of war with your miltary, whom sometimes dont even reach their destination, so exploring the entire island costs a fortune.- Game is too easy, you have no problem with cashflow.- Mines are now placed snugly into ugly horseshoe-shaped rocks.- Trading is shallow and removes the challenge of limited resources.- Military is a badly designed uncontrollable mess.- DLC doesn't add enough to be worth it either.- The largest maps just aren't very big!It just feels like several half arsed elements of a game slapped together for consoles.The devs really need to sit down and fix this shambles by returning to their roots of the original Tropico and some good elements of T2 and T4, and then looking at other games that do certain elements right:Building, simulation, zoning, districts etc: Cities SkylinesConcise ship combat and trading: Anno 1404Land combat and deforestation: Aoe2Uninstalled, back to T4.

number of helpful: 21 of 30 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												I was enjoying this game. The music's good, the graphics look great, the new trade system is nice... But then I hit a wall: The game will not load past the loading screen on a campaign mission. I go to the forums, and other people are having the same issue. There's a workaround, but it's not working for everyone. And there's no official response from the developers on when or if they intend on fixing it. Other heavily advertised features of the game, such as Multiplayer, are locking up on players frequently. Oh, and it doesn't have a save functioon, so even if they do happen to make it some ways into the game, they gotta start from scratch if they have to leave. Still others complain that the game won't even start. Again, there are workarounds, but it should not be incumbent upon the consumer to find fixes for a "finished" game that was just so recently released. New games have bugs, I get it. I can understand the traffic glitch that forces your teamsters to get stuck, unable to transport  commodities to the docks for export and causing your economy to plunge. That's annoying, but it's an easy fix in game once you recognize it. I cna understand how trade ships might just magically disappear from your inventory, preventing you from utilizing them. Annoying, but you still at least have trade ships, and the computer freighters still come to export, so that's more of a minor inconvenience. I can even forgive them for forcing you to accept new immigrants at a steady speed even when you've indicated in your Constitution that the borders will be closed.But I can not understand how the developers decided it a releaseable product when players are unable to complete Sandbox missions because the game doesn't register that they've accomplished the primary objective on the mission. Or how they determined a final release should have a game breaking bug, the likes of which I haven't seen in a game of this budget since Big Rigs. I guess a 30% success rate on multiplayer matches making it through era changes was high enough by Kalypso's standards. And maybe that's why they didn't figure the mode needed saves; because no one makes it far enough.I want to recommend this game. It's got good potential; even though they reduced the total amount of buildings, and therefore functionality, from previous Tropicos; or put a heavier emphasis on the military's role without expanding on the mechanics behind the military units, forcing you to watch the horribly programmed AI duke it out and hope that your side wins.But at its current stage, I can not and will not recommend this unfinished garbage to anyone.

content:
9, 2016
												I really enjoyed the gameplay- moving through the eras and the challenge of the scenarios (although I've been doing it on 'easy' budget and it's still difficult to stay above water, but I do like to accumulate at speed). There are a number of maps to play and the scenarios have you juggle two islands at a time so you're not starting from scratch every time with a new island and the longevity of the islands you build is greater as you revisit it frequently to continue building. I did hit a budget snag on one of my games where I lost about a grand a month for no discernible reason (the budget said I shoud have more coming in than going out and it's unclear where costs can be cut. I had a huge labour shortage, too.) Fortunately the game completed when I was on about -100,000 and the people were at 43% happiness!The reason I wouldn't recommend this game is because there are so few buildings available. Only two choices, tall and small, on the apartment buildings- how hard would it have been to throw in a couple of recolours? This means on quite a large island you're going to repeat the same patterns again and again, with only one upgraded house, an unupgradable mansion, and a tall or short upgraded apartment block, all identical. There are a few parks, but very few seem to offer paths to walk on, which means citizens move oddly through them (although it's nice that they can sit on benches in the parks with paths)- it would have been nice if there were a few more options. The entertainment options are very much lacking- and only a couple of them are small enough to place frequently around the map, so you end up having a visually unappealing map with hundreds of identical buildings. On looking for an expansion to up the number of buildings- new high-quality housing large and small, additional much needed entertainment buildings like a zoo, waterpark, alternative restaurant, children's playpark, a grade school required by some employers but not available int he game... I discovered there are many cheap expansion packs, but all with only one building each, mostly employment buildings relating to a new scenario. None of the buildings I'd like to really customise my game!To summarise- if all you care about is the politics, managing a budget and keeping your factions happy, you'll enjoy this game, but maybe wait until it's on sale. If you're a builder who wants their town to look authentic or aesthetically more interesting than 4 buildings repeated 100 times each you're probably going to want to give this a miss.

content:
4, 2015
												Haemimont Games finally added a mission editor. It's a little late, but a very welcome update which makes the base game well worth getting, especially if it's on a sale.Tropico 5 uses a new engine and completely remade graphics, unlike Tropico 4 which simply expanded on Tropico 3. This being said, your old tricks and tactics won't work, so you will get a fresh new experience from playing this.Pros:+new eras feature allows you to advance and rule through time: colonial era, the World Wars , the Cold War and Modern Times, each era has different foreign nations, factions and availible buildings and edicts+new combat system gives you more control over the defense of your buildings+new research feature+new trade route feature allowing you to manage specific imports and exports, which also affects your foreign relations+the ability to form your own dynasty, which can be involved in certain missions+new policies feature allows you to declare and decide laws on your island, giving you freedom of choice over your method of ruling it+continous campaign system which allows you to pick and carry over your old islands over several missions+competitive and cooperative multiplayer+ingame radio is still as enjoyable as it was in the older games, complete with soundtrack and radio host which comments on island events+the ability to make custom sandbox maps and missionsCons:-the new combat system sometimes takes unoptimal routes, and in multiplayer it is very easy for a player to quick-build military buildings and rush the opponent-campaign lacks an actual challenge-the competitive multiplayer component is entirely reliant on luck and map placement, rather than skill-fewer actors and faction representatives than in Tropico 4-fewer buildings and building models than in Tropico 4 (all the missing buildings were either useless or served the same function as other better alternatives, so this is only aesthetically damaging)-the same cheap DLC marketing methodConclusion:The base game is worth getting now, at least during sales. The DLCs, however, still don't offer enough, so I'd advise you to avoid those, or get them during a big sale.The mission editor (through steam workshop) will offer you great, near infinite replayability, for as long as people keep playing and making scenarios. But you can't just expect custom missions to magically appear, so I encourage you to try your hand at making a mission once you finish the main campaign!I will go do that right now.

number of helpful: 16 of 22 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
5, 2014
												When first diving in, Tropico 5 seems like a promising experience.  Unfortunately, you're going to bang your head against the concrete, because it just isn't that deep.  Verterans of Tropico 4, in particular, are going to find themselves looking for things that just aren't there.  Minor spoilers below:Pros: Tropico 5 sports some upgraded graphics and a couple of new game mechanics that work fairly well.  The timeline is expanded, and the game's main campaign does a decent job of fostering a sense of "era" and moving through history in a way that earlier installments in the series did not.  El Presidente now gets his/her own Dynasty, and the player has the option of training and leveling up several characters with different skill sets.  Any of these characters can be El Prez, while the others can be tasked as Managers to improve the efficiencies of buildings.Cons: Despite the upgraded graphics, Tropico 5 is just missing a lot of customization options that were taken for granted in 4.  Almost no building in the game has an alternate look, so housing blocks tend to look generic.  The decorative options are also fewer, and look much more "cardboard" when compared to Tropico 4's decorations.  Many building types have also been combined in ways that don't make sense.  I spent 30 minutes trying to figure out where the option to build a fire station was, only to find out this was an "upgrade" for my police station.Trade in Tropico 5 doesn't make much sense, period.  You can "trade" resources continually, but to get better prices for goods, you need a trade ship, which you obtain one at a time by building a dock.  Want 5 trade ships?  Build 5 docks.  The trade system scales poorly, has little information provided by the game HUD, and requires a fair amount of micormanagement.The character development and voice acting have definitely taken a big step down.  While Penultimo is reasonaby well done, the other characters in the story line are either flat or overdone.  The faction leaders from prior games (Sunny, Reverend Esteban, etc) are nowhere to be seen and there is no commentary to replace them.  If you want to know how a particular faction is feeling, you will find yourself constantly digging through the menus to do it.For veterans of Tropico 4 looking for a few hours of fun, pick this up when it goes on sale.  If you're new to the series, just go pick up Tropico 4 and skip this one.

number of helpful: 16 of 22 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												Honestly speaking, this is my first time playing Tropico series. I am truly intrigued. You are El Presidente, basically, a dictator of a tropical island nation. As a dictator, the entire nation is under your control. The historical period of this game ranges from the colonial era to its modern counterpart. For each period there is one or two particular types of economic activities that are lucrative and beneficial. You always have to change your construction plan over time. For example, in the Colonial Era, plantations and ranches generate money but as the time passes on you can't count on those to fight the Great War. After the Cold War the space program and internet become crucial as well.It is not only a city construction simulation but a political one as well. You are the sole policymaker. You have to consider all aspects of your nation in terms of policymaking. Should I reduce the wages of the poor to gain public support? Should I use martial law to secure the position of my dynasty? Should I fight the Communists with the US or the other way around? This game is fancinating!

content:
r 5, 2016
												The last tropico game I'll buyGraphics updates are nice, but late game infrastructure is still a mess and the campaign is significantly worse.The worst part about Tropico 5 is the extent to which I don't care about playing the campaign missions. The campaign leaves you with two basic islands to build off of, and your progress carries over mission-mission. This means that the actual act of 'city-building' gets extremely limited - because missions are now about tacking on some arbitrary requirement rather than striving for the most efficient/aesthetically pleasing system. Furthermore, as there are limitations on the number of consecutive times you can re-use an island, both islands have to be able to accommodate any industry (as missions can often boil down to 'make x, y, and then z industry'). Accommodating every industry makes the islands generic - taking away the adaptation game of Tropicos past of dealing with soil/resource/beauty variances. The overarching plot is dumb, and political tweaks (especially over-militarization as detailed in other reviews) just makes things worse.

												Tropico 5 has some neat improvements, including research, moving through new eras, and some steps to reduce micromanagement of previous games.  But it's also got some game-crippling bugs that cause your buildings to stop working.Most importantly, the campaign is pretty short and takes place on the same 4 islands over and over. number of helpful: 51 of 88 people (58%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
er 29, 2014
												I loved Tropico 4, rule your own country, make your economy rise, satisfy your people, execute those in your way, ♥♥♥♥ off foreign countries and wave your nuke around to prevent them from invading. These are just some of the things you can do in the previous game and are still present in 5. But Tropico 5 changed in different ways, military became much more critical, forces are stronger thus stronger defense is required. Trade routes can be chosen and relations with foreign countries' relations affect these. You progress through time and things change even more than Modern Times DLC in 4. Housing is more interconnected with job salary and sometimes you experience problems but don't know the details until you see a detail that changes your prespective. The game provides a bigger mirror to the perspective of a dictator, things need to be watched more often and closely, you must be prepared and at the same time be able to adapt to the situations you must be watchful of such as civil unrest and the end of WWII.Everything got more difficult, more complex, in some cases worse than 4, I miss the old Penultimo, I missing allowing no rent to all residentials, I miss the diverse set of characters and more. But 5 had some things I really liked, the campaign was something I didn't expect and loved, the fact that you make your island grow and don't abandon it at the end of the episode makes you see how difficult it gets to run a country the longer it stays alive. You have multiplayer (which sucked earlier on until some updates) where you cooperate or kill each other with armies and resources. Military played a bigger role, both a good thing and a bad thing because I didn't give a damn about it til 5.Bottomline, Tropico 5 is like a more difficult version of 4, things need to be watched more often as the threat level of everything got more critical such as rebels, civil unrest and pirates and the campaign requires you to realize that you are NOT going to abandon your country and ALL problems you experience now WILL happen into the future unless YOU fix it while you can. Tropico 5 is a great game and I value it as I value 4 but in different ways.If you've played Tropico 4 and loved it as it is and don't want things to change, then stick with it. If you value a bigger challenge, a more complex way of playing it, a chance to compete with other dictators (heads up, few people go online anymore so find a friend) and to realize how difficult it is to manage your own lil island then go buy this, hell it's Steam anyway. Price too high? Steam Sale!

number of helpful: 10 of 12 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												Yes, it seems like Tropico 3 and 4 may have been the peaks for this franchise - I too have been playing since the original. The game looks better but you certainly don't feel like you have the freedom to be a true dictator (fewer personality characteristics, PAINFULLY dumbed-down almanac, dumbed-down economic system, dumbed-down faction system, not enough edicts, etc.). It seems like they also brought alot of half-baked concepts into this game (research, trade, constitution,  etc. - all good ideas) whereas maybe they should have focused on just one of those concepts and made it really decent. What happened to our pre-election speeches? (We need MORE of those types of things).   It's almost as if the game is under new mangement and that the management is out of touch with what has made the game such a great hit - we don't care so much about what El Presidente looks like, we want more gameplay freedom.We care about having a wider range of political and economic options so that we can tweak and abuse our little island nation for our purposes! Why can't we specifically control wages or rent prices anymore - what if I want a farmer to make twice as much as a doctor?    As a fan of the franchise, I feel like #5 has simply taken several steps in the wrong direction - we needed a political and economic system that had even greater depth, not much, much less. It seems like the developers are getting carried away with the looks and zaniness of the game rather than the original concept of the game - that in which a control-freak dictator can run his island nation however he likes, with an endless array of customizable methods on how to do just that! Think Tropico 3 and 4 but with an even  greater range of economic and political freedom and abilities - we can't even place trees, fountains or intimidating statues anymore...   Overall, a 4/10 - a beautiful game but not nearly the political and economic game it once was. I do like the addition of tanks, though. Also, the concept of trade deals is a good one but still seems not completely thought-out. I will be sticking with previous versions of the game to satisfy future dictatorial urges...I hope the franchise makes a 180 for the next release. Instead of making a good model even better, they seem to have tried to renovate the franchise, which, to me, is undermining what has made the franchise so good. I recommend it to those who are new to the franchise, but would further recommend previous versions.

content:
, 2016
The newest member to the Tropico family brings all the main features from previous titles with a slight enhancement in graphics and gameplay.  This is a game I really enjoyed playing. Having an option to build my island and accompany it from an early settlement, a minor colony, till the modern days with technologies of this actual millennium. I enjoyed both being a totalitarian leader and beloved el presidente, ruling with an iron hand or with system based on democratic roots. The game allows you to change so many aspects of the game with a dozens of edicts, constitution options, foreign relationships and island infrastructure, that you have a wide range of options where to head with your leadership. Do you want to lead an industrial progressive small tropical island? Or would you rather it to be a tourist resort? communist paradise? or latinoamerican junta? Now you have a chance, so grab it and rule!Pros✪ It's Tropico!✪ The Eras changing in this game I see as the main feature which improves whole gameplay and complements research system. Thanks to tropico 5 you can experience colonial, world wars, cold war and modern eras on an carribean island. This is something really refreshing.✪ Dynasty - Now you can build your own dynasty which members  have overall effects on whole island and in addition can be appointed as managers.✪ Soundtrack - I love that! However for someone could be annoyingly repetitive.✪ Multiplayer - You can now compete with your friends even though MP doesnt vary much from SP. MP rather motivates you to improve your way of leadership - be more effective than your oponents.✪Constitution, basic pillar of a nation, can now be proclaimed and amended with a few policies which influence the gameplay afterwards.Cons✪ Immigration - Tropico isn't Europe. It's an island but it seems that also there the immigration is unstoppable no matter what you do.✪ Placement - I could really use some single trees etc. for empty spaces between buildings or next to roads where no whole building (or smth else) can fit. I would appreciate this feature very much.✪ Untransparency - Sometimes it happens that a building doesn't work and you just do not know why. Or you have empty houses and people rather live in the shacks for god knows why. No reasons, maybe they are just hipsters...✪ The campaigns could be more creative and better elaborated. Nothing much happens there you just build your island and focus on completing tasks, nothing special. At least this is my opinion. Overall7.5 /10The exact same amount of points as when I rated Tropico 4 considering all pros and cons.P.s. I wasnt able to set audio language to spanish while the rest of the game (interface etc.) remains in english. This option would complete the environment and atmosphere.

content:
ber 22, 2016
												If you enjoyed Tropico 4 (which was great if you’ve never played it), you will likely enjoy Tropico 5.  However, as someone who plays a lot of this genre of games, I will say Tropic 5 was the first Tropico where I actually had to become a dictator to survive.  Note I only play on hard mode since I do have a lot of experience with Tropico games.In every other Tropico game, all you had to do was give the people what they want (housing, food, religion, etc.) and they would vote for you.  I almost never had to issue Martial Law or assassinate someone, unless I just wanted to do it for kicks.  In Tropico 5, the factions have so much more power.  You can have an overall happiness of 80% and an approval rating of 35%, so if you don’t rig the election, you’re going to lose.  For example, if the majority of your population are environmentalists and you build a factory, you will take a huge hit in popularity.  It’s a pleasant surprise because no longer can you easily make huge island decisions and not be punished for it.  If you’ve done mostly communist things for ten years and then all of a sudden become best friends with the USA and make the plebs pay for their own food and medicine, your population will resent you and rebel, even if their overall happiness keeps improving. And hope that those in your military aren’t part of those unhappy factions because even high wages won’t always save you from a coup d’etat.Wages as they were in Tropico 3 and 4 are gone and have been replaced by something a little different.  I’m not a fan of it because when I’m rolling in the rum and oil dough, I’d like to be able to raise everyone’s wage at the same time and now that can only be done on a per building type basis—and each type of farm is considered a different building, so you can’t even raise all farmers’ wages at the same time, you must go into each type of farm and change it.  They also replaced Penultimo’s voice actor with someone much less annoying, and it bothers me.Overall, it is definitely a buy if you can get it on sale.  It’s quite different from previous versions but has the same feel-you definitely know you're playing a Tropico game.  As I’ve said though, if you’ve historically been a loving, graceful, democratic leader who would never really use the Secret Police to aid you, this game might force you to change your ways.

content:
, 2014
												Do I recommend this game - yes or no? Well I wish there had been a "maybe".Because if you haven't played the series before and like City Builders, I'd absolutelyrecommend it: nice graphics, game design, sounds and music, lots to do, user-friendly interface and with a political and historical aspect to it.On the other hand, as for myself, who have played the series from the start -it's a waste of money - really. A lot of great features - like many buildings and edicts has beenremoved and replaced with others. In fact - edicts, witch I find the most enjoyable in Tropico,are much fewer in Tropico 5 - sadly. The historical aspect, where you go through Colonial, World Wars, Cold Wars and Modern Times, at first sounds interesting - but fact is, in ruins the free gameplay totally, and will in a few weeks time (if not days), feel extremely repetitive. Because you can only buy buildings in specific historical times and when you have researched many of them. I want to play a sandbox game where I have the most freedom to build my Tropico "paradise" with only money and some resources hindering me in doing just that. I don't want to be controlled be a game developer dictatorship - I'm the DICTATOR!So stick with Tropico 3 or 4 - if you already have one of these - you won't get much new here,and the new stuff in Tropico 5 will ONLY annoy you.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Off the record and not very hush-hush:In general (Tropico 5 being the sum of that) I simply don't understand what game developers, are thinking about when they make a game. Do they actually play the games themselves?I can hardly believe that - why would you put in stuff that are extremely annoying? And removeprevious great features? It doesn't make any sense. And do they not read and listen to whattheir game communities says or wishes? And what about game testers? Do they actually listento them? Or do they get the wrong people to test the games?But of course - if it's only about making money, it's a clever idea, to make half a decent game,them you'll have an excuse to make yet another game (read: update) to correct the annoying things, that people don't like and put in new annoying things - that way you can keep a series going on for as long as you want. EA being another perfect example of that. Gamers really have to stop falling for that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. Developers - make games that you actually want to play yourself -Rockstar Games, Naughty Dogs and Bohemia Interactive are good examples of that. Not that they don't make mistakes, but you have a feeling that they make games they wantto play themselves.

												First of all, Tropico 5 is way longer than I expected, which is great, as I do enjoy long games that frustrate you. I played on hard and was forced multiple times to restart missions or redo the entire playthrough due to mistakes I've made. Which is just great!Now lets get down to it, is Tropico 5 just like Tropico 1-2-3-4? A short answer would be no. A long answer will be hell no.Tropico 5 is built on what made the tropico series great. City building and controlling your island as El President is addictive. All that you loved from the older games you will find here as well. However Tropico 5 is bringing a lot of new things to the series.In the older games, you could find a balance and then you would NEVER have any kind of problems again with money, well Tropico 5 skull ♥♥♥♥s that and makes you work for it. Just as you think, “Ah ! I finally figured out how to keep my money in plus”, you will go in huge minus due to one of the many random events.The interface and gameplay in many ways will make you feel like home. But all the new things will toss you a curve ball all the time and keep you on your toes, I had to play the last mission 6 times in a row (Yea ! I'm not kidding, 6 freaking times) to even understand what I did wrong and to finally beat it. In the other Tropicos this would never have happened.The graphics are brilliant as well as the humor. Lets not forget that there is MULTIPLAYER. That's right, 2 Presidents trying to either kill each other or work together for a greater goal.Tropico 5 is everything I personally wanted from a new Tropico game and I can only strongly recommend it. There are tons of DLC's but be careful what you buy as not all of them are worth the money.So to sum up, grab the game for sure and grab the DLC's when they are on sale!

number of helpful: 11 of 15 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2016
												Tropico 5 just never hit it home like the predecessors in the series have.  At first it seemed like a direct copy of 4 with some features either added or removed.  I want to like this game but there are so many things just holding it back, chiefly the DLC spam fest that this company has set forth with this game.  Tropico 3 and 4 had similar DLC but not to the extent that this game has.  Another issue I have with the game is the poor optimization for OS X.  While I used to have a windows box and will be building a new one, I am on OS X for the time being and the game just runs terrible for the specs listed.  If I turn off grass everything magically improves, why even bother porting it if you are going to do a half-♥♥♥ job?  Tropico 5 also removed some of my faovrite characters from the 4th, while this isn't necessairly bad, Pinultimo was changed for the worse in my opinion.  Other things follow but they are all small but add up to my dissatisfaction.  But, on to the things that I like about the game.One of the biggest changes that I enjoy was the ability to play with a friend on the same island.  This introduced  mechanic that lets you play relaxed and have a good time while subjugating or liberating your people.  Additionally, some of the newer buildings are nice as well as the other options they added to the edicts. The graphics haven't improved much but they are still decent, if anything they enhanced the color.Overall, the game's performance issues despite having way more than the recommended settings, removal of key character voice acting, terrible pathing of the military (they seemingly walk past rebels in the way to get to their destination), the money solves everything mentality, and much more ruined the game for me.  I won't be coming back to Tropico ever again.  Tropico 1,2,3,and 4 are fantastic and something to enjoy but the buck stops here in the series for me.  Your milage may vary but I find the continual rehashing of the same thing getting old.  I also find that the pay for features that should have been part of the game concept undesirable.

Perhaps Tropico 5 will become even better than past iterations, eventually, but with this sad precedent the company have screwed themselves. I will not bother paying release price for their games again, and I highly recommend that you do not either, Ignore this game for  another 6 months, and maybe they will update it enough to be worth the price tag. But whatever you do, don't pay the full £35.

												I've loved the tropico series, four was fantastic.  five? lacks the same charm in so many ways, my biggest problem is with the colonial age era.. it feels poorly tacked on, there is little to do during it and they didn't even bother putting period matching music in it. The research system is very boring, rather then letting you unlock differant bonuses to buildings and improve the things you have.. it's just a system to ever so slowly dole out the same buildings you had in tropico 4, The Voice actors were universaly bad, the comments didn't seem as witty, Much of the customization from building to building that the earlier games had was striped out nearly entirely.. as was the customization for your ruler. rather then dozens of "perks" flaws and other attributes to pick from and play with, you get to select one of like six. the dynasty system also is as pointless as boring. despite what they hinted it prerelease.. you don't age and die and have to be replaced by one of your family.. you just put a differant perk on each "tool" and elect the one that currently best fits what you want. not that the abilities matter a great deal. Decorative items have been stripped out so no more creating visualy pleasing cities. nor can you jail criminals. All and all the game feels like Tropico 4, if it had been lengthened out in size, and stripped of a fair ammount of content to "streamline it." I was disipointed by the game.  im sure a flood of DLC will be coming to slowly rectify the situation. but unlike with tropico 4 I don't feel the urge to buy it.. honestly I felt like one of the Factory Farm livestock from it. shoved in a small pen and shoveled this "Corn" to make them money.

content:
22, 2015
												Having spent a significant amount of time playing Tropico 4, there is something very off-putting about Tropico 5. In Tropico 4, one would always start fresh with each campaign mission. In Tropico 5, the island is carried over between missions. There are benefits to this, but it changes the way the player plays the game. There are buildings the player might want to put near the coast that aren't available until later missions, but it's quite likely the coast will already be well developed by the time those buildings can be built. This forces the player to build akwardly, with future additions in mind, to demolish what are in many cases expensive buildings to make room for new ones, or to simply learn to live with a less-than-ideal situation that will penalize them moving forward. Many of the interface changes between 4 and 5 seem to make it more difficult to access information rather than easier. There seem to be fewer useful overlays and the overlay can be very difficult to read. Some buildings or building upgrades have an effective radius that can't be viewed, leaving the player guessing. It's still very difficult to easily see what areas are being served by which service buildings. The interface changed from 4 to 5, but that really seems to be the extent of it. It wasn't improved in any significant way. It's just different.There are good points to the new game as well. Features I would be excited about if the rest of the game didn't feel clumsy. The introduction of research, upgrades and building managers are all interesting features. Greater variety in the military is also very interesting, though the military itself is clumsy to use and combat can be rather infuriating. There are some clever additions made in this iteration that might see better development in a sequel.The core gameplay of Tropico is still there, so some may enjoy this. First time players may not find as much fault with the game. Personally, i'll hold out hope that (the likely inevitably sequel) Tropico 6 will fine tune things and simply be a better game on whole.

content:
y 12, 2015
												Is this a good game? Yes, it actually gave me a few hours of fun before it dried out.Do I recommend this above any other city builder? Not at all.I have enjoyed playing both Tropico 3 and 4, not because of the unbelievably easy AI as seen in 5, but because of the ability to control my city and fix its problems. Tropico 5 not only shields you from changing your laws in less than 28 months, but linearly guides you on what to build next. In previous titles, missions were an optional thing that you could participate in, depending on the mission. But, in Tropico 5, say the communists want you to build them a row of 15 houses; you now have to option to cancel the mission, causing the communists to hate you literally for the entire game, OR, you can go into national debt by building the houses, and have a nice little +1 boost to happiness.This prevents players from building the island nation of their dreams, and instead they get a moshpit of infighting communists, capitalists, and acoholic religious zealots. But, don't worry, you can fix the opinions of EVERYBODY for the new DLC called Waterborne, at the low cost of $40! You get off-shore oil derricks for the capitalists, more coastal homes for the commies, and the religious--well, you can get alongside a future character creator expansion for only $15.Seriously, though; every month it seems that features that should have been in the game already are released as DLC bundles. If you look closely, you can see that, in the time of the game's original release, it was coded so that future DLCs would plug right in; before the off-shore oil derricks, we had off-shore oil deopsits visible. Why? Because monehs.The game with every DLC is a good game, but until Kalypso stops dicing off features and putting on a price tag for all of them, do NOT buy this. My final verdict is a petty 3/10.5/24/2015 Edit:I finally came back to the game to see if they had added anything in new patches; all I got was four new DLC's. Expect Tropico 6 to be even sketchier; maybe we will have a one-time 10 population boost for the price of a $5 gem pack.Everybody, go home, back to Tropico 4; this was a bust.6/4/2015 Edit:I laughed this morning when I opened Steam to find Kalypso gave me the Green DLC for free.I now completely change my mind about this game and the developers, they are so generous by giving me their cheapest DLC for free. 11/10 would be bribed again

												A great game, held back by one huge flaw.  You lose everything at each era change, so everything you have built becomes negative income.  And since all of your trade routes go away too, there is zero incentive to spend any time in any era but the final one.  During one game, I had $260,000 entering the World War era, and it was increasing.  2 years into the World War era, I was in the red, being invaded, and dealing with uprisings.  I didn't have the money to upgrade my army, and got thrashed.  In a subsequent game, I was rushing each era, and managed to get through to the modern era with little trouble.  IMHO, any game that penalizes you for playing the game isn't a good game.  Get rid of that horrible transition problem, and this would be a 9/10 game.  With it, 5/10.

content:
4, 2014
												Tropico 5 was a game I picked up after watching a few YouTubers mess around with it, and so I investigated the steam page and from there things went swish!It has a nice quirky story, while might slightly infuriate you, is quite rewarding in the end but sadly not made out to be that much of an achievement.  The characters you'll come to either love or dislike , I however never got tired of Penulitimo's comments or Lord Oaksworth's trails.For the most part this game made me feel like I could actually achieve something by building a settlement and attempting to set it up right and in the most efficient way possible, something that Simcity 5 couldnt really achieve, or at least not very well.  While Simcity didnt do a terrible job at creating your own settlement, there were no actual problems or issues with money or power politically at all after completing your city, effectively making your only problem at that point the efficiency and placement of buildings, or the bugs inscripted in the game itself which rendered a problem unsolveable.Tropico 5 puts you in control of everything as the ''President For Life'', as a Roman ruler once said, for production of all goods and foods, public buildings, the army, and social and constitutional matters.  Stuff up and fail to get the support of your people, and your time as El Presidente could well be up with military coups, rebel attackers, major powers invading your island (if you get them really peeved), or an annoying combination of two of these issues, OR the simple fact the you should have cheated or cheated harder in the elections.  Simcity was lacking this redeeming feature of actually trying to hold onto power, and after a decade you were basically done in that city alone (even though the game controls said otherwise).I am a bit disappointed with the emptyness of multiplayer rooms and hearing that it had problems early on also didnt help its reputation either.  I'm also not happy with the news of a hacker who managed to figure out that for future DLC's, money will be required for most, if not all 10 future DLC's over the next year or so.  Most of the DLC's did nothing for Simcity, and actually didn't add much for the game except visual appeal, so I hope that these DLC's either aren't useless or will be free and useful at some point.Another complaint would be at the achievements.  Some seem too easy to get, while others might take along time to figure out and be able to complete.  Not as much of a biggie, but just something to keep in mind if DLC's factor into future achievements.The biggest complaint I would have however would be the seemingly inefficiency the infustructure buildings get by the modern era/age, seriously, it gets pretty annoying once you hit a population of 1000 and truck offices are everywhere and arent seemingly doing a lot.  I just dont get it, if you get stuffed over by this, then you could be stuck in negative bank numbers, and mostly the only way to solve a problem in this game is to throw money at it, and without exporting goods which seem to stock up in the production buildings being delivered to the docks (because the trucks aren't working for some reason), you've basically signed your defeat, and woe to you if its near an election or popularity is taking a hit and the people want change!If you brought Tropico 4, then its a question of if you want spend the money on this one, but from what I've seen its a great overhall of the old game which might only do a few things better (and possibly worse) than its elder.Overall, fantastic game, I would recommend to anyone interested in town planner games or political-type strategy with building elements, as while becomes harder to manage in the future ages, is actually rewarding in the end and might teach you some lessons along the way, if not the occassional laugh at Penultimo.This game I hope won't finish here, as the developers are capable of achieving much more and adding some more layers on this cake.The music is pretty cool also, wouldn't mind seeing some more music tracks in the future though!

content:
, 2014
												I'm completely gutted that Tropico 5 is such a terrible game. I've been a fan of the series who followed every release back to the original Tropico, and in the week leading up to the Tropico 5 release (of which I pre-ordered a 4-pack) I replayed Tropico 2 : Pirate's Cove through for about the 30th time. Old graphics, a few annoying design flaws, but even in 2014 still a spectacularly fun game, just like Tropico 1, Tropico 3, and Tropico 4... but not Tropico 5. For the first time in the history of the Tropico series we've got a new Tropico game released that is not only not a fun game, it isn't even a Tropico game. Packed with bad design decisions, content compromises, and maddeningly simplified with console limitations/mainstream stupidity in mind, for the first time in Tropican history we've got a game that can't be fixed with patches because the base game is so incredibly, irreparably broken. Tropico 5 is a corporate "game-by-committee" insult to each and every fan of both Poptop's original Tropico creation and Heinimont's mostly-faithful torch-bearing continuation of the series since then. It's a bad game, badly designed, falsely advertised, and will never become a proper Tropico game without a complete overhaul of every design mechanic of the strategy gameplay.Let's begin with the interface. Gone is the functional and useful interface we all know and love, with the traditional Tropico feel, intuitive layout, plenty of options, and helpful tooltip popups for every sub-menu or screen. The layout for Tropico 5 is much simpler, missing many important screens, with less information on every screen, and with almost no tooltip popups on any screen. Building upgrades no longer have any graphical representation, and the upgrades aren't located on the primary building screen, so you're forced to tediously check every single upgradeable building on your island with 2 mouse clicks on parts of the screen that are never near each other. This is unforgivably tedious and by itself makes the micromanagement of Tropico 5 unbearable beyond words, especially considering that buildings freshly built or destroyed in disasters revert to the default settings, necessitating constant micromanagement of every single building on the island.What about the lack of content? Tropico 5 advertises, even to date, "Choose from over 100 buildings from each of the individual eras." This is false advertising. Counting all the buildings up I can only come up with 91 total, and that includes every building from all the eras. Maybe campaign mode has a few unique buildings used only in the campaign, but I never saw any, and even then there's no way to get "over 100 buildings from each of the individual eras." I count 91 buildings in Tropico 5 and 117 in Tropico 4, so this is simply false advertising. No way around it. Furthermore, every Tropico fan who owns Tropico 5 will be quick to tell you why they lied about it: tons and tons of vital and important buildings and even building types are missing from Tropico 5. Take just one example: Prisons. In Tropico 4 you had Jail, Labor Camp, and you could turn the colonial fort into a dungeon for your personal dictatorship needs. Tropico 5 has no prisons or even a concept of jail. You cannot arrest anyone in Tropico 5. Crime is reduced to an overlay and a happiness number, and occasionally you see Crime Lord characters appear in the game that you can have a marginal interaction with. By marginal, I mean Bribe, Banish, Kill, or Discredit, the same 4 actions you have available for you to deal with every single island inhabitant in the game. To quote someone from the forum, "How does El Presidente run a dictatorship without prisons?" To heavily belabor this point, what about salt mines, fire stations, radio stations, wind power, solar power, and condos? "How does El Presidente run an island paradise without condos?" Why is there only one type of restaurant, "Restaurant", when Tropico 4 had "Restaurant", "Gourmet Restaurant", "Ship-O-Rant", and "Cosmic Pin", all of which were better rendered, described, and implemented?This brings me to the graphics of Tropico 5, the major selling point of the game, yet still underwhelming and poorly implemented. Tropico 5 requires DX11 for reasons that I can only describe as dishonest. It doesn't need DX11 or any of the hardware functions implemented therein, and the official excuse for the requirement, and I directly quote from the official Tropico 5 Steam forum, "The game and engine were redesigned from scratch as was requested by many players", simply does not hold water. Tropico 5 is coming to XBOX360 soon, an old console that is only DX9 slightly extended, and in such context the publisher/developer excuse can be clearly viewed as PR nonsense meant to cover up the fact that Tropico 5 is a functional disaster. The graphics aren't very good, there are only a few high end features added on near the end of the development cycle purely for marketing window dressing, and tessellation, if implemented, has been implemented so poorly that it renders the overall graphic package functionally of a lower quality than Tropico 4. HBAO/SSAO simply can't cover up bad design, and forcing the DX11 requirement on top of the substandard graphics is just insulting.The biggest success of the Tropico series was always in the gameplay, and the gameplay is where Tropico 5 fails the most spectacularly. To understand the level of failure you have to understand how previous Tropico games were successful. In Tropico 1/3/4 you started with a few people, a palace, a couple farms, maybe a tenement, and a blank slate to design a society. If you wanted a peasant serfdom that you ruled through fear of your military might you had many avenues through which to engineer this society, any the effectiveness of your approach was purely determined by how well you engineered your economy, balanced competing concerns, and reacted to changing circumstances. As one example, you could focus on mining, pay the miners/police/military high wages, and give the finger to everyone else, dominating and controlling their lives through fear, imprisonment, labor camps, many detailed and useful edicts, and even through pathing and placement of buildings (indeed, in Tropico 2 the latter is essential for accomplishing ANYTHING). Now what can you do? The budget tool replaces rent/wages/cost and a lot more, and since it only has 5 positions, you've got no subtlety to your economic engineering. Low means low EVERYTHING: rent, wages, maintenance cost, production output, housing quality, etc, etc, etc. Same for high, which functionally turns the budget 5-way into a Win/Lose slider.For all intents and purposes, Tropico 5 is not actually a Tropico game at all. Tropico was always a social engineering game, and in Tropico 5 you do not have the necessary tools to engineer your desired society... or ANY society. All you can do in Tropico 5 is build, react to popups, and set the 5-way Budget selector (the Win/Lose slider) to "Win" on every building that you build. It's really that simple, and there's no room to do much else. You could always set the Win/Lose slider to "Lose" I suppose. There's no way to win or lose creatively when there is not an underlying framework governing the simulation. Simcity 5 proved this very clearly, and Tropico 5 insists on following in those same pointless, infuriating footsteps. The fact that someone found 10 DLC confirmed titles listed in the launch config files says it all. Tropico 5 is a greedy, absolutely cynical cashgrab for mainstream/console gaming dollars and it throws away almost every good idea that brought the series this far. Spending 108 dollars to pre-order a 4-pack of this worthless game is a watershed moment in my 34-year-old life as a computer gamer. If you can't trust Tropico, who can you trust?
