content:
r 2, 2014
												A nice update from the previous titles in the series, this one new graphics and mechanics to make the experience new again. The campaign itself is very enjoyable as it takes place over several ages where you begin in the colonial time and progress to new periods as the campaign progresses.Some of the new mechanics involve the economy, as you can now select specific commodities to import and export, granting you the ability to buy low and sell high, while also allowing you to target industries you'd normally lack resources to develop. Other changes also include military buildings also producing different kings of military units (e.g., Army Bases result in 3 tanks per base), which makes military expansion more strategic compared to the previous interations.Also with this version is the inclusion of Online Multiplayer, which unfortunately, I have not been able to participate in.Should you buy?-----------------------------Very much so. This is a fun macro-oriented city builder that provides an enjoyable experience. If you are a person who is compelled to buy DLC, then I suggest waiting for sales or special editions that bundle all the DLC together.

er 26, 2014
												Tropico 5 is far inferior to its predecessor.Tropico 5 is not the worst game I ever played, but it has less charme and worse game mechanics than Tropico 3 and 4 (I spent over 100 hours in each of them). - Multiplayer seems to be badly implemented and boring, feels very much tacked on without much thought.- I played through the whole game within 21 hours, which is about one third of the time I spent in the main campaign of Tropico 4.- The new combat mechanics are terrible, you don't have any meaningful control over your units.- The characters and advisors and their voice actors are far inferior than in the predecessor.- Streets and cars are a complete mystery because there are no real gargages anymore. Everything just happens somehow.- The needs of people and factions are not pointed out anymore and you can't hold voting speeches anymore.- The humor is lacking when compared to Tropico 4.- You again need some extra DRM account to play the game.

13, 2015
												Not a bad game, but I'm voting no for two reasons:1.) Vanillas Tropical 3 and 4 are both more substantive games. Had these not existed, this would be a thumb's up. As it stands, you'd get more for your money from either of those.2.) The incessant DLC. Don't get me wrong; I'm not against DLC. Make money for the devs, more content for us. But, for $4 apiece, you're getting a scenario, a costume, and one building. The costumes, for the most part, suck. The scenarios are okay for a one-off (though, generally speaking, sandbox is MUCH more entertaining). The buildings usually aren't substantive enough to stand on their own.Basically, if they bundled 2-3 of the DLCs and sold the bundles for $5, it'd be much more worthwhile.

number of helpful: 10 of 15 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												Only Tropico game that I've seriously disliked in the series.  Tropico 5 fails by effectively being a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ stripped-down iOS-tier ghost of it's predecessors.  Important gameplay and ui features are cut away, while the UI becomes more bloated and inefficient.  Familiar concepts that set the series apart from other city-builder sims -- like being able to customize your presidential faults and qualities, which makes the game more dynamic, gives the player a wide range of gameplay styles, additional challenges and creates greater replay value -- have been removed or cut down to a micron of thier former strength.The new concepts that are introduced (like FoW) are inconsistent with the genre, hindering that intrinsic creative value of city building.  The islands tend to be much smaller (in both campaign and sandbox) compared to the rest of the series.  The scale of buildings tend to feel bloated and awkward with few effective placeable locations.  Many of the 'new' elements are just disappointing replacements for previous staples, like cocoa being introduced but papayas being removed.  Dammit, I loved papayas...In addition to the cumulative restrictive effect of these changes, the game tends to play carrot-and-a-stick with what little choice you have left.  The campaign (and even sandbox mode) essentially constantly micro-manages the player, which is an unpleasant if not ironic twist on gaming.  At times this is mandatory and oppressive, others it's simply and option one can choose to ignore -- however there is no benefit to attempting to do things your own way.  The player is basically caged in and asked to perform specific meanial tricks.The UX is terrible and easily the worst-in-series.  I honestly felt that the Tropico 2 interface was cleaner, more usable and more efficient.  The Pop up build menu, which is ugly, bulky, and poorly laid out, interferes with with your world viewport inevitably blocking whatever it is you were trying to work on.  The overall design seems to be trying to accommodate touch interfaces, which in traditional iOS fashion means that your have to sacrifice detail and control for huge UI elements.  We've lost 2 degrees of speed control in Tropico 5.  The Overlay's have been turned into the ♥♥♥♥ing ugliest rainbow wire-grid that I've ever seen -- It's almost completely unusable.  The PiP viewport becomes annoying after 30 minutes, and takes up too much screen space as a non-interactive element.  All of the ui changes leave the player with less control and a more cluttered screen.  Useful elements like faction leader notices have been removed, as well as monthly/annual reports (like starvation and deaths from poor healthcare).  Mind you the game still internally wants you to build a new church, or improve healthcare, but you will be left in the dark to guess as to what the social problems are.3/10.  Do not buy.

content:
4, 2015
												Would I recommend this game? To anyone? Even my most hated enemies? No. That's the answer to all of the preceeding questions. Why, you ask? Now that's an answer that's more elaborate.Tropico is fun, don't get me wrong, but the fun you have with Tropico is the kinda fun you have while drunk or stoned. The kinda fun you have looking at a picture of a badger. It's not fun by sober standards, but when you're smoked outta your skull, it's hilarious.What I'm getting at here is that you pretty much need to be smashed or high to find Tropico thoroughly enjoyable. Unlike actually GOOD city-builder games, like SimCity 4, Cities: Skylines or hell, even Banished, you have ZERO control over ANYTHING in Tropico. You can build stuff. Whoop-dee-♥♥♥♥♥ety-doo. That is IT. That's ALL you get to do in Tropico.Enemies invading your turf? Your soldiers'll take care of that automatically. Built a new cluster of nice mansions and want to keep your elite soldiers away from living in them? Sorry, schmuck, but you can't do that. Want to make sure that your precious and EXTREMELY FINITE iron makes it to your weapons factories instead-a just getting exported for a shïte sum of pennies and dimes? BZZT! Wrong answer! You're not allowed to suspend exports either.Simply put, you can't control ANYTHING in Tropico, and that INEVITABLY leads to disastrous results. Maybe not this month, maybe not this year, but eventually, you'll run out of iron for your weapons factories or crude oil for your refineries, and your high-end exportation will come to a grinding halt because you simply can't tell your ♥♥♥♥♥twäts of a population to göddämn STOP SELLING SHÏT FOR TINY SUMS OF CASH.Ironically, many people laud this game for its simplicity. Those people are idiots. A city-building game should NEVER, EVER, sacrifice control for ease-of-use. Cities: Skylines is a good example of how to strike a decent-enough balance between simple-to-play without shaving off player control to an absolute minimum.So, to summarize: would I recommend this game? No. I would not. It's not worth even one FRACTION of the asking price on Steam, and the DLC-whöring? Yeah, no, that shït's not gonna fly with me. Simply put, this game series peaked with #4, and it rapidly went downhill with #5. It's not worth buying, not even for 0.99, and it's barely worth playing at all. Avoid it. 2.3/10

												imagine having to repeat senior year in high school depite all A's, honor roll, and graduating... in this case from the prior gem, version 4. content:
, 2014
												EDIT 1: I managed to get a somewhat speedy reply on a few of the issues I posted about in the game's official forum. Overall I am quite satisfied with Kalypso's course of action.Tropico 5 is a good game as far as difficulty and presentation goes.Right off the bat I noticed that the game runs better than the previous game on the same machine I played it on. There were times when I crashed due to large invasions but for the most part, the game has function well for about 95% of the time.The Modern Times DLC in Tropico 4 was somewhat of an introduction to the multi-era gameplay in Tropico 5. I like this as it makes the game a bit more dynamic. Prices adjust depending on the Era and available technologies, alliances, and political powers differ as well. All in all the multi-era feature is a great addition to the game.Combat in the game seems a bit lacking. I understand that combat is not the main feature of the game but if you plan to run a totalitarian state then you'd best expect to see lots of it. On addition to that, your dynasty members play a passive role during invasions, uprisings, and rebellions (in the form of global effects or manager effects). This seems a bit strange to me especially since some of them can be Tacticians or Generals. I've also had trouble figuring out how to get the rebels to attack my Palace while maintaining a strong Military. It's not like Tropico 4 wherein I can set up an elaborate trap in certain structures or have my own avatar tip the scales of battle in an evenly (numerically) matched battle.As of now I am 60-40 on this game. It still requires a lot of polish but at the same time, I did enjoy it enough to play it to near-completion. If there was a neutral button then I'd select it. For now, I'll wait for that polish to be applied.

content:
, 2014
												Tropico 5 probably introduces the most new gameplay mechanics out of the franchise. It certainly is not just like 4 (which in turn was just like 3). The idea of advancing with a tech tree (of sorts) is an interesting change while a consistantly changing global environment can often catch you by suprise if you get complacent. Unlike previous Tropico games, putting all your eggs in one basket will be your undoing. I have also noticed that while in older instalments I could win ellections with ease, each election can often leave me with a nail biting victory (or twice so far defeat). So I would recommend reducing the difficulty when you first play as Tropicans in 5 will rebel almost 3 times as often as those in tropico 4 with the modifier Rebel yell on.This Game still still retains the political satire and puns of the previous Instalments and on the odd occasion has made me laugh. It does how ever have a few flaws such as; a lack of customisation for EL presedente and his Dynasty (i feel like tropico 4 had more customisation options), the more clunky almanac (i much prefer the tropico 4 almanac) and the fact that you are only warned about a faction not being satisfied when they protest (often leaving you with little time to rectify the problem before some become rebels or you lose an election).

content:
r 5, 2016
												Being a huge fan of the Tropico series, I was itching to get Tropico 5.  When  it came on sale, I pounced on the chance to get it.What to make of this release of the game....There is a large improvement graphics wise, with the islands and the buildings looking really good.  What is sad is that a lot of the building animations was somehow "cut" from the game. In Tropico 4 if you upgrade any of the buildings with skylights or aircons you could see the building changing with these add-ons.  Animations in the pubs and restaurants was also much better in T4, you could see people entering the building and sitting at the tables.  Largely there are no such small detailed animations on buildings in T5.There is really a lot to do in the game.  I like the improved economics system, where you can set up trade routes with better pricing for some of your resources and goods.  There is also now a constitution where you can set the type of community that you build.  This is also one of the things that you cannot really see the changes easily, eg. One of the viewable difference is when you select professional military.  Doing that I had all my soldiers abandon their posts in exchange for soldiers with High School training.The introduction of a timeperiod type of system is nice, but it can at times be a pain especially early in the game.  Especially when you have to please the king with a lot of stuff just so that your reign could be extended for another couple of months.  As soon as you get past this era your are back to elections and keeping your people happy.  Some of the buildings also change according to the timeperiod eg. The docks change the crane and the type of ships that dock.Another annoying feature in the game is the building/people cards.  In Tropico 4, you could see all the information of the building on the card, even the people visiting the buidling.  The people cards had detailed info on what they needed as well as the tourist cards.  This information is lacking in Tropico 5, sadly...  The campaign part of the game is a 50/50 parcel.  You only play over 2 islands during the campaign.  Each of the missions build on the previous one.  So if you build up a good economy on your island in the previous mission you will carry over that advantage for the next mission in the campaign.  BUT....  You only get to play that island for one mission!!  Beware if you do not spend enough time in building a good economy on both of your islands!!!  You then have to select the poor island for a troublesome mission and it will see you failing that mission over and over.  I ran into that problem to the point of rage quiting in the end.  Having given the multiplayer a try, I can hardly say anything about it.  Still trying to get a game to play with someone else, where the game does not quit because of different versions of the game.  Will have to try it again at some point.So what is the verdict??   This is a nice looking game, with some nice changes, but I think Kalypso where not quit sure if their were trying to follow the Anno type games or trying to create a different Tropico.  For me Tropico 4 is a way better island gaming experience than Tropico 5.  So if you have never played any of the Tropico franchise and you get this in the bargain bin, give it a try.  If you love the Tropico series, rather stay with Tropico 4.Special note to the dev's:  I would love to see a new Tropico Pirates Cove, please!!!  Had endless fun with that one!!

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
19, 2014
												I have logged about 20 hours of gameplay so far and upgraded my rating from 3 to 4 stars. I got this on steam so I was able to download it on May 23. This is very different from the previous Tropicos. The difference between tropic 3 and tropic 4 was a few more buildings, but overall was the same game. Tropico 5 looks and feels completely different. You will find this game much harder and challenging on campaign mode but now has difficulty settings. There are many new building and upgrades as well. Multiplayer is still not up but I will update this review when this mode is working as it seems like it will be fun. I have played many hours of tropico 3 and tropico 4 so I am very familiar with the series. They released patch 1.02 on June 9th, which fixed numerous issues with both multiplayer and single player.Pros-Graphics are updated and is much smoother than previous tropicos.-The trading system has been overhauled and you now have a guaranteed trade ship every six months. You now also have an additional ship that you can use to trade a certain commodity at above default rate of the computer generated trade ship. Also the ships will change every so many years and look like a ship of that time period.-You no longer have to build a separate tourist dock. All tourist ships use the same dock as what is given to you at the start of the game.-You can now hire a manager for each building. Each manager with have certain bonuses they bring such as better efficiency or better job quality.-Each place where tropicans work will display what income level they will be at. For example a dock worker or a farmer will be a poor tropican, but you can increase their pay to make them well-off. The housing will tell you how it corresponds to their income level. A tenement will suit a poor worker but a house requires their income to be well-off. This also applies to the restaurants and pubs, which serve the poor tropicans whereas opera houses and casinos appeal more to the rich tropicans/tourists. This is much more detailed than previous tropicos.-There is now a constitution that will have selections such as for the labor market-all citizens 16 and older must work, child labor, or work if you want; each with its own pros and cons.-Many new buildings including cotton and cocoa plantations. You can now build a textile mill and use the cotton you grow to make tshirts. You can now mine uranium and coal and either sell it or use it for power plants. There is now a library which is used to research buildings and upgrades per era.-The construction priorities feel like they work much better than previous tropicos.-The dock now shows exactly what you are exporting and the money you will generate with each item. For example: Corn-$3000-You can now have a population well over the 650 person cap in the previous tropicos. (I currently have a population of 800 on one island and it is not even that built up, there is even one mission where I have to have over 900 people.) The low population cap in tropic 3 and 4 really limited how much you could expand and grow your island because you would not have enough workers to fill positions for every building later in the game, especially when you threw tourists in the mix.-Plantations now have plots of dedicated land that crops will be planted on. This is much better than previous tropicos where farmers would just plant crops in random places around the farm.-I like that in the campaign, as you move to the next mission, you continue on the same island with everything you already built and expand upon it.Cons-The overlays no longer include a map of minerals, instead you have to explore the undiscovered portions of the island to find mines. You now have to pay an expedition $1000 to explore differnt parts of the island and can get expensive. Also mines are only located by hills or cliffs now. You start out only seeing about 1/10 of the island and the rest is fog. I find it kind of annoying that as you build you city and reach the edge of what you can see of the island, the fog doesn't clear. You still have to send an expedition, even its across a busy street.-You can no longer build factories until you hit a certain era.-When trying to place a farm, the crop condition map is not as easy to read as it the square tiles are now outlined in a green, yellow, or red border, not a full green or red square. I personally found it harder to distiguish the yellow and green conditions of the map.-In the campaign you only have a certain number of years to rule, known as mandates, and if you cant complete the level in time you lose. More challenging though.-You have to wait to get most of the upgrades for factories till certain eras.-You cant set wages for all farms or mines anymore (Fixed in patch 1.02). You can only set the sames wages for specific farms or mines such as all gold mines or all corn farms.-The game will pause and go to a loading screen when it autosaves for about 5 seconds. This is just kind of annoying when playing, I hope they can patch this issue.Overall, this game is more fun and challenging than tropico 3 or 4 in my opinion. I bet with a few updates some of the cons I listed will make this game much more fun and enjoyable. I was use to just building up my island at my leisure and building up money to purchase better buildings but tropico 5 is not like that anymore. This version requires patience and a see what this does approach in the campaign. I really like that aspect as it has created a much higher replay value. And this is like most game downloads from amazon, it will be on steam. This has been the case for many years now so don't be shocked. (And it says DRM-steam). I will update after more gameplay.

content:
, 2014
												Maybe it's because I was spoiled by its predecessor (which you can't help but compare it to), but I found Tropico 5 very disappointing. The first thing you notice - right off the bat - is it lacks the charm and personality of the Tropico series. While Penultimo returns as hilarious as ever, all your old friends like Reverend Esteban, El Diablo and the Mighty Chinese Dragon (who's hungry for your goods) are conspicuously absent. As such, factions and foreign powers feel like numbers on a page instead of personalities.The campaign is way too short with way too little variety. You can grind through it (fairly effortlessly) in a few days, during which you'll get to play on four islands. That's right. FOUR islands. Two of which are basically the same. As for the running of Tropico, in pandering to the needs of the crown, the people and the powers that be, you get the feeling of being a thankless civil servant rather than being a power-mad dictator in love with his own reflection, as was the case in Tropico 4.While the implementation of Dynasties was a great idea - in theory - it was lacking in execution. Instead of three traits, now you only get one per Dynasty member. And a grand total of about four or five costumes. Thinking about sending el Presidente to a construction site to speed things up, or a building to boost service? Think again, as the option to do so is gone.On the positive side, it *looks* nice. But as it's a Tropico game (and not a super-realistic bro-shooter), it doesn't really need to. If anything, the mandatory DX11 requirements have screwed a lot of people out of playing it in the first place. I'll have to double check, but I could swear the background music (with a couple of exceptions) is the same re-heated soundtrack from Tropico 4. Come on, folks. There's a wealth of Calypso/Carribean/Latin music to choose from. Get a LITTLE creative!In summary, I REALLY wanted to like this game. I really did. Tropico 4 is still one of my favourite games of all time. It's sad to see what could have been an amazing game not fully realised and ideas not fully explored. Until such time as there's adequate DLC (I have no doubt they'll churn it out piece by piece in $5 increments) to give it a little variety and scope, I can't really recommend it. Go play Tropico 4. It's still a damn good game if you want to indulge your inner megalomaniac.P.S. As if it weren't bad enough you can't build a giant golden statue of yourself any more, you can't build ANY statues. How the hell are you supposed to feel like a tyrant if you can't remake Tropico in your likeness?

content:
r 27, 2016
												This game is immersive and exciting from the moment you start. Every detail is thought through, and the game manages to keep you on your toes and interested as it progresses through such a long time period. You start in the Colonial Era, which gives you the building blocks on which your city will later stand. You then progress to the WW Era, where you are confronted with a new task of keeping up relations with the Allies and the Axis, or to avoid diplomacy and go down the route of a dictatorship! The next is perhaps the biggest transition, from the WW Era to the Cold War. You are, again, confronted with the two powers of USA and USSR. You experience new cultures such as tourism, industrialism and many more new features. You then move on to Modern Times, where you are put in the 'sandbox' mode and are left to enjoy the rest of the game!Another great thing are the characters! You get Penultimo and Lord Oaksworth mostly, whos speeches are always a welcome surprise. They give you quests and tips, and notify you when anything happens. There are many more as you progress, each with their own distinct voice and interesting script.I give this game 9/10!

That's all lost in T5.Another thing: the colonial era has no date, only stressful mandate. The selection of buildings is very poor. Then in the WW ear, the game suggests you to advance into the cold war in the early 30s, which has no historical accuracy. Not to mention the following eras. Basically, the game should just start in 1850 and continue from then on.Kalypso promised a lot of things, which I could not find. Also, the dynasty system is boring, to say the least. I was expecting that I could marry and start a real family, instead of these random and usless additions to my "family".The research of new technologies is annoying and extremely long.I could continue this list, but I', going to play Tropico 4 now. Would advise the same to all of you. Save the money for something else.

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												In it's current release state, I'm hard pressed to recommend this to anyone in regards to fans of the series or as a general interest to city and econ simulation et al. Without delving into past Tropicos too much, these title pretty much abolished everything decent that was good about the past games and while I wanted to strive to figure out the best way to win and be efficient in Tropico 3 and 4, I find myself logging off in frustration a lot with the fifth installment.Don't get me wrong, there is a lot of good and a ton of potential for future DLC's (hate to think that maybe this was a focal point, but it's quickly becoming industry standard). Unfortunately, the bad and the outright annoying is so prevalent that the whole experience gets ruined pretty quickly.Rebels often seem to rebel without any reason. Protests are totally arbitrary and "negotiating" with protestors oftentimes has you build or create something to contend with one of the few problems you're probably not having. Construction costs are astronomical. Power plants are very confusing and either buildings need a ton of electricity to run and maintain optimum efficiency, or the power plant itself is severly inefficient given the amount of cost to build and maintain them.Healthcare, schools, and entertainment are a beast of their own. While a single newspaper or television seems more than enough to land me at sufficient levels for happiness, I'm finding that multiple buildings that should have the same effect as a liberty increasing building in a different capacity don't actually do anything, or the difference is so minute that I couldn't even tell.These things all strike me as bugs, but with the lack of feedback from the developer it's hard to maintain that allusion forever. Essentially, I'm trying to save you money. Even if you're dying to play this, or something has piqued your interest, just wait it out. Eventually I think most of the issues will be fleshed out, but, for all intents and purposes, buying this is equivalent to something that only works some of the time.

content:
, 2014
												On it's own, Tropico 5 may be a B/C rated game. It has all the basics needed, building up a tropical island and a single bizzare campaign. But it's really impossible to play this without comparing it to its immediate, and fare more affordable, predecessor. Tropico 5 adds multiplayer, does improve some design and planning apsects, but strips out much of the micromanagement, a large number of building, avatar customization, a tremendous amount of detail, and nearly all the wit.  For example, instead of the corrupt political humor oozing out of the previous Tropico games, we get an endless stream of toilet humor and bad sexual innuendo with the most annoying 'host' that Kalypso could apparently find.The list of things missing is staggering, and it's very clear that this game was designed for a long run of DLCs just to get us back to what Tropico 4 had to begin with. The game feels, and is, a massive step backward for the franchise. Multiplayer may be a saving grace, but empire builders don't tend to like multiplayer all that much to begin with, so...In all honesty, I do regret spending any money on this game, and it's the first time I felt that way about Tropico. Excuse me as I go back to the much superior Tropico 4.

content:
er 24, 2014
												I love the Tropico series *very* much, but I just can't get excited for this one. It feels much more like a run of the mill city builder game, they changed a lot of the voice actors for the main characters, they brought back the annoying radio host idea, and a whole smattering of other poor design choices. The jokes fall flat for the most part, and a lot of control has been taken from the player, and a lot of the smaller details that used to make the series great are missing. Where that's been removed, however, needless complexity has been added. Now you need a library to research technology- yep, a tech tree. Military affairs are much more integral and like many, many other terrible city sim games, it too is bland.  You are supposed to appoint managers to your buildings- but why should I waste my time flipping through all the potential managers to try to find the one that actually fits, only to get a 10 point effectiveness boost?  And if you have a plantation colony, say, you always end up with a bunch of managers for things like tourism or landscaping or speed-cubing or whatever else. I played for a few hours and lost interest. Your island is consistent across missions, which is cool, but you'd best hope your crystal ball is accurate. One mission starts with you being invaded, so I certainly hope you thought to build multiple forts and towers. Overall, it just feels like a shadow of the 4th game in the series. The 4th game, with the modern times expansion, offers a much more entertaining, satisfying game, and you can probably grab it for a small fraction of the price.

content:
31, 2014
												Short Version: Tropico is a great game. I fully recommend it. Long Version: I joined the series with Tropico 4, which is very similar to this fifth installment, but much easier, so if you have the money, paying for the most modern, challenging one is your best bet. The game is simple in paper: Become Royal Governor of a British Colony, declare independence, and build your small nation throughout history. The 4 eras (Colonial, World Wars, Cold War, and Modern) will force you to change your play style all the time, and the new constitution allows you to replay as a different kind of Presidente (Pro Tip: Try being democratic. You won't get to publicly execute journalists or pesky protestors for "violations of human rights" (whatever that means...), but it will make it more challenging). Also, live each era to its fullest, so you can plan ahead. Your nation might be bustling with trade with your preffered superpower in the Cold War, but once the Soviets fall, you better adapt your commercial strategy quickly, or else you'll go back to being a third world hell-hole faster that you can say "WHY DON'T YOU BUY MY CRAP ANYMORE?". Hell, maybe I am just bad at strategy games (I am not. Dare you to a round of Civ V if you don't believe me), but the game is challenging for me on easy, as your need to change strategies will ♥♥♥♥ you up bad unless you plannes ahead for 5 years or so (5 year plan? Get it? 'Cause communist dictatorship is an option?). People are much harder to please, especially because the Constitution may divide them (the religious might favor you for all the churches you gave them, but half may hate you for not being a theocracy). The era specific random events ("The Soviets have asked us to stash some humanitarian aid that 'has been nowhere near Cuba'" (later) "GOOD GOD! THEY WERE NUKES! WHAT DO WE DO? A) Keep them B) GIve them to the USA C) Hide them, return them to the USSR when possible." This allows you to ideologically ally with one, while maintaining peace with the other superpower), various play styles (Constitution options) and development plans (Will Tropico be an industrial nation? A farming paradise (Thank Presidente for the 'buy organic craze!')? A vacational hotspot?) will give you countless replay options and entertainment.P.S. The Nazis invaded once, and our armies destroyed each other. One Panzer with a smoking engine survived. It killed me. 100/10

Another thing is after playing multiplayer for a bit, the game seems to lag for me. Not as in the jerky lag but a lag were if I ordered my soldiers to attack lets say the Green faction, I dont see my men deploy for awhile but on their side they see the attack. Infact, this even prohibits me building even further as I wont see any change on my screen until possibly a full five minutes have passed by even though I can still scroll around the map. Also there is one major feature I miss and thats the Tropico First option on immigration. My reason being is even if you have the safe haven option, you still can get a ship with 20 new immigrants. However another issue I have encountered is the logic of some civilians. For example if they are married and both earn a poor wage (using my tropico 4 logic) I would assume their accumulated income would make them a "well off" family thus permitting them to live in a well off house. Boy was I wrong...They only live in a poor house thus promting me to have to lower the budget for housing thus making me loose money from not getting good rent profits. The biggest complaint I have though probably is how quickly you can get over populated. For example if you start off in the colonial era with 50 people, if taking your time you can easily get 200 people, and then possibly 400 by the time you entered the World Wars era. The most I have had was 790 people living on my Island and that was just by the Cold War era. With this its easy to loose track of how many houses you need to build, entertainment, healthcare, and hell sometimes your forced to build a entirely new city on the Island just because you've ran out of room in your first original city. With another concern on multiplayer is the lack of the ability to support another player when attack by pirates or even the Crown. With this the only way you can support them is attacking the player who's attacking them. Also to add in further is the common understanding of "If you place a parkinglot/garage here. Everyone who is traveling will go to that and take a car" however in this game, if you place a parking lot right where everyone lives, only a few will think "Hey...I gotta travel right into the center of the Island for my job. I think I ought to take a car..." instead of the norm of spending five months to get to the farm they work at, then spend another five months walking back home. By the time you get the metro tunnels, people dont consider that if there's a metro tunnel RIGHT next to their house and there's a metro tunnel RIGHT where they need to work, that they should use it. It is the most frustrating thing when you see that your money is getting wasted on transportation because people simply refuse to drive or even take the metro! Overall the game is great but once you start seeing how these people work at times it can get tiresome. A great example is you can have a good five empty houses for the poor and have enough poor people to house them but refuse to abandon their shacks.

er 21, 2015
												I say "yes" because there is no "maybe" button. I'd recommend this as a great entry point to the series for new players, and veterans of the series may very well enjoy it too. For one thing, building farms is much easier due to them being zoned out and planned instead of farmers just throwing fields down willy-nilly after construction is done.But I personally, coming from Tropico 4, don't enjoy some design decisions made with this game. For one thing, having to explore the island is tedious to me, and I don't really like the Era system much. I don't like that you can't have your Presidente walk around visiting buildings to improve their production. I also dislike the problem with genders and working. See, the game is based mostly in past points in time, but this game fails to reflect that in jobs. Women can do manual labor, and men can and do work as strippers long before they would have been allowed in those positions by their society.TL;DR I don't like some choices the devs made, but it's still a well-made game.

content:
0, 2015
												Tropico is a series of city builders lite where you are also a dictator (a pirate lord in 2) who has to stay in power while trying to build his little heaven (or hell) on Earth.And whereas Tropico 4 was just a Tropico 3 with more stuff - Tropico 5 has many features changed, reworked, added (and some cut) to warrant being called a proper sequel. Oh and it also has MUCH more stuff to do.With changes in economy and many product chains and raw resources added compared to the previous game - it may take a few failures to wrap your head around the way things work.Your tropical dictator paradise can now also have sharper teeth with more offensive stuff to beat down rebels and invaders with (although with changes in faction system the rebellions happen a lot more often for my taste).All other categories of things to build and create are expanded as well, coming with a lot more comfortable interface.As usual Sandbox mode is where the real game's at. And now it doesn't have time limits, albeit the generator is unfortunately simplified.Instead the time frame takes you through four eras starting with colonial one where you are just a mere local manager of the king - you have to use crown's cash to kickstart your playground which you also have to make independent before your term's over. Don't worry it can be extended by doing missions (later on they give you much more varied rewards).Of course if you don't want to bother with the colonial era (with it being quite different from the rest of the game, but I personally like it) - you can pick any other era to begin your game in.I recommend it both to newcomers and previous Tropico players alike.

content:
, 2014
Tropico 5 is not quite as good of a Tropico game as it's predecessors, however, it is a better city-builder. Tropico still maintains much of it's comedy and charm but, unfortunately, something feels like it is missing since Tropico 4.The new interface leaves much to be desired as much of the information that El Presidente's are used to is now either buried or missing. Want to know which buildings are profitable and full? Too bad. Want to know where the oil is? Use a magnifying glass! The lack of a Tropico 4 style interface leaves much to be desired and makes it difficult to get the information you need.It also seems that with the addition of the new interface we've also lost the fun faction interaction that we've come to expect. They do still exist but they've essentially taken a back seat to everything and are much harder to find with much fewer missions.The addition of the new dynasty system is pretty cool. Your new family members offer you some nice bonuses, more benefits, and you can use them as new 'managers' which help you run buildings better. You can even send them on fun little missions and storyline quests for more bonuses. However, with the addition of these new folks you also lose direct control of El Presidente himself. You can no longer tell him where to go, who to visit, and what store to promote. I used to LOVE that feature from Tropico 4 and it helped pass the time and improve production. Now all El Presidente does is wonder around like an NPC. Furthermore, you also have a lot less options in character creation when it comes to El Presidente and can no longer pick from a vast number of backgrounds, histories, bonuses, and penalties; now you pick ONE bonus and that's it.As I said, Tropico 5 is likely the best city builder of the series. The addition of the new grid or city layout system makes placing and organizing structures MUCH easier. Due to the new era system you also have building that grow and change as time passes. Farms, for example, get nice upgrades and then can be transformed into Hydroponic Farms which are much smaller and more efficient.Overall, I have been enjoying Tropico as a good city builder but I often miss the micromanagement, humor, and the style of Tropico 4. Everyone expects at least a dozen DLCs (ten confirmed so far) and I hope that future patches improve Tropico 5 back up to Tropico 4's level.

												Tropico 5~~~~~~~This series is getting better with each sequel. Of course you have to build and reach your objectives as usual but in Tropico 5 you have more options than before. Saying this, you can play with the keyboard and mouse but it is not smooth in my opinion.Positives:~~~~~~~-	Visually splendid-	Fantastic soundtracks-	Plenty things to do-	Setup your levels of difficulties (political, economic, etc) before you start each mission-	Challenging-	Achievements-	Trading cardsNegatives:~~~~~~~~-	Gamepad as primary controlOverall this game is a solid 8 out of 10 (just because of the gamepad), Otherwise I would give it a 10 out of 10.Well done El Presidente!MORE THE_CPT_FROGGY REVIEWS HEREFOLLOW THE CPT FROGGY CURATOR PAGE HERE

content:
er 18, 2014
												I was introduced to the Tropico franchise around the time when the newest Sim City came out. Sim City was a massive dud and Calypso Games decided to capitalize with a 75% sale on Tropico 4. When Tropico 5 came around I was ready for more. I enjoyed Tropico 5 immensely. All the annoying little bits of Tropico 4 were wiped away and the new game style was great. Having to plan a city to last the entire franchise mode was fun. I got attached to my cities. I recommend Tropico 5. Then I downloaded 'The Big Cheese' DLC. It was 5 bucks for a silly costume, new building, and extra missions. It was a ripoff  but I was still loving Tropico so much I didn't care. The building was decent. I could never find the costume. The mission was impossible. I mean IMPOSSIBLE. I normally build my cities to use the resources well and keep my people happy. I tried this with the mission and failed to finish it within the time allotted. Begrudgingly I lowered the difficulty down to east and tried again. I failed. I was a little confused at what I was doing wrong. A month later I decided to load it up again and go for it one last time. I screwed over my citizens in the name of milk. I built as many of the creameries as possible and put all my resources into pumping out as much as possible. I failed. I see this as lazy game design. They made a great game and now are trying to just cash in until Tropico 6 comes around. Get the game. Skip the Expansions.

This review only relates to „Tropico 5 - Complete Collection“ With ALL DLCs! I really love the whole Tropico series and heard nothing good about this game when it was published.So I waited, 2 years, dozens of patches and DLCs!And it was the right thing to do!! Now with all the DLC, this game isfeels complete and there is not much to criticize. There are only tiny things which bothered me and could easily be solved via patch or another DLC (please don’t! :-D): - more buildings in the colonial ages would've been great.- more diversity in buildings, especially other varieties of every building for each era !!!- On „hard“ the rebelsand factions are pretty much impossible to please. One oft he faction will always revolt.- More of this great music or an easy way to include the music of Tropico 1 – 4 would’ve been nice.- There is no different or altered music for each era.- In retrospect (without being affected by this myself) this DLC policy of Kalypso has been pretty dickish.- Trees should be placeable outside the grid, so that cities look more realistic and the gaps between curvy roads and buildings, placed inside the grid, can be filled up.The aspects I liked most are: - It’s a true Tropico and not some pared-down imitation to make money (only with all DLCs!).- There are some nice and new innovations like the eras.- I really didn’t miss anything from the predecessors and really don’t think they’ve dumbed it down as much as said by some people.- assignment of keys is possible.- adjustable levels of difficulty.- The real „Tropico feeling“ is still thereAll in all, I really like this game, just like Lulu Marie does:

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2016
												The thing about Tropico 5 is that none of the in your face issues about the game never got patched or addressed in the games tutorials or updates, and that is what makes it hard to recommend it on a level in addressing all of the "advertised" aspects of the game. So I guess I'll just make two sections talking about what is really bad or good about the game.The Good: The single player in Tropico is pretty standard where you follow a campain (which is rare but well appreciated in Tropico) as you develope your own little Cuban esc country while siding with different people for different things.  The voice acting is awesome and funny and you'll really come to appreciate the character and personality that the game brings to the table.  The trading system is very confusing when you get past the beginning stages because just because the boat says its bringing in a certain amount of money doesn't mean you will see the impact in your treasury (just a note).  Also if you are a sucker for graphics this game is fine, landscape is a little empty at first, but once you start filling it up you'll be astounded at the bright colors and tropical atmosphere.  If you really want to get the most out of the game I recommend the Sandbox mode and just set everything to a place where you can go on forever (cause it will take you a long time to fill up your island) and the campain makes you start from scartch as you move from island to island so it's nice to have something concrete to hold onto.  Dlc is also alright if you get it on sale.The Bad:Annnnnnnnnnddddddddddd here comes the kicker.  Character selection and custimization is basically worthless most of the time and it's just pointless trying to upgrade them when you could build or do something that will help you much more in the long run, or just have a bunch of lower level characters on your island to have scartered effect which is also a good alternitive.  Going along with characters the manager assingment process in general is just abysmall as I wish that there was a seperate easier menu to see where your managers are rather then going in and clicking on every single building to see.  Then comes the biggest letdown in this game, which is the learning curve.  I have just over 100 hours and I still haven't even come close to mastering this game, the way that the game wants you to build the city contradicts the idea of a city builder completely, they want everything in close proximity  and one supermarket per block and one church per block but thats such wasted potential on something so meaningless and confusing and limiting to the creativity of building your own city.  Then there is multiplayer which is what I would describe as a one night stand, over and over again, because guess what?  You can't save the freaking multiplayer worlds if you are playing with a friend so you will have to start new every single time you restart that world, which is so god dang stupid and should've been patched the day after this game came out.This leads to the conclusion where I'll recommend it dispite it's flaws because at face level and on sale this is a really fun game to play and really get the atmosphere of, and despite all of it's flaws the developers managed to create a game that has some of the most fun and attractive efforts of any city builder game I have ever played.

content:
, 2014
												I've been playing Tropico games since the third one. I still haven't played the first and second Tropico games though I might pick them up on the next sale just to see how the game has changed over the years. I enjoy Tropico 3 and 4 a lot but Tropico 5 is by far my favorite with all of the changes that have been made to make it more of a enjoyable and challenging game. If you've played Tropico then skip the next paragraph.For those who are unfamiliar with Tropico, you play El Presidente, the dictator of the island of Tropico. You can play the game as a leader of the people, doing everything to please them, or you can bribe, cheat and kill your way through your lifetime (If you choose to have it end). You'll face rebels, foreign powers, protestors, and elections as you play a much more humorious city building simulator. While I enjoyed Tropico 3, when I got the fourth installment I could tell the developers knew how to improve their game and did what people wanted by adding more of well, everything and included the humor that made Tropico 4 even more enjoyable. However one thing remained unchanged, Tropico has a issue named after it. The issue is once you know what to do the game becomes way too easy and the other problems being builds stop being built by the NPCs (Luckily happens later in so you can insta-build everything) and the worst issue being that shipments stop being transported for some reason. These issue have been taken care of in Tropico 5, however in the Modern Era sometimes I run into issues with the Teamsters again.Tropico 5 adds new features like the time era and research to help keep things from getting too easy. It has you create a constitution that will help and hurt you in various ways. Importing and exporting goods go far more indept, allowing you to choose who you buy and sell to for each individual good to get the best prices and help (and hurt) your relations with foreign powers. For example, in the World War Era, if you sell to the Allies it will hurt the Axis' view of you which can lead to less trade with them and if your relation with them is bad enough, an invasion.Old things like your military buildings are far more useful in this game. Before they were only good for when rebels attack. Now they'll help you with foreign invasion (which before ment Game Over) and pirates when they attack you for your gold. You also won't get that one soldier that just turns into Rambo because they end up killing everyone attacking by themselves. They also add a "Manager" system. Most of the building can have a manager and depending on who you pick will give you certain bonuses, like increasing housing quality nearby or increase production.With all of the improvments made, the game has become noticably harder. No more is re-election a definite thing. The player could be making large amounts of spending money but if your people are not pleased, come time for re-election it could mean Game Over. And with no speeches this time to save you (Though might be nice to add something where if you don't keep your promises it'll hurt you in the long run might be good) you may find yourself bribing and exicuting faction leaders more often. I know I did. In Tropico 3 and 4 I never did but here I find myself cheating the votes and taking care of the faction leaders just to end up winning by no more than 30 votes. The game is fair about it though. I've won before having 80% of the votes before, what you do can make or break you here and I love it.There are other things like an online multiplayer which I haven't tried out fully yet but given the way the game plays, it might be kind of like a fast pace version of Anno 2070, but when my roommate and I tried to play together on the same internet connection, I found it laggy.(He was hosting) I could sit here and go indepth with every detail and share my experiences but why sit here reading that when it'll just be there to tell you why you should buy this game when you could get it yourself and give it a go. If you enjoyed the previous Tropico games, like city building sims, or just a casual gamer, this is a purchase you won't regret.

												The newness of new Tropico:- time passes. Different tech in different time periods. To level up the time you have to achieve different stuff. Start in colonial times and move to modern times. - tech up. You have to research the technologies to unlock them. - fog of war. Before a certain technology is unlocked you have to explore your island to be able to use it. - dynasty members. You level up your dude and his family for bonuses- more battles. Military actually matters cause you get attacked for more reasons than riots. - managers in buildings. You can discover and hire managers to improve and specialize buildings- building upgrades. There are a ton of ways to customize and level up almost every building.- more complicated trading. Lots of trade ships and trade routes so you can play an import export game if you want or smuggle or whatevs. Also political rating affects what trade routes you have available. - fun campaign. It involves time travel and stuff. - multiplayer mode. Which I have not tried yet but would like to...

content:
9, 2014
												Tropico 5 contains some substantial improvements over the previous two in the series (because face it, Tropico 4 was really just Tropico 3 with a few bells and whistles added.) Most notably, Tropicans do not have to be physically present in a building for the building to be active-- meaning that the year and a half of downtime while Tropicans wandered over to the Cigar factory to actually earn their pay is now gone. This results in a much smoother economic development.The second big change is that the campaign is not just a story woven through some otherwise disconnected scenario maps. When you finish a scenario in the campaign, your island is saved so that when you return to it*, all your buildings and Tropicans are in the same place.The third item of note is that within the campaign, the progression of time is usually not measured as the passage of months within a year (ex. Nov. 1959) but is instead a countdown to an event related to the scenario (ex. 48 months left before mandate expires) which you can usually extend in several different ways while playing.

												I am thoroughly enjoying this game.  I have  played all of the previous versions of tropico and this one is obviously a new generation separate from the older titles. It is more difficult, and it does not run on older machines. However, I am on mission number 4 of the single player campaign and have been having a really good time playing.  I recommend it to any strategy game fans out there. I like that your old builds remain in place- it makes long term planning more important.  I have also found that the military is something you need to pay much more attention to-- which is fine in my book. After all, why play a banana republic dictator if you  don't have to rely on soldiers to keep you in power?  I heartily recommend it to all fans of sims or  strategy games. The graphics and sound are top notch. Of course they will expect you to  pay  for downloadable content in the future, but this is nothing new for those who have prior tropico titles.

er 29, 2014
												Buy Tropico 4, not 5 if you want to have fun owning your own island.There are many small annoyances with this new entry to the series. For instance sometimes it feels like I'd rather pull my fingernails off than try getting roads placed where I want in this game. Same goes for buildings, especially on shore regions. What makes this task even more frustrating is the new "fog of not knowing your own island" which can be painstakingly cleared by sending your palace troops to "explore" said areas. Only that the troops are idiots that don't reveal important areas (mines, oil) but rather walk right past them. Have fun sending them again and again (1000 credits every time) to reveal even the smallest of areas. These guys are like Vickers in Prometheus, capable running only straight ahead - except when they can use roads to go around and reveal even less of fogged area than using straight path to marker.The "combat" in this game... whoo boy. Not good. not good at all since you can't control the troops at all and the outcome is based on placement of your building in relation to path taken by attacking forces. What fun.A new console-player friendly task system within campaign missions is like you're playing a tutorial all the time. Do this and do just to get some reward. What happened to being supreme leader? In this game you're just an errand boy.Campaign missions end on victory condition, just to kick you to another island for one mission and then back to the first one. Around we go. Not the smoothest experience and feels like a continuation of tutorial feeling described above.Execution is poor and overall Tropico 4 is so much better than this its not even funny.

content:
8, 2014
												So, Tropico 5. We meet at last. Do you know why you were brought here, Tropico #5? Because El Presidente believes with the right sort of, let's say, motivation, you could become so much more useful as a citizen of our great virtual island. But as it is right now? I don't know, Tropico 5. I don't know. Considering the work of the four previous Tropicos who have come through town, who have very rarely made any significant changes to the status quo, which I have to admit, around here we can appreciate that sort of slow gradual change considering how everything has been working just fine, you decided you wanted to make a few more, shall we say, radical changes. This has El Presidente very concerned. Let's go over the dossier, shall we?Let's start with what you've been doing around town that's got so many fellow citizens vocally supporting you. One of the biggest changes you've made is to the infrastructure. It's nice to see that you've scaled down the size of the parking garages to something manageable, and look, in the Modern area you've introduced the Metro to our tiny island! Letting citizens get from one point of the island to the other nearly instantaneously is quite the feet. Something that El Presidente truly appreciates when he wants to get out to the llama farms for some quiet and relaxation without having to drive through all of that horrible traffic. Which is another issue we see significantly less of. It is good to see more people walking instead of filling the streets with cars! I applaud you, Tropico 5, for finally resolving that issue. That reminds me, the whole Era thing. It is, if of a somewhat debatable quality, nice to have Eras from which to transition. Going from the Colonial Era to the World War Era is probably the largest change of the four. The other two are the Cold War and the Modern Era. Having the ability to upgrade certain residential units to other certain residential units is nice as the era transitions, and new constructions become available.Having Edicts become available as the Era progresses is another thing to look forward to, until finally you have access to all of them. And the Constitution! Who would have expected something like that to be introduced into our tiny island? The discovery of science, which is used to enhance the Constitution and advance the Eras, was nice as we can finally figure out that whole sliced bread thing.The price of docks is considerable cheaper than they were previously, which allows El Presidente to build many, many docks to help speed up the export of his new delicious cheese. And speaking of money, it's nice to finally be able to have a use for El Presidente's, shall we say 'private' income. Being able to use the Swiss Bank account balance level up El Presidente and his family members abilities is quite good at encouraging you to play multiple maps with the same family so you realize their full power! Oh yes, and El Presidente would like me to pass along his thanks in allowing multiple members of the family to share power on our island.For the workforce, being able to hire managers with minor Presidente-like powers to manage buildings is a nice touch indeed. The people of our island enjoy being empowered in such a way that makes them more useful to El Presidente.But now onto some concerning trends that I am seeing here. The buildings snap to a rather large grid system that while nice when fitting buildings together sometimes, is terrible unimaginative and can leave a lot of extra space between buildings where they meet at odd angles. It doesn't help any that you have taken away El Presidente's favorite toys. No longer can we build statues to honor El Presidente's might. No, now parks and decorations only come in two units, small and large. The small is one grid or two, while the large fluctuates slightly more, starting at a 4x4, and going to such sizes as 4x6, to the mighty 5x5 and 5x6. But what happened to the gardeners, Tropico 5? Did you murder them in the study with a lead pipe? Because we can no longer plant individual trees, or benches, or any of the small single items. This is a great disappointment to El Presidente, for he had quite the green-thumb.Housing has now turned into something of a mess, since, as we said, Tropicans walk far more than they did last time. Now if a Tropican can not find a house near where they live, they will opt to just build a shack near their work-site, even if there is ample housing on the island. I have been told by many who do this, Tropico #5, that they were encouraged to ignore El Presidente's benevolence and build these eyesores around the city by you.And another thing. Why have you taken away the ability of El Presidente to personally manage the wages of our citizens? Not only that, but he can no longer set prices for buildings or services. Everything has instead been rolled up into one "budget" function. Tropico 5, I'm concerned about this power grab. These are function that should be left up to El Presidente himself to manage, not some overly simplified "budget bar" that controls everything. This has actually made it HARDER to manage the economy, since if we want to pay people less, we now have to also decrease the efficiency of a building by lowering the budget. This is a big problem, and I suspect it may be sabotage!I was also shocked to discover that we need to discover our own island now! When we start administering our great government in the Colonial Era, our island is shrouded in mist, and must be explored by our soldiers during "expeditions" that cost a thousand dollars an event! And you can't even control them, you just click on a way point and hope they go the right route in getting there to discover it. Though the discovery of the Compass does negate this, it is none-the-less irksome.And speaking of discovery, why are our people no longer able to improve their skills concerning their profession? Why have you taken this source of pride from our people, Tropico #5? The people are also kept more out of sight as well, as no longer is El Presidente able to see them when they utilize a building. Gone are the queues that show up when you click on a service building. Instead, they are reduced to mere numbers.Having to mine minerals out of very specific "mines" instead of just having to dig it out of the ground did not actually turn out to be helpful. These "mines" take up permanent space on the map, even after they are used up and collapse. Which is another issue! When a resource node, with the exception of the fishing wharf, is used up, it is automatically destroyed, regardless of whether or not the output storage is full! This destruction of El Presidente's property at the hands of no other than you, Tropico 5, is a great crime! It is most irritating and wasteful. If a facility no longer has resources to mine, El Presidente will choose when and how it is removed, not you!And with the Edicts, while we do have some nice new interesting ones, I see the Pope is no longer able to visit our island, Tropic 5. That is a little disappointing.Elections are now quite a bit more boring. Why do you not allow El Presidente to do speeches anymore, Tropico #5? In fact, why is it that El Presidente, and the family, are not able to directly control their actions on the map? Gone are the day when El Presidente could walk up to a construction site and encourage the workers to construct faster, or walk into a service building an inspire greater service. This is very disappointing that you have talked otherwise upright citizens into ignoring El Presidente in such a way.In the end, I find my appreciation for you mixed, Tropico 5. I can stay with Tropico 4 and not really miss much, I think, but I do still enjoy your presence, even if I think you're a half step back in progress.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 5, 2014
												This game makes for a great city builder with a comic twist. Previous Tropico titles were also very fun and time-consuming, but with the new edicts, tweaked economy and the added eras, this game has evolved quite well. Though it takes a while even for the somewhat experienced Tropico player to get into it, it's well worth it.The colonial era is an enjoyable starting position where you focus on raw materials before becoming an industrial powerhouse. Previous titles always made you start with minimun buildings in 1950, but this gives your island nation a colonial tradition as well. New military buildings and modes allow you to repel rebel attacks and fight off foreign invasions. Multiplayer is fun! Co-op or fight your friends is great, but as both cities reach around a 1,000 population, connection issues are immenent. This still needs fixing, but overall, multiplayer is pretty great!So far, I have played several sandbox games with varying settings and one multiplayer game with a friend. I have listed several pro's and cons below:Pro's:Colonial Start - Great feel and well suited to the game. Every island in the caribbean has an extensive colonial history. Glad Tropico is now one of them :) You can already experience 15k + profits with every freighter which will allow easy and fast industrialization in the next era.Resource and Manufacture Diversity - New minerals and raw resources, more factory goods and more production cycles, with the opportunity to elaborate and initiate new production cycles: Coal to Oil, Oil to Pharmeceuticals; Cocoa, sugar and milk to chocolate milk, etc.Trading System - Profit from extra trading deals for your resources and manufacture. A big plus as this can sometimes lead to incredible boosts to economy. Though these offers appear and disappear over time, it's worth checking your trade tab every few months.Elaborate Tourism - A diversity in the amount of tourists reflects in the many hotels that one can build. Different buildings add to appeal for different types of tourists. You'll decide to place buildings in particular places that will increase effectiveness of buildings: Haciendas and historical inns near colonial buildings; economy hotels and cabana villages near your entertainment hotspots; country hotels and cabins in the middle of nowhere, etc.Cons:Limited Ruling Options - In previous titles you could choose several ways to rule. Background info for your character could make a great difference. I feel with the constitution options this has actually been limited if you want to make most out of your island. When encountering different constitution choices, there three options, but it two are opposites of each other and the third a more-or-less neutral stance on the subject. I personally feel this limits options.Traffic - With more teamsters in each era, traffic becomes a total nightmare in Modern Times. Any junction, even three way junctions, already halts most traffic. Even if you have more than enough teamsters, goods sometimes don't reach buildings for some time, even if your road layout is quite good. Hopefully they will add future options to add rotundas, yielding signs, trafficlights etc to aid traffic flow.Music - All music has become instrumental. Whilst that is not per sé a bad thing, I do feel Tropico loses it's Hispanic touch in that sense. Tropico 3 and 4 both had excellent OSTs, whilst I feel that Tropico 5's soundtrack is a bit more repetitive and just not quite as fun. Best soundtrack is still Tropico 3. Venga bailar! xDOverall:A great game if you like the series or city builders. The game needs some more elaboration, but I'm confident new DLC will be available soon enough. For now, Tropico 5 offers enough to ease the gaming experience. Va a su proximo aventura, presidente!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
1, 2014
												First, a brief history lesson. I was an avid player of Tropico 3, and snatched Tropico 4 up on the first day. I was underwhelmed, as the game seemed more to be Tropico 3.75 than a new game in its own right; for example, all of the UI and art elements were exactly the same. However, over the next several years, patches and DLC helped make Tropico 4 a truly outstanding game, far surpassing its predecessor.Now we're met with Tropico 5, and history seems to be repeating itself. Tropico 5 has a rock-solid foundation. The mechanics and the underlying systems have been streamlined and now make a lot more sense. Building variety has been diminished, but gone are a lot of buildings that you only ever used once (and that was just to find out what it did). What's left has a time and a place, and the only time you won't use a building is if it doesn't suit your playstyle (as opposed to, say, satellite dishes from Tropico 4, which had very little extra-campaign utility). I've yet to experience a crash. The new systems function well. I especially like the introduction of eras. The dynasty system works, I think. I'm not sure. I seem to get all of the bonuses all of the time, regardless of who is Presidente.That said, the game needs work. Some categories (entertainment) are far too sparse, unless you want a dozen cabarets on your island. I've experienced one game-breaking bug: I don't win Sandbox missions despite meeting the victory conditions. Hopefully that gets patched soon. Upgrading buildings is tedious, although I'm happy that they streamlined modernizing them. A big letdown is that the trademark Tropico humour largely falls flat this time around. Instead of the caricatures of various tropes (the drunken priest, the inept second-in-command) and the banter on the radio which could be genuinely funny (I still laugh at General Rodriguez's description of the Museum of Modern Art), you get "Brokeback Mountain" references, predictable flat-out stupidity from Penultimo, and...Lulu. One cannot be told what Lulu is, one must experience her awfulness for oneself.All told, it's a solid game that will likely only get better as time goes on. It's worth the price--you can easily get 30-40 hours of gameplay in its current state. It's still one of the best city-builder franchises out there.

The lil people of tropico are  brilliant lol, and winning them over is not easy.. We pay so little for an installation that gives us countless hours of entertainment .So, what did i love and what did i hate?LOVE -  the  new buildings, tanks, new maps and  new challenges.Game runs smoothly  and is visual delight. content:
6, 2015
												Economy building game type thingy. The game looks nice, but as a fan of the genre I do have some gripes with it. First of, it is rather shallow compared to feature packed games like Unknown Horizons or Sim City. Since I'm now used to playing high quality strategy games like that (some for free), I expect commercial titles to go the extra mile.Placing roads is akward at best. Yes, you learn to work around it, but a user interface should work for the player, not against him. During multiplayer you can build roads that stretch far out, but they cannot be demolished leaving you no room to make a single mistake while placing them. That is a tall order considering how akward the road editing is.The game rushes you from era to era and I often struggle to remain in one era because I feel I haven't gotten to use my newly researched technologies enough. This combined with very small map sizes (even huge is rather small compared to other games) makes it a poor choice for the month long builds I'm used to.There is supposedly a way to save/load multiplayer games, but it's not clear to me at this point exactly how. As with seemingly all modern games, it lacks a proper server browser, instead your left with some social network thing for matchmaking and remote hosting. I didn't like it in L4D2 and I don't like it in this game either. Really old games like OpenTTD (which is free) solved load, save and multiplayer features a long time ago. Just do what they did.The game has also crashed a few times, not a segfault, but a hard lock forcing me to get a console up to kill it.

content:
5, 2015
												I did like Tropico 3 and Tropico 4. In fact I loved them!. However, Tropico 5 was, let's say, different. The graphics were good and the humour was there too (if not a bit repetative, a joke is funny once, twice, three times, four times -cringe, again, again and so on). Too little dialogue was included.I'm sorry to say the gameplay just didn't work. What do I mean by that? Well, it was boring by comparison!One of the features that unfortunatly dictate how the game is played, is that each scenario is played on a different island. That in itself is not a problem, but two or three scenarios later you go back to the island that you previously developed and you have to try and remember how and where all the resources are and how you developed the 'supply chain'. It was like going back into somebody elses half-played game and trying to work out what's wrong with it - even though it worked when you left it!!!The menus are at times difficult to work with - important features, that can make or break a game, are sometimes buried deep in a menu that you hardly use or struggle to find (even though you might remember it was somewhere).My next comment is strange, yes I agree. But it is like the rebels and armies are random. Now I know that they are not. But I felt like they were detached from what I was doing even though I do understand the mechanics.I have saved my biggest gripe/problem until last. Groan. The price of the DLC's!!! I paid a lot of money for this game £35. Nobody should have to pay a total of an additional £52 for all the DLc's) making the cost of this game a humongous £87 (about $135 american dollars as I write this). This was a huge problem for me IN THIS GAME. Because I felt that I did not get the gameplay that I should have had from the original package and the content just wasn't there!!!I am not against all DLC's. But these were overpriced and the original game was short of too many features. So I did not buy them. The original base game is on SALE now at £12.24. I believe £14.99 would be fair price, maybe.......... BUT this price should certainly include all the smaller DLC's. Maybe £19.99 with all the DLC's included. So it is still not good value even at 50% off.If it was reduced to these prices tomorrow would I buy them? I'm sorry no, for all resons that I wrote about above. The game does not compare to the fun that Tropico 3 and 4 were and I tired very quickly from it.

content:
y 19, 2015
												Tropico 5 is a very fun game. It is a distinct experience from Tropico 4. It varies with the competiveness of the campaign missions, the overall features and the core mechanics of the game. It is a very solid continuation to the series, but there is plenty of room for improvement.The core mechanics as compared to Tropico 4 are improved completely. The little things that add to the game are great. There is more of a sense of tightness when it comes to the mechanics.The features and campaign missions vary on experience from player to player, however I feel that it is a good improvement from T4, however is somewhat short and less features than T4.Overall, it is a real good game that I am continuously enjoying and is being supported with DLC and updates regularly. 8/10.----UPDATE as of 2nd August, 2015:I finally got back into finishing this game, and I can say from an updated experience, I loved the final three missions I had to finish in the campaign. The cities are fragile on producing income, but when you have the right amount of buildings, it is sustainable and the missions become progressively easier. The hardest mission for me was building the space/nuclear program and that was half into the second campaign.Updated rating for me increases, but is still rounded to 8/10. Campaign took me a solid 30+ hours to complete. Overall playing time is 53 hours as of now so its hard to comment on the length it took me to finish the campaign, but the majority of those 53 hours went to the campaign.----Thanks for reading my review! If you like my reviews and care to read more, feel free to join Antwog's Analysis (Reviews). http://steamcommunity.com/groups/AntwogReviewsIf you have questions comment below or post in Antwog's Analysis (Reviews) general discussion page. If you liked it, give it a rating.

												Been playing Tropico 5 for a week now and I must say, though on the surface this game looks like a step in the right direction the inside of this game is 100 steps back. Pros:-Longer game time from the new dynasty eras. (Colonial, World Wars, Cold War, Modern Times)-New ways to power your government through your new constitution-Add members of your family to your government for extra benefits-Bigger islands that need exploring before you can just build anywhere-Multiplayer (All we ever wanted, right?)Cons:-Lacking in everything everywhere (explained below)-Every model of each building is the exact same unlike Tropico 4 where you could change the way they looked.-No more loyalist (my personal favorit faction in T4. no more hardcore dictatorships favoring your loyal subjects)-No more prisons/labor camps to lock away the people against you-No more decorations for your city (Statues of your self, national flag, you know that fun silly stuff)-Only about 5 outfits to choose from all of them worst than the other (Where is my traditional flag suit?)-The Almac is just a tad harder to navigate in (just considering the amout of clicks it takes to find what im looking for)-You cant choose a back story or how the Presidente rose to power anymore (just one and ONLY one stat)-YOU CANT SAVE YOUR MUTIPLAYER GAMES (Who let this one happen?)  -_-I could really just go on and on about how much I really dont like this game. I am beyond dissapointed, this is almost scam worthy. If you already own Tropico 4 and your thinking of getting 5 please, do yourself a favor and walk away, im begging you. Dont fall for this game and it lies. Terrible just terrible.
