												I am barely ticking down into the no vote on this one. Maybe "Not Yet" is more accurate. I would not recommend paying full price for this game if you have Tropico 4. The additional content is limited and I suspect you will be able to get a good deal in a few months with a bundle of DLC.I loved Tropico 4 and I am quite disappointed in this installment. It is one of the few city builder games being released though, so beggars can't be choosers. I will likely keep logging hours on it so I won't say it's worthless.-Campaign takes you through only two islands - really dislike this because it just seems like one, long and boring mission. Different demands put on you when you strategically set up for a previous mission. This was obviously a purposeful shift to have a "Dynasty" and age with the island but I don't enjoy the campaign much.-There are no other missions but there is a missions box so it must be coming or unlocks when you beat the campaign? I would bet it will be $$$ DLC though.-Tropico 4 had a crappy scenario creator which limited the amount of user-generated content there was (and hindered the replay value) and I was hoping for a better one in 5 but there isn't one at all-There is a random map generator for sandbox which is an improvementOverall the things I wanted to see in this installment aren't there and mechanics I thought worked well have been changed.

14, 2014
												TL;DR, co-op is neither co nor op. I bought the 2 pack looking forward to a co-op city building campaign that my buddy and I oculd play together, maybe this was expecting too much. Load up the game (after stealing an old graphics card of his, because my dumbass cant read the stickies, or the game requirements), start the campaign, no multiplayer/co-op option. Fair enough, maybe we expected too much hoping to play through the campaign together, maybe we can just jointly build a city, and go freeform/sandbox on it. the first time we get into game together (why cant we make private lobbies?) we start across map from each other, with "victory objectives", well wait a second, there was an option for co-op or versus, I must've selected the wrong one, because we are on opposing sides from each other, with no clear way to interact.Restart the game, make sure we are on co-op instead of versus, pick a new island just because. Once we get into the game (not a knock at the loading times, it runs quite smoothly) it's apparent that no part of the "co-operative" gameplay will involve interaction between the two of us, he is on his side of the island, I am on my side, and we still have "team 1 victory points" Ummm, there is only one team. His fright ships come in on their own schedule, mine come in on their own schedule. He accepts certain missions (such as sell us 3000 lbs of coco), I accept certain missions, on the ocassions that those missions DO overlap, our counters each fill up independently!! Add to that the unchanging, bullet-fast gameplay (in which we don't have time to properly read the rewards/punishments, a slower option would be nice, if it could pause when dialog is happening would be friggin wonderful), and the complete lack of notification when one of us gets knocked out of the game.. oh and why do all of their buildings and civilians cursedly die upon their leaders flight? ITS A CO-OP GAME, Why dont you let the remaining/surviving partner take over the buildings?this game has a LONG way to go, I am incredibly disappointed.Avoid until, forever?

content:
, 2015
												I was very, very suprised to see nobody mentioned the xbox 360/one controller compatibility. This is the only strategy game that I have ever played that completely works with a controller. No other tropico game, and from what I understand, no other similiar strategy games has that feature. It has been very useful for me, and I only play it on the controller. I can keep beat this game with every single setting on its hardest in sandbox mode. Getting to the next era (Colonial, World Wars, Cold Wars, Modern) is very difficult. In almost every playthrough I am barely win several elections by just 1-2%. That is with using every desperate measure and trick I know. You can adjust the limit of the population in the game settings. I think it is 5,000 now. I bought all of the DLC when it was on sale. 7 out of 10 of the DLC are useless and I never use. Espionage, and the Sea ones are useful. (Specifically the tidal power plant, Spies, dungeon, the submarine)Pros.-The unique challenges of each era (colonial, world wars, cold wars, modern) basically turn each sandbox game into 4 different mini games. This extends gameplay.-Once the trading logistics is mastered, it is very useful. -The randomized quest force the player to react to different situations each game, ensuring no repititive gameplay.-The ABSOLUTE BEST implementation of a xbox controller for strategy game that I am currently aware of (on pc). -The tropico series in general, is a very unique game that has a pleasent blend of violence and simcity.-Game length is good. 3-4+ hours. Cons-This game requires advanced logistics, but doesn't provide the tools or controls to micro-manage them. For example, I can't control which dock resources that are traded are delivered too. Nor can I control which farm/factory teamsters will go to. I have to basically build teamstears near buildings that are important. -The thing that I hate the most about this game is that it desperately needs districts. I want to be able to set different policies for different parts of the island and it would be cool, if certain districts could be attacked/occupied by rebels. I am thinking like the hunger games.  You have a capital district where all the rich/military people are. Then poor-improverised districts spread out through the island.-I don't like this single building DLC. I would rather have large expansions and higher price points on those.-I don't like buying tropico after tropico. It is redicilous. Just stick with one and release "real" full priced expansion packs  (I am talking like game changing features like districts. I would pay $50-$60 for real expansion packs)

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
er 28, 2014
												I was hesitant to buy this game at first because of the reviews but I went ahead and got it anyway because it was on sale and I love the Tropico franchise. This is now my favorite tropico so far.This game got me just as hooked as the others, and hands down it is the most in-depth and complex tropico so far.They have introduced dynasties so you can have additonal characters and vote other dynasty members in during elections and take advantage of their bonuses. Moving the character around to give boosts to buildings has been eliminated. I see this as a good thing because it just seemed like unecessary micromanagement in the previous game. Instead your character or dynasty members give global boosts to production or whatever else they do (military strength, effectiveness of services, etc.)They have also overhauled trading and added trade routes which can be very profitable if you find good opportunites (Not every trade is profitable and sometimes settling for less lucrative ones is desirable.) They are very easy to manage and not annoying at all. Docks are now more useful to provide more ships for trade routes.The difficulty of the game has gone up, which is a good thing for me because in previous installments I'd get bored when I had loads of cash and almost 100% happiness. In this game I've actually had to use my military AND do the voter fraud thing. I had never had to do that in previous games. You no longer need a secret service building to do certain things, which I thought was pretty annoying.They've introduced a constitution which give you decisions to make that will benefit your country. There is no more immigration building but the benefits provided by one are instead on a constitutional amendment. Edicts are basically the same but some have to be unlocked through research. They've also added research, and it's not just buying blueprints like before. Building libraries and staffing them give research points.Armies and military are very important now and are to be utilized. In previous games I would not bother with militaries until the militant faction complained, in this game it is very handy to have a sizable military, especially when declaring independence in the colonial era.There are now multiple eras in the game. I did not have the modern times expansion from Tropico 4 so I will not compare them directly, but the eras add a whole new interesting layer. In the colonial era you should try to increase revolutionary support to buy independence from the crown and move on to the great war era. This is where the military can also come in handy, to declare independence the crown requests $20,000. If you have a sizable military you can refuse and fight off the crowns troops to save that money. It's not extremely difficult to do and is somewhat challenging but it was a lot of fun for me to do.Farms and mines are also much different. Farms are much more asthetically pleasing and larger. The way building upgrades work has also been changed and is more relevant early game. It's not just a statistical advantage to get late game anymore. A previous reviewer has complained about the way the mine looks, but I think it looks much much better than before. Instead of a random patch of land being dug into, mines are now in preselected locations along mountains. Wages & rents are more simple to manage, no longer do you set individual rents or wages but you set budgets which determine worker prosperity. I do not think I can explain it well, but if you set budgets high, the workers income level becomes either poor, well-off, rich, etc. This determines what kind of house they live in.There is now a "fog of war" type mechanic on the island. In the colonial and great war era you need to explore your island to reveal what resources you have available. You use your military for this.The game runs just as well, if not better, than the previous version of Tropico. I honestly think it runs better than Tropico 4 did on my laptop which is surprising. I also feel comfortable hooking the laptop up to the TV and playing this tropico from my couch with my wireless laptop & keyboard. The GUI had been changed and is much better. I also like that they changed the portraits on the message screens. It's not as exaggerated and cartoony as it was before. I also feel like I can't zoom in on my island as far as I used to. Cons: Only bad things I think is that there is no real additional building sprites. I thought this would be something easy to do. The almanac also has a little less info available but the data that it does show is much more useful and better organized than before.I highly recommend it for anybody who likes the Tropico series. I have been playing since Tropico 2 and this one is my favorite so far. Definitely buy, even at full price.

r 2, 2015
												Tropico 5 changes a lot of systems, yet stays familiar. It simplifies some aspects, yet makes goals harder to accomplish. new installations: Humour. This game turned out to be funnier than I expected! Every single line that your Presidente says is quite ridiculous (like for example "finally Tropico is free from modern medicine!" or "Welcome Tropico police force to its new home! You can strip search me any time dear officers, oh and by the way your forgot your handcuffs at my palace"), every single research message is humorous and even some of the mission statements are. You have less base buildings and their functions have been simplified, however the research track provides many many different extra buildings, that you need to spend time on. dynasty system - you get to choose less perks, however each family member of your can carry perks of their own. You can use your family members on buildings as managers, or you can send them on missions. Is the game worth it? Yes. Most definitely yes. The charm of Tropico has not been lost. It's different in many ways to the previous ones, however still worth playing!

												The only other Tropico game I have tried was the very first one, which was interesting. This game; However, I found thoroughly enjoyable, though I can't quite explain why. It was fun playing a Quasi-dictator who tried running a democratic state, while juggling the many scenario surprises such as, Russian Invasions, Tsunami destruction, Tornado's, Rebel attacks, Riots and having multiple foreign powers crying for my attention. I spent several hours just getting lost going through each faction member, playing with my population by bribing, arresting, or banishing them to see what would happen. The graphics are not bad, and the mods and add-on content such as, Waterborne add content to make the game even more enjoyable. All in all, I would recommend this game for those who enjoy this type of game. It is worth multiple playthroughs using various tactics.

												Tropico 5 is the new younger brother of the awe-inspiring Tropico 4. Not suprisingly, Tropico 5 has many less buildings then Tropico 4 *cough* expect DLC *cough* but it still manages to be an upgrade to Tropico 4.  El Presidente's notable new toys include better military and companionship (multiplayer). You shouldn't not buy this game just because it wasn't as much of an upgrade as Tropico 4 was for the franchise. But if you don't have any Tropico games I would suggest buying Tropico 4 now and getting this on sale with the destined-to-come DLC later.Edit: It's a year later and I recently purchased all of the DLC (but two minor ones) for 85% off at 11.00 dollars recently(Humble Bundle). True to my predictions Tropico 5 has introduced 12 DLC's so far to fill the void of initial release. I've put in 30 hours at this point and plan to put in more, so I can safely recommend this game. Buy Tropico 5 and its DLC cheap, and I think you will find it worth it. (I should also mention the older Tropicos are almost just as fun and still much cheaper atm.)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 15, 2014
												One of the crtiticisms levelled at Tropico 4 was that it was purely an extension of Tropico 3; not so much a new game as an expansion pack.  In a way, the same can be said for this new offering albeit with a different engine and management focus. Running through the campaign means juggling between two islands; once you complete a scenario, you either continue on your current island or switch to the second. They have the same buildings and workforce, just the scenario parameters change.  This can be quite annoying if you've spent so long playing on one island as switching means remembering where you were up to, particularly with the new management system.  Gone is the focus control of El Presidente, running him around the map to help with building times and increasing productivity; instead we get an increasing number of managers with different abilities who you have to allocate to buildings.  This can be very micro-managing, especially with your `family` who you have to send abroad on tasks and then re-allocate to a building.The scenario tasks remain pretty standard compared to previous Tropicos.  Exports/imports, tourism and rebels are still present as are the natural disasters.  A nice design touch is being able to rebuild all your destroyed building post disaster rather than finding individual ruins.Overall, there are some nice improvements and the graphics engine is certainly an improvement.  This is still a Tropico game though, and not wholly different to its predecessors.  Recommended to previous El Presidente's but if you're new to the series, you would be better off starting with Tropico 4 and the Modern Times expansion.

												Tropico 5 is a strange experience. In many ways it is better than its predecessors but yet in other respects worst - especially without the DLC of the previous games. One of the key issues with the game is that it doesn't feel as though the game has really changed the formula all that much... Yes they've added some "eras" but frankly they add little to the game - all that changes from era to era is the ability to access a few new buildings and appease a new set of world powers.It just feels as though Tropico 5 is being sold on the basis of being "revolutionary" and "game-changing" when all it is in my opinion is a prettified version of Tropico 4 with a few nifty features thrown in (arguably this is not a bad thing...but let me explain) - such features are the trade, research and constitution. While these features are good I feel as though didn't get implemented or used to their full potential. For example the constituion in my opinion needs more options; there also needs to be a greater variety of tech and research options (at the momment its just a load of icons that have to be pressed in more or less a set order to progress) and lastly the trade feature I believe would be better if it gave you the freedom to import as much as you like (assuming you had the necessary funds, rather than having to use up your export ships).Additionally another area I would really like to see improved is the variety of buildings - both in terms of style and new buildings, undoubtedly these will be added as part of DLC but it would have been nice to have more from the initial release. For example a greater range of housing options, restaurants, government buildings and public services would help make towns feel less duplicated as it doesn't take long to exhaust all of the construction options.Despite these gripes Tropico 5 does have several great features, namely the graphics and overall design do really make the enviroment look like a real "Tropico"-al Island and the models are all very well detailed too. Plus the economy and government approval system also feel more realistic and fluid. Quests are also varied and interesting which ensures a steady stream of tasks and rewards - these actually make you feel more engaged with the outside world.Another feature of the game that is core to Tropico 5 is the multiplayer aspect but as I haven't really played it enough I have decided to not comment on this feature.Generally speaking Tropico 5 is a great game and for any fan of the series it is certainly a must buy, but that being said I do feel as though it's not as "revolutionary" as they appear to make out - it is simply the great Tropico series you have known and loved but back and better than ever...

content:
er 16, 2014
												Lately I've been holding off on reviewing many things, due to the nature of many games being worked on continuously and things changing very fluidly.Today I write a big thumbs up for the Tropico 5 team for pulling through on two things that many in the community thought they had ripped us off on.The first, prisons. Why these weren't there at launch is beyond me, considering they were in Tropico 3 & 4, the community thought perhaps we would get nickled and dimed for a prison DLC. The dev team to the surprise of many, at patch 1.08, have hadded the prison and the ability to arrest citizens for FREE.In addition to this, the second large complaint was the 2000 population limit. Tropico 5 offers various huge Islands for the players to build on, much of which would stay empty due to the low population limit. Not to mention the horrible side effect of this limit and multiplayer - in which the total cap was divided among all players. New with patch 1.08 is the ability to change the max population anywhere between the original 2000, and the new high limit of 10,000.I have to say I am very happy to see the devs change their stance on the population cap after community feedback, and would highly recommend this game to anyone. It's done a lot for the series, and is very unique in its approach compared to T3 & T4. Not to mention the devs, while a little slow on the action point here, nontheless pulled through for the community. With my restored faith I may just buy the large upcomming DLC at full price :)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
17, 2014
												8 hours in and I still have absolutely no idea what people are complaining about. I've been an avid Tropico player since the very first game. I sank and hours and hours into Tropico 3 (on the Xbox360) and have a ton of time racked up on 4 as well. So when 5 was released and everyone started complaining I was kind of confused. I held off on buying the game until it went on Sale and let me just say that I think it is more than worth the full price. So far it has absolutely everything I love about Tropico and more. No longer is it game over when the US or USSR decide to invade. You can defend yourself! Your presidente gets a single trait, and all of the members of your dynasty get one as well, every time there's an election you can decide which dynasty member you're going to have run for office. You can appoint managers to your buildings which offers a bunch of different ways in which to modify the behavior of the game. No longer are protests are just the populace voicing their displeasure. You can choose to negotiate with them and trigger an event that increases that faction's opinion of you if you complete it. The import/export system has been overhauled to great effect and the trade system is absolutely a pleasure to work with. Same with the reasearch section which adds a new element to the game and removes the feeling that all problems in El Presidente's life can be solved by throwing money at them. I have a mid-low end computer and even on somewhat low settings the game looks gorgeous. It runs smoothly and feels well optimized. There's so much more I could probably go on and on about it. I honestly don't have any complaints. As someone who has played these games from the start I've had so much fun watching it grow and change over the years. This newest iteration doesn't disappoint and promises many hours of play in the future.

content:
y 3, 2015
												The only real issue I have with this game, is that it often creates copies of your ruling family. After playing half the campaign mode, and 1 game in sandbox mode, I had 5 copies of my single ruling family. Not 2: 5. I like the idea of having your family bridge multiple games, but I'll have to throw away 50% of the time spent playing this game if I want to use my family in its most advanced state. It's unfortunate this feature wasn't implimented better.The music and atmosphere of this game is great. It's relaxing to play, and makes you feel stress-free: like being on a tropical island. At the same time, you have a lot of choices to make, and really feel like your decisions are critical for your island's well-being, although quite possibly your citizenry would be well off if you took a ten year nap.. . there are a few annoyances regarding how the game ships resources: effectively all resources are always sent to the docks: if another building on the island requests them, then those resources won't ship off the island--right away--but as your island gets larger, and more demanding, it can be months before resources get picked up. and they end up getting sold instead of transported forward. The addition of a checkbox you could tick to not sell an item if it's stored at a dock, would solve this, but instead the solution is to import much more of a resource than you need and hope some of it's still there when someone arrives to transport it. And don't get all uppity at me and be all "oh, just build more resource moving dudes:" the rate of resource movement is fine when there's a surplus of resources. The issue is that, when your power plant needs iron, and then a ship comes in and all your iron gets sold, and now the task "transport iron to the power plant" gets lost. . . Then another ship imports iron, and the task "transport iron the power plant" is added again, but to the bottom of the queue. Then, before it reaches the top of the queue, another ship arrives and all the iron is sold again. Do you see how this is a problem? Yes, there are some things you can do to outplay the system and get to your own iron before it gets sold, but just having a option to not sell the iron you critically need for your island, would be a much more realistic, simplier solution, which does not exist. Why not?!! I've given you two issues, and these are really the most serious issues I have with the game. Most everything else is clear, and fun to play with. Oh! It does suck that you can't build new buildings during an attack: the time my island got invaded just as a two large military facilities were about to complete, and so I lost: that sucked. The island was in a state of war for a year and half: you're telling me the new barracks couldn't finish training their troops in a year and a half and come to finish off the one enemy unit that survived and slowly plinked away at my manor until it was destroyed?! Okay, so those three things suck, but a lot about this game is really enjoyableI hope that, being more aware of the issues with this game, will help you enjoy it more, because they are issues you can prepare for, and this is really a relaxing, fun, game to play :)

Pros:- difficulty increase. On medium I can barely pass the elections a lot of the time.- different difficulty options for both economical and political side of the game.- humour. Oh this game has a lot of it. Everything your presidente says, evenrything your research team says is there to make you laugh. - the new research and dynasty system- new graphics (the game is beautiful and runs far better than Tropico 4 on my system, even though this one is DX11 and previous one wasn't)- the new age system- multiplayerCons:-lack of avatar customization - most bjuildings were moved to the research page, meaning that in the first age you have far less to choose from- the single player mostly springs you back and forward between two islands. Kind of reminds me of Tropico 2 with their changes. Either way it's a good game and I don't regret getting it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
11
												Tropico - The original dictator simulator. Now in its fifth iteration, has enough changed to justify another purchase, after facing criticism of a lack of real progress between numbers 3 and 4? Well, yes and no.I'd like to get this out of the way right now: Tropico 5 is a great game. In fact it's probably the second most fun, humourous and complete title in the series, and having played it through on the Xbox 360, Xbox One and PC, I can say without hesitation this is the version to have, right here on Steam.Gameplay hasn't really changed much from the last title, but some alterations have been made which both enhance and detract from the experience. First of all, international trading is much more involved and satisfying. Instead of going into your almanac and simply checking off things you'd like to import and export, you click on your shipping dock and work to the supply and demand of each nation. You can assign more than one ship to a trade route, so if for example you're trying to get a nuclear power plant up and running early and China have a good price on uranium, you can stick three ships on that route to bring it in as quickly as possible. You'll also find limited time export deals, so you can send your excess stockpile of coal or canned goods to a country which will pay double the going rate for a contracted time of three years. Again, just an example.Another big feature, especially when playing on randomised islands, is the RTS style 'fog of war'. In Tropico 5, you have to send out your palace soldiers to scout the land, uncovering the fog to reveal the landscape. You can see where mines and different are through the fog, but the types of mineral they hold will only be revealed by clearing the fog. You can't build in fogged territory either, so it's a balancing act between uncovering land to build, or making a bee line for the nearest mine to get your production up and running. Like any real time game, this is only really important during the opening stages, but if - like me - you're constantly in the red for the first year or so, paying $1000 per time to reroute your scouting party can prove a costly excercise.A further decent addition is that of having a proper family dynasty. El Presidente will have children, and you can form a dynasty of up to five members. Each of these dynasty members has their own traits which affect the overall balance of the game, and you can select which one to play as before every mission, allowing you to preempt the needs of the people during that mission.Also, you now unlock research, Civilization style, which allows you to gradually uncover more edicts to write and more buildings to construct. Edicts are plentiful and have a huge impact of gameplay, allowing you to do everything from banning tobacco to providing social security for your pensioners. Of course there are fascist ones as well, such as putting the entire island under military control or completely banning emigration.When you first start a new island, you'll be running it under the command of the British Empire as a colony,and you have a limited number of months to achieve your goals and gain total independence. When this happens, you get to decide what kind of leader you'll be by signing a US style Constitution, setting out the terms of your leadership and controlling everything from who's allowed to vote, to how the media is run. If you decide to run your island as a democracy, you'll find yourself at the mercy of the voting factions every year, and as before you can make promises to sway the voters before each election. You can only ammend the constitution every four years though, so be very careful what you put in place!Some of the micromanagement has been pared back, and to be honest it's not always for the better. The individual needs of your people are far less important than the groups as a whole. So, it doesn't really matter any more if a part of your community is outside the radius of a church or hospital - as long as the different factions on your island approve of you as a whole, you're not going to lose an election. Also, your happiness and approval rate are now separate stats, so again, as long as you are ok in the big picture you'll be fine. Direct control of your avatar has also been removed, so you can no longer visit your building sites and establishments to crack the whip.Another simplified idea, which sounds good on paper, is the alteration of the island structure during the main campaign. Previously, you would manage a different island from scratch for every mission, allowing you to push yourself to meet the goals of that mission before moving on and starting afresh. Now, you have just two islands which you go back and forth between, with the idea being you play missions 1,3,5 etc on island one, and missions 2,4,6 etc on island 2. The mission goals change just as in previous titles, but your island is preserved as you left it. Again, it sounds like a good idea, as you have to think ahead about taking care of your people long term. But that's why it absolutely doesn't work: You have no idea what's coming next. Suddenly, you're out of space and you've built a carefully constructed military defence, only to have to tear it all down to meet the goals of the next task. The mission goals aren't structured to take advantage of the long term island system, so they may as well have left you island hopping as before. Half way through the campaign, you do get two fresh islands to start with, and it's a huge relief, but the same thing happens for the latter half of the game, moving between the two.It's a good job then that the actual gameplay is still as robust as it ever was: Building and hiring workers is identical to previous releases, with a radial menu equally suited to mouse or controller. Yes, a city management game which arguably feels as at home using an Xbox controller as it does using a mouse, and it works straight out of the box, with the appropriate button commands displayed on the screens. The game still looks great, with fantastic detail on the buildings, allowing you to zoom right in and see the curtains in house windows, apartments with laundry hanging on the lines strung from wall to wall, and the gradual build up of goods in farms and factories waiting to be taken by your teamsters so the nearest dock. Individual garages have been removed, and people can now take their cars straight from any building with a garage to any other, and they've added a metro system, which you can place anywhere as a station entrance, essentially allowing pedestrians to teleport from any one to any other.The disasters, complete with Penultimo's warnings, are back and are as destructive as ever. They have changed the voice actor for Penultimo, but when you get used to it he's just as funny and just as stupid as before. The great Latin soundtrack is back, and is as fitting and brilliant as ever.Largely, the pros outweigh the cons in Tropico 5. Whilst I still consider 4 to be the peak of the series thus far, there's enough new, funny and outlandish content here to justify diving back in. With the whole collection being available for a good price, including extra missions and two extra campaigns full of new buildings and concepts, if you're a fan of the series you'll love it. If you're a city builder fanatic and have never played Tropico before, this is the perfect spot to jump right on in, but seriously consider picking up the marginally superior previous title as well.

I like the idea of having your family bridge multiple games, but I'll have to throw away 50% of the time spent playing this game if I want to use my family in its most advanced state. It's unfortunate this feature wasn't implimented better.The music and atmosphere of this game is great. It's relaxing to play, and makes you feel stress-free: like being on a tropical island. At the same time, you have a lot of choices to make, and really feel like your decisions are critical for your island's well-being, although quite possibly your citizenry would be well off if you took a ten year nap.. . there are a few annoyances regarding how the game ships resources: effectively all resources are always sent to the docks: if another building on the island requests them, then those resources won't ship off the island--right away--but as your island gets larger, and more demanding, it can be months before resources get picked up. and they end up getting sold instead of transported forward. The addition of a checkbox you could tick to not sell an item if it's stored at a dock, would solve this, but instead the solution is to import much more of a resource than you need and hope some of it's still there when someone arrives to transport it. And don't get all uppity at me and be all "oh, just build more resource moving dudes:" the rate of resource movement is fine when there's a surplus of resources. The issue is that, when your power plant needs iron, and then a ship comes in and all your iron gets sold, and now the task "transport iron to the power plant" gets lost. . . Then another ship imports iron, and the task "transport iron the power plant" is added again, but to the bottom of the queue. Then, before it reaches the top of the queue, another ship arrives and all the iron is sold again. Do you see how this is a problem? Yes, there are some things you can do to outplay the system and get to your own iron before it gets sold, but just having a option to not sell the iron you critically need for your island, would be a much more realistic, simplier solution, which does not exist. Why not?!! I've given you two issues, and these are really the most serious issues I have with the game. Most everything else is clear, and fun to play with. Oh! It does suck that you can't build new buildings during an attack: the time my island got invaded just as a two large military facilities were about to complete, and so I lost: that sucked. The island was in a state of war for a year and half: you're telling me the new barracks couldn't finish training their troops in a year and a half and come to finish off the one enemy unit that survived and slowly plinked away at my manor until it was destroyed?! Okay, so those three things suck, but a lot about this game is really enjoyableI hope that, being more aware of the issues with this game, will help you enjoy it more, because they are issues you can prepare for, and this is really a relaxing, fun, game to play :)

												Attention: if you go to negative reviews, completely ignore people talking about DX11 and DX11 cards. Those were in the minimum system requirements and it's their fault for not reading it. Now about the game:It's different from the rest of the series, and I think that that's a good thing. Pros:- difficulty increase. On medium I can barely pass the elections a lot of the time.- different difficulty options for both economical and political side of the game.- humour. Oh this game has a lot of it. Everything your presidente says, evenrything your research team says is there to make you laugh. - the new research and dynasty system- new graphics (the game is beautiful and runs far better than Tropico 4 on my system, even though this one is DX11 and previous one wasn't)- the new age system- multiplayerCons:-lack of avatar customization - most bjuildings were moved to the research page, meaning that in the first age you have far less to choose from- the single player mostly springs you back and forward between two islands. Though you have to be strategic about what mission you play on which. My opinion as a person that owned the previous tropico games? It does so much differently that it's a must have! Kind of reminds me of Tropico 2 with their changes. Either way it's a good game and I don't regret getting it.

content:
y 14
												Tropico 5 is a game that I originally didn't think I would get much out of. It seemed too simple or too narrow of a topic. Just focusing on a small tropical nation. However, I quickly found it to be quite enjoyable.Tropic stars you, El Presidente, as you and your family take your tiny colony through the world wars, cold war, and the present. Making choices about how free your people are, economic and political choices, and balancing the needs of your people, your own bank account, and keeping your grip on power. You may start out as a benevolent leader, but you may find yourself having to take drastic measures and fight off the occasional revolutionary or election opponent.4/5 Cuban Cigars smoked. Great game if a little simplistic at times.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
er 6, 2014
												Tropico 5 offers a wide range of choices for building a city. Industrial, agricultural, or commercial cities all provide amusement. The era system feels great, and trading in the game has never been better. The missions are diverse and funny, with some being a pain in the neck. Technology is nicely executed. I certainly enjoyed watching my people withstand hardships (since I am a dictator). Foreign relations are greatly expanded, and are more complex, accompanying serious dilemmas that can decide the fate of your city. Military power is straightforward and easy to handle, although I wished for more options. Every building seems to be handsomely illustrated. Concerning transportation, I expected multiple road systems, such as: bridges, tunnels, ext. Tourism in the game is really exciting, but most of its buildings are expensive, which can halt construction for a period of time. DLC? meh, don't even bother. In conclusion, Tropico 5 runs smoothly and is fun to play. It brings this simultaneous feeling of simulation and pleasure. Go buy it if you liked Tropico 4.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												"Chances are, if you’re a “Tropico” fan, you’re going to pick this up anyway despite what reviewers may say.  As such, allow me to address those completely new to the series.  “Tropico 5″ doesn’t exactly redefine the series, but it makes some very ground-breaking additions that make playing the game much more enjoyable.  It unfortunately takes away some really important features (setting rents & wages to an exact value, etc.), but adds almost just as much to keep things interesting.  If you’re on the fence about dropping forty bucks (the price as of 4/30/14), then go and download “Tropico 3″ or “Tropico 4″ for much cheaper.  They won’t give you the full experience (“Tropico 4″ with “Modern Times” comes closest), but will give you an idea if you can handle life as “El Presidente”.  If you can’t, then you’re only out ten or twenty bucks instead of forty.  As a whole though, “Tropico 5″ is a joy to play and I’m looking forward to many, many hours of ruthless dictatorship the likes of which my Tropicans have never seen."Full Review: http://www.dadsgamingaddiction.com/tropico-5/

content:
y 20, 2016
												The idea of the game is pretty cool, but it still lacks the completion and amendments for the game that make it perfect. I played it like five or six hours and literally couldn't stop, you as a dictator governing your own island and manage and watch it pace into more modern stages. Each stage of an era is a new start, you will have new foreign powers influencing your island's future, you will have to trade as much as possible to fulfill your treasury bag. If your first start at a innately rich island, you basically just need to export as much as possible, making your dictated country rich and prosperous. Build more and more buildings, infrastructures, research facilities, education facilities, be the most self-righteous gwuy in the world and implement it to your real urban planning. As I'm bit interesting in urban planning, this game literally give you the chances to build a city on the basis of all your ideas. In other word, be the most ♥♥♥♥ing awesome guy in the world and your countrymen will kneel down as much as possible, if they don't, make them. ;) The idea of owing an island in Carribean Sea is as cool as developing it into something you aspire to. And the ultimate goal I guess is to develop it into a country that is as strong and powerful enough to be able to against superpowers manipulating you for long. Anyway, till here, the game is kinda cool, but there are defects that it has to address.Typically, the battle element. The game focuses on mostly construction and governing, but the battle is awful. You can't build anything during a battle, you can't save your palace as long as you don't have enough manpowers to fight back, and literally watching it collapse (WTF?!). And the invasion of superpowers are just op, your squads of soldiers literally do nothing but wandering around and getting high I guess, they just get beaten up one by one or just basically get vanquished. And one building only produce one squad of infantry, which is painful, you basically don't have anything to against superpowers army when you only built three or four military facilities. And once your palace is compromised, the game is over, you lose and you have to start it over. And rebels, they are just as annoying as your neighborhood granny, once you stepped into more modern eras they r like periods basically wouldn't stop and appearing periodically. And once appeared a rebellion force you will have to eliminate them, and we start to talk about battle. Yeah, battle is just painful and bad. I wondering why they still haven't fix it or upgrade it since the game has released almost one year and a half and more, and there are people complaining about it.  You can't take peoples money and do nothing. That's basically it, think before you buy.有没有官中无所谓，简单一句话，战斗太蛋疼，被打的时候还不能造兵怎么让我好好大独裁!?

content:
y 26, 2016
												In a word: Over-complication. T3 and T4 are some of my most favorite games. Each with their own liitle quirks, but totally enjoyable. T5 manages to improve on one of my biggest pet peeves from previous installments: Farms now have clearly defined areas in which to grow crops. And that is ALL T5 does for the series. Every single other action is over-complicated to the Nth degree. I can barely enjoy sandbox mode because, surpirse, it's no sandbox. No matter what you do, or what you WANT to do (that is the point of a sandbox, afterall), you're going to be following the same damn repetitious timeline for each and every game. Nevermind the fact that it's boring and complicated, it just doesn't feel finished. Thoroughly dissappointed in this game. Haven't lost hope for the series, hopefully someone at Haemimont is paying attention to this stuff.

Foreign policy, winning elections, and charting new trade routes keep the game feeling fresh and fun, plus the eras help provide the player with new challenges and abilities as the years go by. Overall, great game and I definitely recommend it!

content:
y 20, 2016
												The idea of the game is pretty cool, but it still lacks the completion and amendments for the game that make it perfect. I played it like five or six hours and literally couldn't stop, you as a dictator governing your own island and manage and watch it pace into more modern stages. Each stage of an era is a new start, you will have new foreign powers influencing your island's future, you will have to trade as much as possible to fulfill your treasury bag. If your first start at a innately rich island, you basically just need to export as much as possible, making your dictated country rich and prosperous. Build more and more buildings, infrastructures, research facilities, education facilities, be the most self-righteous gwuy in the world and implement it to your real urban planning. As I'm bit interesting in urban planning, this game literally give you the chances to build a city on the basis of all your ideas. In other word, be the most ♥♥♥♥ing awesome guy in the world and your countrymen will kneel down as much as possible, if they don't, make them. ;) The idea of owing an island in Carribean Sea is as cool as developing it into something you aspire to. And the ultimate goal I guess is to develop it into a country that is as strong and powerful enough to be able to against superpowers manipulating you for long. Anyway, till here, the game is kinda cool, but there are defects that it has to address.Typically, the battle element. The game focuses on mostly construction and governing, but the battle is awful. You can't build anything during a battle, you can't save your palace as long as you don't have enough manpowers to fight back, and literally watching it collapse (WTF?!). And the invasion of superpowers are just op, your squads of soldiers literally do nothing but wandering around and getting high I guess, they just get beaten up one by one or just basically get vanquished. And one building only produce one squad of infantry, which is painful, you basically don't have anything to against superpowers army when you only built three or four military facilities. And once your palace is compromised, the game is over, you lose and you have to start it over. And rebels, they are just as annoying as your neighborhood granny, once you stepped into more modern eras they r like periods basically wouldn't stop and appearing periodically. And once appeared a rebellion force you will have to eliminate them, and we start to talk about battle. Yeah, battle is just painful and bad. I wondering why they still haven't fix it or upgrade it since the game has released almost one year and a half and more, and there are people complaining about it.  You can't take peoples money and do nothing. That's basically it, think before you buy.有没有官中无所谓，简单一句话，战斗太蛋疼，被打的时候还不能造兵怎么让我好好大独裁!?

y 26, 2016
												In a word: Over-complication. T3 and T4 are some of my most favorite games. Each with their own liitle quirks, but totally enjoyable. T5 manages to improve on one of my biggest pet peeves from previous installments: Farms now have clearly defined areas in which to grow crops. And that is ALL T5 does for the series. Every single other action is over-complicated to the Nth degree. I can barely enjoy sandbox mode because, surpirse, it's no sandbox. No matter what you do, or what you WANT to do (that is the point of a sandbox, afterall), you're going to be following the same damn repetitious timeline for each and every game. Nevermind the fact that it's boring and complicated, it just doesn't feel finished. Thoroughly dissappointed in this game. Haven't lost hope for the series, hopefully someone at Haemimont is paying attention to this stuff.

content:
30, 2015
												Sadly I can't recommend this game. I am a big fan of the Tropico games and was excited when I finally got my hands on it to play it. But after playing it, beating the missions and doing some sandbox games, there is something definitely wrong with this version of the game. For one thing there seems to be money issues all the time. With no matter what you have set up you are always losing money as you get into the game. Your popularity goes to low  levels that you have no way of recovering from and you get military take overs with no way to get out of that situation. Tropico 4 had it all and fine tuned it and the game was just fun. This one is like Tropico 4 with less options. less fun and more frustration.  The game is supposed to be fun. And for some reason they removed all the elements that were fun in the previous installment. I do like that they tried to come up with new ideas for the series with going through time periods and having family members you can add but instead of removing things that were in prior versions and making the game much harder and frustrating .. how about just improving on the previous edition and remembering that the game is supposed to be fun too? Its not fun always losing money, having everyone hate the president and having less options in the game. Sadly  just not enjoying it like I hoped I would. I played this one a lot as you can see from my time put into it. So its not just a quick play to come to this final decision here. Tropico 4 so much better. Hopefully Tropico 5 will be improved in later patches but I can't recommend this game as it is currently stands. Sorry just was so short and disapointing. No way am I spending another cent on DLC for this mess. The game is supposed to be more fun as you get to the present and beyond. Not ridiculously unfair. Sometimes I think developers are too smart for their own good.

content:
, 2014
												Wow, while so many other franchises are releasing lifeless clones made with more modern middleware. Tropico 5 adds gameplay to the existing strong strategic game mechanic, while increasing the graphics and streamilining the gameplay through use of often comical npc interactions which keep the game moving, adding TRUE online multiplayer, featuring a masterful invite friendlist ready system as well as a join random games list. The TRUE ONLINE MULTIPLAYER GAMEPLAY is done exceptionally  well too. What a superb addition to an already bright futured franchise. I can honestly say this is the first game I can remember enjoying its sequel more than its original... We couldnt be more happy with this title. If I had to find some cons to the amazing list of pros this title boasts, I would have to say the lack of a multiplayer save function and no Lan option. However because the Online multiplayer has been working so exceptionally well since day two, You probably will not miss LAN very much. The only worry I have is when we manage to last hours and one of us runs out of time, the game is effectively over. I hope they will add the multiplayer save in the future. What a great game I highly recomend! ^^PS great music too, but thats not news with this franchise :)

content:
er 29, 2016
												I DIG city builder games and I went into this with as positive an attitude as someone possibly could.  After 10 hours of repetitive gameplay unfortunately the experience is incredibly 'lightweight' and disappointing.  Much of my time has been spent alt+tabbing to find the solution to something on a Steam guide, which sometimes turns out to be 'just a bug' or 'guesswork'.Cons:- City builder elements are very shallow.  You upgrade Police Stations to put out fires as there are no Fire Stations. Tropico lacks the essential city building elements of its rivals, and it doesn't do a good job of explaining or giving information on the elements that it does have.  There is no 'traffic', and no feedback or information as to how your production network even runs.- Strategy elements are near non existent.  You plonk down some houses and some farms then after a while you get enough money to plonk down the next thing.  You do get attacked by rebels but there is zero strategy involved with how it plays out.- A huge issue with lack of information.  How many construction offices do I need?  How many Teamster offices do I need?  How much stock makes up the 'other' stock which is about to be shipped out - why can't I expand that window to see how much I am actually producing?- Communication ambiguities, for example, 'setting the budget' on a house actually means 'raising the rent', not the budget you give towards the upkeep of houses, like you do for other buildings.- Housing bugs, for example citizens refusing to live in houses and instead declare themselves 'homeless' even though you have set their salaries high and the rent of the houses low.  No information is given as to why citizens would be homeless, and after searching online though guides, this is possibly a bug.- Lack of building variety, even with the DLC buildings, which are very unreasonably priced.- Voice acting is used sparingly.- 'Advanced trading mechanics' - lol, good one.- Even when on amicable terms, signing an alliance treaty with the Axis results in them invading you, then you defeating them, and then them immediately agreeing to the alliance after they declared a 'mini-war' on you for initiating an alliance treaty.  That's not what I'd call a believable simulation of the diplomatic and strategic implications of an alliance...Lastly the population is capped at 2000, you have the option to raise it up to 10000, but raising it above 2000 comes with a warning message about game stability and bug issues.  If I can only populate 10% of an island then where's the fun in that?

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
y 14
												I feel bad leaving a negative review, I really do, because a part of me wants to love this game and I burned many hours on Tropico 4. However, I haven't finished the campaign and do not feel the DLC merits spending because of glaring gameplay issues and I really hope the developers read this and there will be a new and improved Tropico 6. The short version is that you will probably be better off buying 4 if this interests or taking a pass if you are only tacitly interested in city simulators. On the off chance that a developer will read this though (or if you are really curious), there is a long version below.I want to start with the positive. The new look of Tropico 5 compared to 4 is an improvement, the basics of running an economy is still there and I appreciate buildings like the office block which rewards you for building a large and dense city just when natural resources will start running out. I feel like if they expand ways for you to make money outside of pulling crops, metals and oil out of the ground then the sequel will give people the freedom to construct much more personalized cities that fit their own styles. I also like that a new level of complexity has been given to elections but that is where we quickly run into problems. The fundemental problem of Tropico 5, which made it too frustrating for me to want to finish, is the dimension that requires you to keep control of island despite elections, coups and revolutions. People who move from Tropico 4 to 5 will be startled what a much larger role factions play in getting re-elected. Now you can largely ignore basic services and as long as you build a new church or start taxing the rich at election time you can make huge gains. Unfortunately, this is very poorly communicated. The most effective thing to do is to see which factions have the largest populations, see which ones you can make happy at the same time and then tailor your constitution and edicts accordingly. However, while you can guess who will like what changes (ten dollars for guessing the Religious will like a Theocratic State) there will often be people who dislike one change that you could not really have forseen and because there is also a penalty in relations from changing policies that people liked you are quickly trying to fix them all before all of a sudden you lose.I get the feeling that the first couple levels were trying to familiarize you with this system but because I was able to beat them without going in-depth, and no text pointed me in the direction of the factions, this was a poor tutorial. I ended up having to look up why I was having so many popularity issues (strictly in the game I mean). A tooltip under edicts, buildings, and amendments that told you who liked what and by how much would have gone a long way. If that is too much handholding it would be fine if there was an option to disable it. However, it would allow one to more effectively build a coalition by avoiding decisions that will permanently and unforeseeably damage relations with one faction. Without being able to be that effecient, I feel like I am constantly trying to patch relations to please these factions so I do not suffer a game over. While some people may like this, I feel that these challenges should force a player to adapt their city, not completely rewrite. The way it is now, I feel that I do not have any substantial control over how I build on the map and then ruins the city builder fantasy for me.Along similar lines, if we had more information on triggered revolts and coups then I feel like this game would be alot less frustrating. I saw other people calling attention to this in the comments and I feel like it would go a long way towards helping. I am not sure if the difficulty itself actually need to be reduced but I definitely feel that I do not have a way to address these fundemental obstacles in the game, lose, eventually get frustrated and just quit. I mostly play it on the offchance of a eureka moment that will finally let me finish the campaign, but I am not holding out much hope. I hope great strides are made in Tropico 6 but I will have to wait a while before I decide to buy it.

content:
ber 9, 2014
												I was one of the many die-hard Tropico fans who was suckered into pre-ordering this game. Tropicos 1 - 4 were all amazing, I can't even begin to count how many hours I've blown playing them on PC and X-Box. And I don't regret a minute playing any of them. So when I heard Tropico 5 was coming out, and it would include features like multiple eras and even a Constitution, I got very excited and pre-ordered ASAP.Big mistake. The game is buggy as hell, some things they refuse to fix. The Constitution options for immigration? Forget about it. They don't make a lick of difference. Even if you ban immigration you still get bunches of immigrants (illegal aliens, anyone?). The entire game has been simplified and dumbed down. And forget about better graphics. Buildings may look sleek from a distance, but zoom in and they are flat and pixelated in the extreme.Just about everything I loved from Tropico 4 was cut out of the game, and precious little was put back in to make up for it. This game is bland, boring, and a complete betrayal of the fan base. Do yourself a favour: buy Tropico 4. I promise it'll be more worth your money than this piece of crap.

												I played Tropico 4 and fell in love with the series, that game was near perfection for a city building series. I then played Tropico 3 and loved that too. It had less features than Tropico 4 but was still fun. Tropico 5 is terrible compared to the two and that's putting it nicely. They literally took 20 step backwards to try and pretty up the game. But in doing so they made the game much tougher to run and just plain slow unless you have a pc that's not 2 years or older. T5 also has very little features compared to the other Tropico games. They essentially want you to buy the DLCs and they did that by literally stripping all the features that made tropico great to package them into dlc to make extra $$$. When companies do that to their games it strips the quality in the game and you can tell if you just get the base game. Do yourself a favor wait until the game is like $15 with all the dlc content packaged together. You'll save yourself money and MIGHT actually enjoy it in the end.

content:
, 2014
												Feels like a Beta to me. There are some really promising features in this game (ex. dynasty, trade ships) but not so many. Definitely wasted potential. And what irritated me the most? Boring as hell Colonial Era. Really bad music - not even close to the old series. Forget about any singers. Textures without shadows and details. Only one variant of each building and four clothes/faces for your presidente. You just can't stop people from coming to your island (even with Constitution options!) – and there is no emigration office to help you deal with this problem. No options for restarting current missions – from main menu you can only play full campaign from the beginning. And there are 10 missions in 2 islands for the entire game! And of course they removed many cool building from Tropico 4 ex. Police stations is now also a fire brigade, only 2 types of schools, forget about zoo, tourists shops, golden statues (they give only 2 gardens size with no variations!). No options for education profiles, tv programs or kinds of films to play in your cinema. Only a few different models of peoples. As a big fan of series it seems to me like they don’t have money or time to finish the game properly so they sold what they have. Sad. Now I understand why they give you free copy of Tropico 4 and “future DLC”.

content:
7, 2015
												I don't think this is a terrible game, and if you're bored or not worried about the cash - sure, buy it.But it's not great.  I think the series (or developer) has gone a little bit creatively bankrupt .. clearly struggling to find new ways to reinvent the game.  (Which, strictly speaking, I don't think you need to do - you can just improve on the existing formula).What I mean is - rather than look for substantial changes, make iterative ones - make the underlying financial simulation stronger, make the graphics better, make the islands larger ... and then make it all about the story-telling and controlled challenges in the scenario.Instead, it feels like they've kind of tried to reinvent a bit .. consolidating concepts that came up in Tropico 4 DLCs (like changing eras) and introduce them into this game.  Problem is it all feels shallow.  There's this dynasty concept where you can have children, raise them, have them fulfil roles in your dynasty (but you yourself don't die, apparently).  There's just .. I don't know .. a shallowness to it all that makes you start yawning before you're even halfway through the game.They've also left core elements out of the game, and a lot of the stuff that made Tropico 4 interesting (such as balancing the factions) has been de-emphasised in Tropico 5.It feels to me that Tropico 5 is kind of like the wanna-be cool grandad of Tropico 4 .. it's actually older and less edgy, but it tries to dress up in a younger persons clothes and act cool .. but you can kind of tell it's struggling to keep up the charade and running out of ideas.It was hard to decide whether YES I DO recommend this game or NO I DON'T.  For me it's marginal .. if you're looking for a city builder with it's own personality, why not ?  It's not a terri-♥♥♥♥ game .. it's just not great.

												It's still Tropico! It's pretty, it's funny, and fun... Although offering fewer options for micromanagement or the closer review of your population compared to Tropcio 4, which slightly bothers me. Trading is a handy addition and exploiting it is necessary to keep the island running, and the heavier focus on the citizens' political leanings makes keeping everyone happy a tad more challenging, although the endgame, as always, is the least interesting and exciting part of the game- Tropico is about the journey to greatness, not the destination. Overall on some fronts it feels a tad simplified, for better or worse, than the previous games. A little spread thin, if you will. Still recommended to fans of the series and citybuilders in general.

												Tropico 5 expands on the old things that made the Tropico series great. I love the new combat system, it was always a pain to never be able to fight off foreign invasion despite having a huge standing army, I mean, come on, Cuba won the Bay of Pigs, didn't they? Anyways, although the game is great and the expansions are also great, it would be very nice to see Haemimont/Kalypso expand from the regular Tropico theme. I know that Tropico 2 was comparatively a failure and its pirates theme was probably part of that, but I'm not asking for that much of a deviation. The one thing I would absolutely love for Tropico to do is to take the same everything its known for and place it into different nationality themes. Its great to be Castro for a while, but maybe sometimes I want to be Kim Jung Un, or Idi Amin, or even Erich Honecker. I would love to see a game exactly like Tropico that let me do everything tropico does but with a different ethnicity of people, a different flag, and a different climate.

content:
5, 2015
												I love Tropico and have done since my first experience as El Presidente in the original (i love it so much that i rebought 1-4 on steam). For a long time all I ever played were city building games, and I will say that the Tropico series are my favourites. While yes Simcity (the old ones) and even the new Cities Skylines are enjoyable, I usually get bored of the city I'm building after a while with the whole zoning, waiting for people to come to the city and build house/shops/industry build some services then repeat. The Anno series steps it up with you building each building, production chains and the occasional quest making it more engaging for me. Tropico gives me that but it also brings a fantastic humour to my megalomania experience (sorry in advance if I over use humour/funny etc, but it's true) that has me laughing out loud every time I play it and after nearly 300 hours of play I'm still not bored.In this latest instalment the humour that has kept me endlessly amused in previous games is still fantastic (I wish we could all have a Penultimo in our lives). The building models are done with great detail, the colours and textures of my island paradise are amazing. I sometimes like to zoom the camera right in and tilt it so it's like you standing at street level and watch the occasional sunset/rise.I used to feel that I never really had enough time lording over my adoring subjects (benevolently lording, most of the time anyway), especially in sandbox with games 3 and 4, but with the eras setup in this latest instalment I’m in El Presidente heaven. The addition of the colonial time is really nice, when declaring independence I always say 'let the redcoats come, I ain't paying the crown anything' (I'm actually British before anyone says anything). And the era specific random quests have fantastic humour in their delivery. There's one quest during the world wars era where La resistance needs messenger animals, the result of each animal tried - pigs are too tasty and become bacon before reaching their destination, still make me laugh every time. I know there have been a lot of disagreements over the whole DLC thing, I have to admit with other games I've thought they were a bit of a rip off, but with Topico's I've been really quite please. For £2.50 the small single mission ones have kept me entertained for at least a weekend on each play, the 2 £14.99 new campaign ones at least a couple, so I see them as good value (I have played them all more than once). The new random 'side quests' that accompany the DLC's are just as funny as those in the vanilla game and playing through the main campaign again with them popping up can drastically change how things play out. I failed a mission during my 10th play through of the main campaign after the addition of the Mad World and Espionage DLC's, due to a revolt caused by my overuse of banish/kill of crime lords and enemy spies. It was hilarious. So I have bought them all and I probably will continue to buy anymore that come out - if anyone from Kalypso is reading this I loved Pirate Cove, so if you wouldn't mind doing a piratey DLC. As Lulu say's everything is better with pirates!The one thing I will say I don't like and that's the complete reduction in advisors/representatives. I miss Miss Pineapple and her love of spanking (her little guest appearance visiting the fish people in one of the new side quests from the Waterborne DLC was a nice addition). Where's El Diablo telling me to stop letting the riffraff in. And while I love Lulu's radio show, Sunny and Penultimo's banter in 4 was just as fun (maybe they could do a guest spot). What happened to the other nations diplomats? Sometimes I could do with the 30,000 instead of the promised camelI’ve would definitely recommend Tropico 5 to anyone who likes city building games and I hope that Kalypso will continue to bring us more life as El Presidente

22, 2016
												I do not recommend this game because of its various bugs and flaws. First of all: This is like the 4 games before in this series. The concept is not new: build your island, control your money, eliminate rebels, do a tiny bit of diplomacy. After one or two tries you will realize that this game is much to easy compared to other simulations.And there are some really annoying things about this game:- You can't control immigration. Even if you restrict immigrants to only educated people you will get swarmed by them. They will be homeless and unemployed and rebel costantly.- You can't control stored goods. Even if you essentially need goods like Uranium, the game will sell it. You even can't check how much goods you have stored. Only in your harbor and that's where you don't want to have them- the transportation system is completly bugged. If you add tourists your roads will be one single traffic jam. But your people completly ignore alternative roads but simply pick the shortest route. Even if it takes years. Also you are forced to place production buildings directly next to the resources. Otherwise they will never get them. And later in the game even that doesn't work. If you want to play a city simulation that really works then try Cities Skylines. This one will only frustrate you.

content:
er 13, 2014
												The latest iteration of Kalypso Media's Tropico series, you take the reins of controlling your very own dynasty in order to create thriving metropolises right smack in the middle of a tropical island. Those familiar with the Tropcio series will feel right at home here with the fan favorite city building style that Tropico has to offer, but with some distinct gameplay, UI and graphical changes that spice up the series. For those unfamiliar with this game as well as the previous installments, the series is very Sim City-esque but with a refreshing take on the city building genre, giving you free rein on your citizens to do what you please. Want to be a absolute dictator, policing your city completely, riging elections and stopping the immigration of people all together? You can. Overall, I highly recommend this game, as well as the previous Tropico games. It might be worth it to pick up Tropico 3 or 4 with all DLC's if they go on sale before buying this game to get a feel for the series.

content:
, 2014
												The one thing I really like about Tropico 5 is that they really tried to make a new game. Anyone who's played the last 2 Tropico games knows that they're basically the same game with a little graphical touch up. Everything in Tropico 5 is different, from the apartments, to the power plants, everything has been redone. A lot of mechanics have been improved to feel less redundant and more intuitive. Now you can clearly  see how much space plantations will require, and gone are the days were you can't figure out how to get rid of the "garage overloaded" message.The campaign has changed in a big way. Maps from the previous missions are saved and you pick up where you left off in the next mission. No more having to start from scratch, the campaign is much more rewarding, and finally allows for building sprawling cities. But my favourite thing about the campaign is that it is finally challenging. I loved Tropico 3, but some of the missions in Tropico 4 were so mind boggling simple, they were exhausting. Tropico 5 brings the challenge in a new way and actually encourages building sustainablitiy instead of suiciding your treasury for mundane mission goals so you can win and start over.I haven't played the multiplayer yet, and I don't really plan to. This is the first time a Tropico game has really interested me with its sandbox mechanics, and when I'm done with the campaign I think I'll spend a long time trying to build the coolest island I can.

content:
, 2015
												Tropico 5 is still a Tropico game through and through, although it is a slight step below Tropico 4.There has been a lot of reviews that say that Tropico 4 is better, and it is, but Tropico 5 is still a fun game and that doesn't mean you should skip it.In Tropico you still play as a lovable dictator leading his latin america island to glory. You have to manage the economy, population happiness, military defence and politics in order to survive.There is flexibility in what economy you want, whether it be exporting raw materials like iron and coffee, turning them into goods like steel or canned food, or tourism.Politics is more advanced than in Tropico 4, where you have the Constitution which affects your country in different ways, and what you choose will affect your standings with the external world powers and also the internal factions in your country.The things that Tropico 4 did better are little things like Penultimo being voiced by a goofy hilarious voice actor, but in Tropico 5 he sounds like a monotonous person with no charisma.Tropico 4 also had nice music with the singing, but Tropico 5 doesn't.These little things however create the funny and fun atmosphere that Tropico is famed for, and something that is slightly missing in Tropico 5.Overall Tropico 5 is still a good game for people who love the franchise. But if you have never played Tropico 4, that game may be more worth your money.

r 24, 2014
												Well , if you have already played previous tropico's then this review is for you , BUT if this is the first tropico you have ever play , then this review is for you aswell :DAlright , for the previous players of tropico you may find this one is easy , with slight compeition and more realistic ways of getting things done , how? well they have added exporting/importing system to be more ''manual'' than just an automatic process , meaning is you can sell your production with higher prices if you get yourself a nice contract , and importing with all its types needs to be done manually. this might be abit harder for the players who first time play tropico through this 1. also the animation of military has been improved , got to be more realistic and more variable. soldiers / tanks / aircrafts / gun towers etc.-The humor in this tropico is slightly less than the previous ones but it didn't vanish.-The dosage of fun when you play either campaign , or single/multiplayer has much more improved than previous ones.-Graphics , textures , buildings has been improved to fit a realistic standards without damaging the purpose of the game.-Choices choices choices , well you get to do more things in this one , so u get to have everything in old tropicos with bounses. BUT HOW COME THEY FORGOT TO ADD PRISONS !!!!??? -Resources variation has been increased , also manufactoring system has been improved , to better.in other words , if this is the first time you play tropico , you will find it one of its kind between the other games in this similar genre , and if tropico 5 isn't your first experince with this title , you will enjoy the variation and upgrades that shows the effort that was put on this one. i recommend having this game either in full/discount prices 10/10.

												So far in my limited time playing, the game has been somewhat error prone with random crashes and stablity issues.  I've so far on my own traced this back to what I suspect is the game's DRM ( which is just goofy considering this is a steam game ).Waiting to see if they can figure out what's wrong with the game and go from there.  I spent money on this game so I hope to get some entertainment on it and I haven't written it off just yet... but I figured anyone who hasn't purchased it yet should keep in mind that this doesn't feel like a stable product.Update:I went back and forth with support to try and figure out what was going wrong.  After switching off all video card performance settings, checking my hardware for a bad cooling fan, etc... I kind of got the game running for a little bit before it crashed again.If you liked Tropico 4, this feels like a Tropico 4 DLC with some changes here and there.  Unfortunately I didn't get very far into the game due to stability problems ( I have no problems running various other games so I don't know what to think ).

												It's okay. I bought it for 30$ on sale, and haven't got my money's worth out of it. DLC is crap, gameplay is fine. It has about 2 sandbox games worth of VO content that tends to be very amusing. Cities all feel the same in the late game though, and there tends to be a "correct" way to play, which doesn't gel well with me. A lot of systems are odd. It's almost great. A few alternate building models, some buildings dedicated to avoiding natural disasters, some more interesting mechanics for trafic and roads and pollution, and it would be a different, awesome game. As is, and knowing what I do now, I wouldn't buy it for more than 15 dollars.Suitably amusing.

content:
25, 2015
												If you like city building strategy management games, or Age of Empires/Mythology - Tropico 5 is top notch.The missions are fun and some can be a challenge. I have wasted a few hours here and there on failed missions, but that doesn't take away from the enjoyment of the game.Unlike others I have played, you are not restricted in where or how placing specific buildings. Obviously there are a couple of rules that need to be followed to maximise efficiency, but you're are pretty much left alone to build what you like where you like. The game is very deep and if you love micro management, comedy politics, trade and resource production then this game really is for you.The only thing that bugs me a little is the camera control or lack of. Otherwise this is a solid game and I strongly recommend it if you like your strategy management games.
