content:
, 2014
												This  game is pretty good, it has everything that tropico 4 has and more even! The era system really gives players a fresh new feeling everytime they move through from an era to another. Buildings can be unlocked by advancing through era's, and also through technology research, like researching the shovel will allow you to build mines. The humor still looms well and fun just like tropico 4, penultimo is still in the campaign, helping you rule and get through the missions. He still makes jokes like he should, and there are many more characters that will help you out or just annoy you, the campaign also has a nice new story added to it, try out the campaign! Really, it's very interesting and personally, i liked the story. If you're not here for the laugh, then the in game city building system will sure to attract you if you're a kind of person that likes to build a buzzling metropolis from an island. This game is for you, every person that lives in your country will have an impact to your rule, because that individual can be a crime lord that will promote crime, a rebel, or a very educated person that work on buildings that normal people arn't qualified for! The new biggest difference that this game is from tropico 4 is that it has a new military system, it now has tanks and aircraft carriers. And soldiers now fight in squads, which makes it a little more realistic than it's predecessor. Although combat will feel very limiting as you are not commanding the squad like how an rts should be, instead it's pretty much a auto fight where squads will only defend one single building and you can't move them anywhere else but only "retreat" to another building and defend another spot. The team which the most soldier's or more superior men are more likely to win. And last but not least, the new multiplayer system! With the combat system, you can fight other players, like attacking infrastracture, military buildings,etc. But that's all really, you can't personally command them to move to a specific location or even target a building of your will. And that's a downpart, but really, this is quite innovative for a city building game. You must race against your rivals for techonogies, money and military, you can form an alliance with one of your rivals, or war with another. This is all good but there is another major flaw that the game has, server issues, and oooooh, it takes quite a long time to find a proper game before you can begin. They must fix this! I waited for 20 minute for the autosearch match and i got nothing! searching for custom game is also a dread. But from what i know, they are still fixing the problem, i have faith in them! In conclusion, i'll give this game a 7.5/10, It offers a brand new experience for both new and old players of tropico. There are many new buildings, edicts and factions that players will have to look out for. Multiplayer is fun! When is works, and the new military system on the multiplayer will help keep players active on military achivements. I will recommend this to my friends and city building adicts. If you're not a fan of city building games, don't get this, but if you are, join us in tropico 5!

content:
, 2014
												First off: I did not even touch the multiplayer part, so I am not going to comment on that. From what I have heard, it does not run all too well, so I guess I am not missing out on any possibly redeeming aspect. I am a long-time fan of the Tropico franchise and had a lot of fun with 3 and 4.Tropico 5 introduces some interesting new mechanics, which sounded cool at first:For example, there is the ability to fight. Disappointingly, this boils down to building some Barracks, Army Bases and other Military sites, since you cannot really control anything significant during an invasion of your island. Your soldiers move out automatically (following the same annoying pathing that also causes Teamster's Office hickups), the only thing you can specify are priorities (works just as fine as with Construction Offices - for which I would have to be in a super-sarcastic mood to call it good).Then, there is a tech-tree which you can research subsequently using research points generated by various buildings (Libraries, Colleges, you get the idea). The main flaw in tech-progression probably is the fact that you get your hands on most interesting things rather late in the game (but at that point at an incredibly high rate). Have an airport? Well, that's cool, some minutes later, you will be able to build a luxory version of aforementioned.You can destine managers to your production facilities in order to boost efficiency or grant other boni to the laborforce and or building's vicinity. As far as I understand, these managers don't level up (even though a star rating is visible for all of them), unless they are one of your heirs (which you can upgrade spending money from your swiss bank account). However, character progression is not as fun as in e.g. Tropico 3, since the traits are kept very basic in Tropico 5.I have never seen Tropico as a hard-core simulation but rather a feel-good game. Earlier titles did achieve exactly that. Tropico 5, however, does not. Not only because the additions in terms of gameplay mechanics neither feel well thought out nor turn out to be interesting in any way. It is more, because the current iteration offers little to no feedback. Also the prequels did not show all too detailed information on what's wrong or doing well on your island, but this time, the lack of feedback reaches an annoyingly high level: Imagine, you are on a campaign mission, trying to accomplish a specific task when an election comes up. No problem, you think, my supporters greatly outnumber the critics. 1-2 months in the election phase, your ratings suddenly drop from ~60% to 45% - time to act! Opening the score overview, you however notice that all your ratings are well above 50% - too bad, so take a trip into the blue and build a Cathedral, a Hospital and some Entertainment buildings (all that using "quick construct" and taking a money penalty scaling with the building's cost, since Tropicans are still utterly incompetent when it comes to building stuff). "Phew" - you tell yourself, seeing the rating passing the magic 50% threshold again. 1 month before election, Autosave hits. Afterwards you are told that only 49% voted for you.Would this have happend just once playing the career, I would not bother. But things like that keep happening constantly. Even if your island's economy florishes, you provide food through numerous supermarkets, keep crime rates low using police stations, reduce polution,... Problems only rarely amount from a lack of money (you usually have access to some very lucrative products at any point in time, and at a surplus once you reach cold war ages). They result from poor feedback: If you check a police station, an overlay shows you current crime rates. Waste disposal sites show you polution. Religious buildings _do not_ show saturation, neither do supermarkets or hospitals. Then again, Newsstations show a "Liberty"-overlay - is that what you would call consistency? I wouldn't....And then, there is bugs. Your game will crash, your game will freeze. Just now, trying to finish the campaign, the game froze, killing the entire progress of that particular mission. Not, that it happens often, but considering other annoyances, this is the tip of the iceberg.Bottom line: It plays like 3 or 4. It looks a little better than 3 or 4. The music is still nice. The game provides even less feedback than the predecessors. The gameplay additions are not worth it. The campaign is comparably boring. The early ages evolve incredibly slow. Just too many flaws to keep the constant "holiday"-feeling up.

content:
8, 2015
												The game is very similar to tropico 4. The gameplay is streamlined and simplistic, even moreso than its predecessors, and this somewhat detracts from its depth of gameplay. It is, however, intuitive and obvious to pick up and play. The only major fault I've seen are the bugs. Roads will get jammed, industry buildings will fail to produce, and several other buildings will sporadically fail to function properly - despite flawless planning. As the game has been out for over a year, I find the lack of bug fixes to be somewhat offputting, especially when you note the massive ammount of DLC there is. If it weren't for the sporadic bugs I'd give this game a 9/10; when it works, it's a fun and intuitive game. However the bugs can really make the game unplayable. If you don't feel like fighting a losing battle against glitches on 1/2 your play experiences, you might want to skip this title. Otherwise, it's well worth the $9.99 75% off sale price!

content:
y 3, 2016
												Such a fun but horribly flawed city builder.  I spent the time I have in this game developing my island into a democratic, high liberty, and manufacturing mega plex. Single player only review.Positives-You can develop your island as you see fit (manufacturing, tourist focused, agriculture power house, or any combination)-Streamlined development options for your island-Start in colonial era and work your way into the modern era-Foreign affairs with robust trade options for several other countries-Robust government management (write a constitution with various effects and issue edicts, LOTSA edicts)-Many interesting and unique buildings *IF* you purchase the DLCs (I got them all for .99 during holiday sales)-Military options and invasions (see negatives)-Great graphics, entertaining voice acting, good cha-cha music, humurousNegatives-Poor implementation of the military aspect (if you are going to implement something do it right). Poor pathfinding, very little or no control over military units-Rebels everywhere! No matter what you do you are going to ♥♥♥♥ some faction off and they will attack frequently.  It doesnt matter how nice your island is. It dfoesnt matter how free your government is.  It also doesnt matter if you have a 95% happiness rating. It doesnt matter if everyone is filthy rich and living in a mansion.  You WILL get attacked by rebels.-Strange citizen behavior.  Example: Your filthy rich bankers will erect a shacks below a luxury high rise.  This happens often and is very annoying.  Example:  You have guys and gals that just wont get a job no matter how many open jobs there are.  Then these citizens get mad b/c of no work and join the rebels! Example: Your citizens choose to  live in a shack rather than commute to thier job site (even with mass transit available)!-'Cha-Ching' DLC policy by Kalypso (this is nothing new)Overall a fun as hell game with a few annoyances.  Would definately recommend if you are into an interesting city builder where you dont want to worry about micro managing things.  Rating: 80% FUN! 20% Aggrivation with a dash of ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off thrown in.

content:
4
												Not a Fan. I played through the main senario but by the end I was just hoping that it would be over. The game get tedious pretty quick and i've only started one or two games since then just becuase of the annoyance factor. They included mini-quests like on phone games and the quests are pretty stupid and arbitrary, often out of line with what the island needs or can support. Not doing them is immediately detrimental your relations with the faction the proposed them, but also the citizens happiness. It's not a gradual thing like in 4 where you could refuse some and do others or refuse them all if you'd met the factions other island requirments. In five you better do all the mini-quests or else. For a dictator you end up with very little agency.Like everybody says the almanac sucks and people hate you for no good reason. I once was diposed by uprising on an island where 91% apporoved of me and were happy. I have no idea what happened but more than a third of my population suddenly rebelled. Just... what?The detail that went to into each citicen was cool, but it's awkward to access, not like in the previous games where it was fun to click on people while you were piding your down time.The tech tree was an interesting idea, but you end up always getting them, making it inevitable, rather than fun. There's also only one way to progress so once you've got some science you can ignore it (unless there's a mini-quest). I would have been better if espionage or tech buying from dipolmatic chanels was a thing. Or if you lost opertunities for not getting them.I'm also not a fan of removing the time limit as an end of game point. Most of the other ones I hit really early, but leaving it open ended is dull.Which is a good word to describe Tropico 5, dull.

												Being Latin myself, I felt at home in this game. The music makes me want to play topless in my swimming shorts holding a cocktail even though I live in wild, wet & windy Britain. The gameplay is very good. The irony & comedy is very well done, Pythonesque even. HOWEVER, the multiplayer still has issues. Issues you thought would have been solved by now . . . but no. DLC is more important than a fully working & fully optimised base game. The game is a bit of a parallel to the latin dictatorships it aims to emulate. It comes out & may seem to be good & beneficial but ends up screwing you over for its own personal interests. We may need a computer game developer version of Che Guevara to finally get these problems solved.

content:
9, 2016
												(Note my comments are strictly holding to the base game.  I have not played a single expac/dlc.)  T4 just felt like a more compelling and engaging product.  Managing the army felt better, and also playing the tourism side felt more interesting.  The Campaign for 4 definitely felt superior too.  5 has some improvements: less guess work with construction, and I like managing the plantations/ranches in 5 (unless you are talking hydroponic farms.  Really Calypso?  High school graduates?!  You don't think that doesn't totally bork your game?)  but I do miss running the prison farms from 4.  In short, I may remember a few small details wrong because it's been years since I played 4, but I do remember being super satisfied with my experience with 4.  Not quite with 5.  I liked it enough, but I wouldn't recommend it. Oh and Calypso, after playing Prison Architect, the only way you are getting me to buy the eventual T6 is if you provide  a layout mode.  Guessing, placing, cancelling construction, replacing, maybe cancelling again, etc. until i get the building placement perfect (I hope) for my future plans is something we need to get passed.  Presidente' has access to paper and pencil.  It is well within his/her capabilities to plan ahead.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 7, 2014
												I can't recommend this title, despite it being somewhat enjoyable to play. The cheeky story and humor are there, but, if you're looking for an experience as deep and challenging as Tropico 4, you will be disappointed.Unfortunately, as with many games of recent issue, this game suffers from dumbing down for console play. Lots of things that experienced Tropico players know and rely on to really add depth to the game are gone. The most useful overlays, such as occupancy, profitability, employment level, newspaper, television, and rado station types... all gone in favor of being able to play the game on limited hardware with just a few buttons. In fact, radio stations are gone altogether. You cannot directly set wages at buildings anymore, in favor of a "budget" system that supposedly sets wages, but in reality allows you NO control over wages to properly prioritize your economy. Rents and entry fees on homes and service buildings also gone, in favor of a simple button saying "Tourists Only". You can see these glaring oversimplifications everywhere you turn.The campaign is far too easy, and I was able to complete it in about 20 hours with no failures, really. The dynasty system seems pointless and can be ignored without affecting gameplay in any way. In short, Tropico 5 is to Tropico 4 as the Texas flag is to the US flag... a dumbed down, easy reader version of the original.Also, I got the "Big Cheese" DLC as part of my pre-order for free, and this is a good thing, because I would have been really upset if I had paid for it. All it adds is a singlee building, the creamery, and ONE, count em ONE mission... which is 100% more missions than the game came with outside the original campaign.Look, I'm not a console player. I don't like console games, because I prefer something a bit deeper. That said, there are some console-type titles I have enjoyed and do enjoy playing. If this is the future of the game industry, then there are some pretty dark times ahead. I'll be putting this back on the shelf and playing user content in T4 instead.

Guessing, placing, cancelling construction, replacing, maybe cancelling again, etc. until i get the building placement perfect (I hope) for my future plans is something we need to get passed.  Presidente' has access to paper and pencil.  It is well within his/her capabilities to plan ahead.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 7, 2014
												I can't recommend this title, despite it being somewhat enjoyable to play. The cheeky story and humor are there, but, if you're looking for an experience as deep and challenging as Tropico 4, you will be disappointed.Unfortunately, as with many games of recent issue, this game suffers from dumbing down for console play. Lots of things that experienced Tropico players know and rely on to really add depth to the game are gone. The most useful overlays, such as occupancy, profitability, employment level, newspaper, television, and rado station types... all gone in favor of being able to play the game on limited hardware with just a few buttons. In fact, radio stations are gone altogether. You cannot directly set wages at buildings anymore, in favor of a "budget" system that supposedly sets wages, but in reality allows you NO control over wages to properly prioritize your economy. Rents and entry fees on homes and service buildings also gone, in favor of a simple button saying "Tourists Only". You can see these glaring oversimplifications everywhere you turn.The campaign is far too easy, and I was able to complete it in about 20 hours with no failures, really. The dynasty system seems pointless and can be ignored without affecting gameplay in any way. In short, Tropico 5 is to Tropico 4 as the Texas flag is to the US flag... a dumbed down, easy reader version of the original.Also, I got the "Big Cheese" DLC as part of my pre-order for free, and this is a good thing, because I would have been really upset if I had paid for it. All it adds is a singlee building, the creamery, and ONE, count em ONE mission... which is 100% more missions than the game came with outside the original campaign.Look, I'm not a console player. I don't like console games, because I prefer something a bit deeper. That said, there are some console-type titles I have enjoyed and do enjoy playing. If this is the future of the game industry, then there are some pretty dark times ahead. I'll be putting this back on the shelf and playing user content in T4 instead.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												This was one of the games I was most excited for this year. I have been a fan of tropico for a while and have played 114 hours of tropico 4. I pre ordered this and was very happy when it was released a few hours early!However, I was a bit disappointed by the game; it wasn't exactly what I expected.What I didn't like:When I first started I noticed I didn't quite like the HUD. First, the building menu isn't really what I like; You should only be able to see buildings you can build in your era. I also liked the tropico 4 building menu better (where it starts with you picking what category of building you want). Building HUD isn't really greaet either. There are tabs that are a bit confusing, and you don't really see what you want to see.In tropico 4, you could zoom ALL the way in and see each citizen, piece of trash, or crop, whereas in 5 you can barely zoom in at all. I like to see my little peoples and cars zooming around, but you can't do that as well in 5.What I also liked about 4 was the fact that you feel so CONNECTED with your citizens: you actually click seperate citizens walking around (i know you can in 5 but I dont feel compelled to) and look at their job, education, age, whatever and look at what they need. I want to actually look through my people and feel like they are real not just look in the happiness section at what they need. And the happiness section is another issue..I really don't like the happiness section. You are CONSTANTLY having to build new buildings, even though you have NO workers to work them. I am at 887 population, with only 47 happiness because I have no more workers to increase the entertainment or food quality or anything. My happiness went from 82% to 47% in only 1 year even though I didn't destroy any happiness increasing buildings or introduce anything that could have decreased it. Still not even sure why it went down, my population didn't increase all too much.I've also had a few graphics glitches. Whenever I load a game, my camera is facing down like a top-down game. trying to reangle it makes it zoom, and it doesn't fix until I spaz the mouse around and maybe press a few buttons. Then, while playing today, my minimap randomly had a square of inverted colors right where my city was. I have no idea what caused that one and it didn't go away since I played. Checking out of screenshots will show the glitchesI do not like how you can't customize rent, pay, or fee in this one. Rent and pay are both confusing in how they work.What I like:I like how the voting system is actually difficult. In tropico 4, all you had to do was not have happiness at like 0%, otherwise you always win by like 90%. In this game, you have to work hard in the beginning to win the elections (unless you cheat!).I like how there are lots of buildings!Combat, combat, combat. tropico 4 combat was simple and lacking. THIS combat is epic! No other word. Axis tanks and infantry storming your beach while your own tanks are firing at them is about the coolest thing you can imagine in a tropico game. You no longer automatically lose when you are invaded, you have a fighting chase.So in all and all I thought it was 4/10. If they were to update it, I will of course change my review! I will also continue playing and see if I change my mind at all.

content:
18, 2014
												Honestly, I was just expecting more from this release. I completely finished the campaign of Tropico 4 and love the hell out of it, but I feel like this game was built on the same engine. They reuse the same animations and camera angles from Tropico 4 for a ton of things that happen regularly, like tsunamis. The game doesn't look noticeably better than Tropico 4, and there aren't really even many new building types. The only new additions are a research tree which is ultimately a waste of time because it doesn't give you meaningful upgrades, the ability to apply managers to buildings based on certain traits (it's a really passive thing), and what else, the islands stay the same from level to level? Both of them. Furthermore, the game runs sort of poorly. All in all, if you can get this for cheap and haven't played the previous entries to death already, go for it. Otherwise, save your money and your time.

content:
r 26, 2014
												Ach... what have they done.Tropico  has always been funny, charming and clever. Tropico 4 had all of this in abundance, and what kept me coming back was the immersion it created. I really was El Presidente, and it was a blast toying around with all the options open to me, regardless of the shallow simulation and lack of viable options for all types of dictatorship.Tropico 5 however, is dull (dare I say embarassingly unfunny) , lacks all the charm infused into it's predecessors (the representations of El Prez, his staff  and his family are devoid of any personality or wit), and all the clever political satire that kicked in everywhich direction (right or left, east or west, rich or poor, everyone got the finger of ridicule pointed straight at the flaws in their propaganda) has been stripped away.What you are left with is a shallow simulation with limited options and poor gameplay. You'll be tabbing back out to your games library before you reach the third era in your very first playthrough, looking for something, anything. Because surely there is better entertainment to be had elwewhere.Buy Tropico 4 instead, or else ...

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												Manage a vaguely Caribbean island, starting with cash crops, mining, and shacks, and build your way up to lucrative manufactured goods, tourism, and skyscraper apartment buildings. Along the way, try to satisfy the needs of your people to keep them happy enough that they won't overthrow you. If you fail at that, or anger a major country too much, there's always your military!Though fun to play, Tropico 5 has a lot of problems. It refuses to load the second campaign scenario for me, and victory conditions in sandbox mode just outright don't fire. These issues, along with other technical and game design problems, detract from the overall experience enough that I would recommend holding off until the developers release a major patch.While the writing maintains the same quirky Cold War/dystopian flavor as previous entries in the series, it lacks the same punch as Tropico 4 had. The cast of characters, one of Tropico 4's strongest points, has been gutted. The new characters just don't have the same cartoony faction personalities, and don't offer anything new or different to make up for it.All that aside, you still get to build and manage resource/manufacturing enterprises, distribute wealth as you see fit, enact edicts and constitutional amendments to define the nature of your dictatorship, and set up tourist traps to rake in the tourism cash. Those parts are a lot of fun, and give you a lot of freedom to develop your island however you want to, whether that means a nation of happy, healthy citizens who gratefully vote to renew your mandate, or oppressed factory workers who endure squalor, surveillance,  and sub-par wages in order to maximize your Swiss bank account.Speaking of the Swiss bank account, the dynasty system is an interesting new take on player avatars. The perks from leveling and deploying dynasty members are nice, but I'm mostly grateful that they give the Swiss bank account a purpose other than "because that's the kind of thing El Presidente does."Still, it would be so very nice if I didn't have to fight the UI to find exactly the right corner pixel to click in order to close a building info pop-up.

Unfortunately, Tropico 5's DLC is falling far short from the family tree, but that's another review entirely. A must have for Tropico fans.

												Amazing gameplay, amazing progression; unfortunately big crippling bugs prevent this game from being an actual game. I would consider this on par with other early access titles except I had to pay $40 for it. From really stupid things like not being able to bind WASD to camera, or not being able to use mouse wheel zoom when placing buildings, you can't help but shake your head at how they missed such obvious things.If you are buying this for multiplayer you will be dissapointed. There is no way to change the gameplay speed settings, so you are stuck on fastforward. There is no save feature AT ALL in multiplayer, which goes well with the frequent crashes that will ruin your game. This game will make you mad because there are is a lot of stuff here that is really good, you will want to play it but the game will make sure you can't.

												While it is by no means bad, I feel that this game is a lesser version of its predecessor, lacking a certain depth and variety that Tropico 4 enjoyed. The addition of a 'snap-to' grid that allows for easier building placement is welcome, but with so fewer buildings available, my cities are just never as vibrant as before. The changing of eras throughout the missions is nice, but no replacement for the genuine humour and excellent voice-talent that is sadly absent.Even the soundtrack lacks the panache that was present in Tropico 4. It's still a competent, enjoyable city-builder that's worth a play if you're new to the series, but even then, you'd be better served by picking up one of it's predecessors, much more cheaply.

												This is in my opinion the best version of Tropico. Many people complain that there are not so much statistics, and infos are missing. They are not. Even the famous "empty buildings" statistic is there. The only things which are missing are the first person view and the speeches before the elections. But these few things that are missing can't compare to the things which are added. Four epoches, many more buildings in total, new units and finally some suspense. The best features are the slightly harder difficulty and the controller support, trade missions, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, colony status at the beginning, more fights (which are by no means the center of the game, but it's better than the games before when nearly no one was attacking you). The graphics are nice, the music is great as ever and the humor is always there.A really nice game to relax, to shape your town, to do mad or bad or good things, listen to caribean music and watch your people embrassing their beloved leader (or trying to kill him).

content:

												- Voice actors are worse than 3 and 4, especially Penultimo- Character variety, faction leaders typecasting and funny plotlines are less than other games- Actually, in general the game has lost its funny and sarcastic nature compared to old games- Only 2 maps for campaign and you continue next missions where you left off.  This seemed to be a good feature at first but after four or five mission it's getting annoying- New trade system is frustrating and complicated.- Constitutions change nothing, there were still religious tasks/demands/protests/riots even though i proclaimed "atheist nation"-Campaign scenario is weird, Every new mission starts at Colonial Era no matter how far the date progress on previous mission. But plot, buildings and character interactions stay chronogical. This is a very stupid thing.- Zoom-in is restricted to about 4-5 meter top down view and you can't see the Tropicans closely or even El Presidente.- By the way There's no controlling El Presidente anymore- I didn't like the new radio host. She is not funny and don't compatible with events that happen on island.- El Presidente customization is barren, you can't even customize your first name. Wt* actually?To make the long story short; Tropico 5 is a big disaster and fail. Absolutely not recommend it, buy 3 - 4 or both instead.

content:
22, 2014
												Bad enough to prompt me to write this review. Stats that are no longer linked and missions that have nothing to do with your island. "New Steel Mill" when I have no coal mines - it's too god damn expensive to import coal to make it worth it. Rebellion every 5 minutes even though my Almanac consistently says 0 Rebels on the island. "Budget" is a confusing mess of dollar symbols.Do NOT spend your money here, Kalypso does not deserve it this time. See the comments too.I have played for more than 100 hours at the writing of this final piece. Tropico 5 is a badly designed, badly implemented, really pretty version of Tropico 4 that was made for ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ in diapers who have never played a city builder and need hand holding to the max. Replayability: 0. Expect the SAME THING every time. Put it on a higher difficulty? Don't expect it to be logical or even challenging in a humorous way like T4 was, it will just be a BIG WASTE OF YOUR TIME AND MONEY. Campaign? Oh, play the same 2 islands that will get bugged out and impossible to play the campaign if you try to do anything other than what your hand holder tells you. Multiplayer? Don't waste your time, the rest of the game is terrible. One way stat progression, one way tech trees, mines and mines of useful information that is buried 15 layers deep in the game, time-flow corruption (i.e: your trade ship says it will be here in 6 months, the election doesnt happen for 8 months. Somehow you lose the election before your trade ship gets back to dock.) Not to mention it's so god damn FAST. By the time you have researched "power plant" in the world war era, its already time to advance to the cold war and you are in massive debt from trying to keep up with the tech tree! Economy is BROKEN BROKEN BROKEN on any higher level difficulties, with or without trade it is nigh impossible not to go into debt while trying to keep ANY factions or people over 50% happiness, let alone one at a time. Disasters want to feel like they are broken but really some noob game dev at Kalypso decided it would be a "good" game addition for disasters to break everything all the time. Don't even get me started on the TERRIBLE voice acting and the ATROCIOUS sound effects, as well as the three whole songs that loop on repeat OVER AND OVER AND OVER AND OVER.PLEASE DO NOT WASTE YOUR MONEY HERE. Kalypso has made some good gems and a lot of terrible trash. This game is terrible trash with faux gems hot glued all over it.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
2015
												If you love City Building Games then I highly and most certainly recommend this game for sure. It is by far the most interesting and tedious city builder there is to date which covers a lot of ground to keep you busy and reeled in for hours on end.There are only two major complaints I still have about this game - read why below.1 - The Multiplayer was horrible at first and because of that the game got a really bad wrap from the get go so players stopped playing it online due to the issues it originally had. On a positive note most of those problems were fixed and it does work very well online now. However, due to that bad start it may be hard to play it online unless you go to the community or get a friend to join you.2 - One of my biggest problems that I have always had with this game with each of it's following game sequences is that the buildings are way too repetitive as in all of the building types are the exact same. So once you get further into the game you'll notice that you have lots of areas with houses and buildings but they all look exactly alike with absolutely no variance whatsoever. I have repeatedly complained to them about this in every series and nothing has been done and I doubt now that it will ever change either unless a ton of people start to do the same. One thing though that does make it a little better is the different building types and the added buildings from the dlc but still if you have a bunch of houses and similar buildings you will notice that and it may become an annoyance. If you can look past that then you'll enjoy it! On top of that the Eras also do help aid with that in changing the look of several types of buildings after upgrades have occurred from advancing in time but many do not such as housing unfortunately.Anyhow though, aside from those two issues it is still an epic game and I definitely think it's worth the price in full but if you'd rather wait for a sale then I would certainly recommend grabbing it for sure to say the least!

content:
r 8, 2015
												Tropico has always been a favorite of mine since the initial release but the trend of this series is becoming a money grab and they are starting to mess with the game mechanics too (they release more game mechanics through DLC) So the core game itself is pretty streamlined with basic buildings, not too many options in each category. You cannot see the building upgrades make an impact on the appearance anymore. Its very stripped down, prepped for DLC unfortunately. The limited options you have with buildings make "less" impact than they used to. You no longer see people visit entertainment locations. Previously, you built more entertainment buildings if they were becoming overcrowded but thats not the case anymore, less control or micro managing which takes away from an economy style game. After reading some of the bigger DLC packs, many players have complained that some of the game mechanics should have been in the core game and the DLCs offer more player strategic options. Why am I rating this down? Its because it costs $120 for everything this game has to offer. If your a fan, pick up an older title on sale with all the DLC, it will be much more rewarding than buying just the core copy. Its a great game but their model needs to change.

content:
r 10, 2015
												I haven't played the older Tropico games, so I don't really have any preconceived notions about how this game should be. The game is beautiful. Lovely graphics, and the user interface if fairly intuitive and easy to use. And it runs on Linux, which is a HUGE plus.My biggest grief is what appears to be inconsistencies in the economics. I have homeless and unemployed citizens. I build a library, I build houses, and the library sits there empty because no one will work there. The houses sit empty while the peasants build shacks round it. I build a ranch so my idle workers have a job and are producing something that you can consume and/or sell, and now I'm loosing money hand over fist. I demolish the ranch, my citizen homeless rate goes up, content goes down, but now I'm making money again. I've watched my treasury bleed away into the negative, I'm loosing money fast, and nothing I do stops it. I build docks, ranches, mines, farms. I build housing. I increase budget on buildings and ranches and farms. I give them a bar, churches, libraries, clinics, etc. Nothing I do stops the money loss.I finally discovered two secrets to making money: 1) Don't build anything. Just sit there with the bare basic town, only build what you are told to as part of a task, add a few docs, and you make money. You start expanding with ranches, plantations, industry, etc., and no matter what you do you start loosing money.2) Set economic difficulty to the lowest setting. NOW you can play and enjoy the game without going bankrupt in 30 minutes or less!And you might as well get used to your people hating you. I finally figure out how to get my approval rating up to 50% so I can declare independence and not loose elections, but what you have to do to get there is not always obvious.I don't recommend this game because of the frustration level involved with  just trying to survive. There comes a point where it just isn't fun anymore.

content:
20, 2015
												Ever want to be a leader of your own nation? With it's own set of rules, laws, and regulations? plus the ideological factor that drives your nation so? Then this game is for you!I had a blast while playing this game and you will too! There is a lot to do in this game, which can make time fly fast which is nice. Like in Sid Meier's Civilzation V you have to keep an eye out on your happiness, and your production level! Too litte, and your nation will starve of resources and rebel against you, Too much, and you will have constant invasions by the outside world. You need to find the right balance, plus make sure you choose your edicts wisely, pick the wrong ones too early and you will be at a disadvantage, pick the right ones in the right point in time might just help in your favor, or not depending upon whether or not you choose to upgrade your armies and defenses.You can 'customize' your dictator, with outfits, looks, first name and last name. However, the first name is randomly generated so that's the downside to that. Plus you can upgrade your 'dynasty' members to be better, which is highly advise. Another downside is that it's not like Crusaders Kings where you can marry someone and have a child, it's randomly generated with a look, and the only thing you can customize is the outfit itself.The locations are very well done, each island offers a unqiue spin on how you want to build your nation. If you pick a tiny island you have limited resources to build your country, If you have a huge island you have endless opportunity to build whatever it is you want to build. Like real life you must geographical plan out where you put your buildings and roads, plus your defenses and what not. The last you want is have a full fledge invasion, and your military defenses is sub-par, plus your guard tower locations are out of whack.The music in this game while it's fun to listen too, It can get a bit repetitive so becareful there. I am honestly surprised there is no mod workshop for this game, i can see the potential in what kind of mods this game can produce. Lastly, the achievements are easy to earn. And the tutorial is really simple and easy to understand.If you want in-depth nation building then this game is for you. Recommend!

content:
22, 2014
												Really funny city simulator.The campaign is solid and its objectives are really nice.There are several different (and all valid) options to get fast cash, from farms to factories, from tourism to offices.In this game you are the people manager, for real - not only the buildings positioner -, you need to understand how many educated citizen you have (high school and university), how many not educated, and how your economic development choices will impact on the high school / not educated ratio - for example a farm based economy just needs not educated ppl / a offices based economy needs all ppl from university. Besides the education the population is sorted by age, wealth and preferences, since the population is divided in factions, often asking the opposites, like nationalists vs globalists. During my almost 40 hours play-through I experimented several different economies and I had fun with them all, which is the most important thing to me.To succeed you have to find the right balances between multiple contemporary conditions, all spiced up by random disasters and the various rebellions / invasions.Suggesting the game, my personal score is 8/10

content:
1, 2014



YouTube™ Video: Tropico 5 - Sandbox Play Through Each Age 

			Views: 74		

			I present to you, Tropico 5! This is a great development of the series. A common complaint for Tropico 4 was that it was too much like Tropico 3, so this is the answer for those that wanted something...		

Tropico 5 is a great development of the series. A common complaint for Tropico 4 was that it was too much like Tropico 3, so this is the answer for those that wanted something different. Luckily they didn't change anything about the game that made the previous ones so great. I recorded this video with no music, because sadly Youtube griefs me anytime I've done that for any Tropico game... so the video is a bit lacking. Just play some Hispanic music in the background and you'll be all set.The age system is the biggest difference in this iteration of the game, other than perhaps multiplayer, and although it is a valiant effort... it becomes tedious after progressing through it a few times.  It works ok for the story mode, but the best part about the age system is that it can essentially be turned off during sandbox games by setting the starting era to Modern Times. Multiplayer looks good... but I haven't played enough to really get a feel for it yet. The best change to Tropico 5 is the Dynasty system. Building your dynasty is fun, and finally gives you a reason to have a fat stack of cash in your slush fund. So all in all, I'm really happy with the game. I sometimes miss the simplicity of the older games, mainly because of the addition of the age system, but the Tropico series is still my favorite city builder, and I expect to play Tropico 5 for many, many more hours to come.

r 11, 2014
												In terms of the options available to build your city, Tropico 5 fares worse than the previous versions. First, there is that fact that you have to alternate between two islands that keep the previous developments (i.e. you keep the same two islands for the duration of different stages in the campaign). Second, the various industries follow a timeline (e.g. the tourism industry is not unlocked until you reach Cold War era, if I'm not mistaken). These two factors basically force your island to develop on a specific path. Natural resources (logging and mining) to light industry to heavy industry or tourism then advanced stages of the industry and toursim. This makes logical sense in the real world but this is a video game. It doesn't have to make sense. It would have been better to letter the player develop the island anyway they wanted from the beginning.I still recommend just because I am a fan of the previous Tropicos 3 & 4.

												Although I was a big fan of Tropico 4, I can not in good faith recommend Tropico 5. Massive chunks of content were taken out from the previous game. What little has been added is sort of a "one step forward, two steps back" scenario. While the constitution and era mechanics are nice, it doesn't make up for the fact that most buildings were taken out. Not only that, but several GUI elements have been removed entirely, like being able to see the monetary balance of specific buildings and being able to see population maps. There are even fewer political factions as well. Just about everything in Tropico 5 is a downgrade, and it's a real shame because I was rather excited for it. All in all, you can probably squeeze a few hours out of this game, but I'd recommend getting Tropico 4 instead. 4/10

content:
, 2014
												Went ahead and familiarized myself with the tutorial levels to what new has been added to this already excellent game series; and I have to say, Kalypso has outdone themselves. The engine is smooth, AI works more accordingly, changes to buildings such as updgrades and expanded timelines with technology research has made the next piece in the Tropico anthology an obvious gem.The reactions from foreign powers and consequences against your little island paradise are vast and far reaching. Random events and disasters are far more balanced; and politics and trade are a bit more in depth, giving players a chance to either maximize profit or be able to work up foreign relations through trade.Most notable in the Tropico game series, is implementing different era's for your island to push through with a new technology tree, allowing one to progress in numerous paths when deciding there tropical paradises fate.For any looking for an excellent city building simuation, Tropico 5 is worth the price-tag.Edit: Update on gameplay:So I get to a population of about 2,500 and things are looking good not only financially but my diplomatic stances with foreign nations were all warm, if not neutral. However there was discontent brewing over the past decade, the nationalists were becoming increasingly vocal and taking up arms in small rebel actions against my regime. I began noticing arresting rebels belonged to a mixture of the nationalists and environmentalists. Years of an open immigration policy, immigrants on almost every boat to port for the past couple years. Then recently I managed to receive 60 Chinese immigrants.Immediatly rebel action began to scale up with a series of attacks on my cash crop farms, and they were succeeding with every other attack. I chose to put my foot down and lure the rebels numerous times, thinning there ranks and arresting identified rebels. But of course I had many citizens who were very loyal, I met all their desires, the militarists, globalists and capitalists were almost eating out of the palm of my hand.Well one fine morning I put the finishing touches on putting the last of identified rebels down. Moments later the uprising began. Markers began popping up everywhere as my military scattered to intercept any rebel forces. There were people fighting for my regime, but many more fighting against. I watched as my population counter suddenly dropped by fifty in mere moments. One by one guard towers fell and the mob slowly gathered together in an unstoppable show of force. My fighters bombarding the crowd to no avail, there were to many to stop now.After a drawn out battle with some few loyal forces I had left who trekked over half the island to my palace were to late as the rebels burned my personal fortress into ashes, three square blocks on fire or bombed out. The revolution was over, it wasn't even sunset yet.

												Absolutely terrible in every way. This game is one of the worst I have played in recent years. Every single game I own that I frequently play supports 4K no problem, this game only does 1440p. When you turn 4K on, it's pretending to be 4K but really it's exactly the same as 1440p. On 1440p AND 4K mode, the scroll/camera rotation rotates at least 100 times at the slightest touch. The only way to make camera rotation work is to run it on a low resolution like 1080P and turn V-sync off. However, every few minutes with v-sync off on ANY resolution will cause my screen to get visual artifacts in the middle then flash black over and over causing my graphics driver to crash and the card to over heat. I have never experienced such a faulty game since tropico 4, which right after I purchased my 4K monitor started glitching and flashing black, then corrupted all of my save files. I don't know if the developers are ignorant or incompetent, but whatever it is, they're obviously not very professional when they can't make a game without significant bugs. Will try to get a refund.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												OverviewTropico 5 is a fun, light hearted yet deep city builder game.  You can create your "El Presidente", and through the course of the game, their dynasty.  You rule over an island over various eras and need to build it up, focusing on housing, food, money making, employment, religion, healthcare, happiness, diplomacy among other things.  For fans of previous versions, Tropico 5 is more of an evolution of the series rather than a revolution.  New & Improved features (A sample)- Dynasties - Can have more members of your family, can make them managers, send them on missions or make them El Presidente- Eras - Can start from the Colonial Era, under the tyrrany of the crown, up to the Modern era. - Managers - Can now employ different kinds of managers to buildings to grant bonuses. - New buildings- Improved AI - Especially construction priorityPros: The game has a lot of depth and challenge, that gets more challenging to handle as your island grows.  Managing employment, military, production, diplomatic relations, security are just some of these.  The game has a nice, tongue in cheek humor that I like and it looks great.  A lot of the annoying AI issues in the previous version seem to be fixed.  The campaign is fun and does a good job of taking you through all the areas of the game.  Also, the Dynasty / Manager system is a nice feature allowing you to provide good bonuses to key areas / buildings. Cons: The game, like the previous one, suffers from lack of information tabs.  While it does a good job at providing the basic information you need it lacks the ability to get a more detailed look, for example, to compare production vs transport capacity, unemployment by area, free jobs by location etc.  While with practise and some manual effort you can get some of this information, it really should be provided to you in an easier way.  As such, it leads to a reactive nature, reacting to issues instead of being able to be pro-active, especially when your island grows. Summary: An evolution of the series that has fixed most of the issues from previous versions while adding some nice new features on top.  The lack of in depth analytical info is a shame and I can imagine some Tropico Vetrans might be dissapointed with the lack of new content vs previous versions.  But for those new to the series with an interest in city builders, this one comes highly recommended. Score: 8/10 - Good Solid City Builder

content:
, 2014
												A singleplayer game worth your money. Tropico 5 is a fair game for a fair price, an enjoyable Dictator simulator that while borrows many visual assets from previous games, has gameplay rebuilt from ground up. As a player who never touched campaign mode, the focus on a deep and richer sandbox mode is exactly what I wanted. Here are some ups and downs from my experience.-DON'T BUY FOR MULTIPLAYERAnyone buying Tropico 5 for multiplayer should definitely wait a long time, its a half-baked feature that may very well need an entire expansion (or two) to get right.-ALMANACThe new Almanac technically has most of the information you could get from 4, but its not very intuitive.  It takes a long itme to figure out where the important info is scurried away. Sometimes you need to scroll down, sometimes its behind an inconspicious word button. You have to explore every nook and cranny to find what you need. +DYNASTYThe Dynasty mechanic was kind of a letdown. Its an upgrade from T4, where each skill doesn't go into a massive pool, but is tied to a specific character (who can potentially die in certain circumstances.)+ERAS AND MISSION STRUCTUREThe Era system is the real game changer. If you've seen TotalBuscuit's T5 preview, you'll know the game has a very rigid, formulaic mission structure at the start, the Colonial Era. This is the most defining and brilliant of changes made to the Tropico series.These Colonial missions are guide you to very specific objectives, ignoring these usually  results in a premature ending. This is done to prevent you from falling into a routine which in prior games, would kill the fun of these games after awhile. These mission chains will seem binding, that you HAVE to do exactly what these missions tell you or fail. However, as your understanding of the game mechanics come together, you can figure out how much breathing space you have to fulfill the missions while building the Tropico you have in mind. +-COMBATCombat is all about expectations. Its no RTS. Its a little hands off, but for me personally its hard to react to changing circumstances. Your firepower comes only from three sources: guard towers, soldiers and tanks. If all of these sources of attack power are gone, you're effectively done. The most depth I've found with the system is grouping Guard Towers, so that the tankiness of the towers are complemented by consistent firepower which can kill enemy units and actually turn battles around. There should be ways to react to a bad situation, by cutting deals or accepting demands.

content:
, 2014
												I give Tropico 5 4.5 pairs of fancy El Presidente Brand Sunglasses out of 5. The other one got broke when El Presidente single handedly broke the noses of the Premier of the USSR and President of the USA with a swing of his beard. Seriously, this game gets a 4.5 out of 5. Another of the great series of city-building dictator sims that made me fall in love with city-building sims again in the first place and have a personality that makes it so few people can turn away after beginning to play with them, it delivers much of what it promises, but there's tarantulas in those crates of bananas. The first and foremost is that the voice acting has degraded, and things are less funny, than its predecessor Tropico 4. The storyline shares some mirrors to that game, ultimately, but is enjoyable despite this fact. The addition of tech research and a static continual build of your islands throughout the campaign (Which is something I greatly greatly missed in the Tropico 4 game, wishing it existed) provides a cohesive story and more believability, while keeping things humorous. Add in options like crafting your nation's constitution and it has plenty of playability, eve if your fun per minute might be lessened and ther's less commentary about your actions.Sandbox mode remains solid, especially with the addition of a random generator for islands. The multiplayer is a GREAT GREAT GREAT addition to the game, but that crate of bananas has a tarantula in it, too. What is that, you say? There is absolutely no save mode at all in it. So if you and your friends play 2 hours playing a multiplayer game? YOu'd better finish it because you won't be able to come back to it, you either have to devote a large chunk of time to it or play on small maps, in the end.Finally, there are plenty of bugs and glitches, even now, including things like the menu stuttering (at least 30 people including myself had this problem, which was because an intromovie playing in the background had horrible frame rate issues) but there are easy enough fixes of these until official fixes from Kalypso come forward.Over all? The game is a solid addition to the genre and the Tropico family. IT could have sailed higher, and it might still with DLC, but it's already far more enjoyable and far more playable for computers with lesser capabilities than its competitors in the city building genre, especially with very real trade, invasion, and competitive options in the multiplayer making an already deep game deeper.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
8, 2015
												I've only played Tropico 4 and 5 and since most people have been commenting and reviewing on the differences between the two of them, I figure I'm qualified to review this accurately.I highly enjoy Tropico 5. I find it very addicting as I'm a complex strategy player at heart and enjoy the extra content, options, and challenge it provides. I think the dynasty mechanic is pretty interesting, it helps you overall in game though it does suck you can't control it a little more, specifically the first names and skill trait your heir gets.You definitely have to use your head! This is a simulation of you being a dictator after all! ANY decision you make will typically either affect you positively or negatively. How extreme depends on previous decisions you've made like who your allies are or will be and whether or not you've taken precautions to keep social unrest down. It's a lot more scale tipping than Tropico 4 and you have to have a short learning curve to enjoy this game for what it is. It's highly political and invasion is more likely from people you ♥♥♥♥ off than Tropico 4.Overall I think it's a more realistic rendition of a dicatorship simulation. Even at "Occassional" freaking random disasters, riots, conspiracies, etc happen regularly. I love it.If you don't actually like critical thinking strategy games, rely on foreign aid like a crutch all the time, or only played Tropico series for the humor then I wouldn't recommend this to you. If you love a true leadership simulation including managing, building, arresting, bribes, banishing, political gambles, and all the little aspects that come with it or just love world history, I do recommend this game!Likes- More challenging overall- Nicer Graphics- Dynasty Members Mechanic- In Depth Import/Export Trade Mechanic- Politics Game- Love having building managers to increase overall production/job/building function!Differences | Dislikes- *BIG* Less humorous than previous Tropcios IMO. They have jokes but it's like "Ha. Ha." More than hilarous imo.- Wish I could name and pick the trait (other than the 3 provided) for my heir- Would like more outfits than currently provided for avatars (Might be future DLC)- Wish I could purchase/attract more trade ships other than building a dock per trade ship ratio.- While I like the Eras mechanic, find it a little hindering BUT NOT IMPOSSIBLE for things like tourism or imprisoning/arresting etc not able to be done earlier in the game.- There is less of a subtle teaching mechanism in Tropico 5 than 4. You pretty much trial and error play blindly until you find yourself out of a job and have to restart the game with what you've learned. I can handle it personally but it might be a turn off for other players who need a bit more guidance in a game. (Took me a while to figure out how trade works and that I could send squads to unveil the island. No instructions on that.)Tips- Save Regularly. It does autosave but since crazy ♥♥♥♥ happens in short amounts of time, you may want to change a bad outcome.- I reccommend doing a little research before playing the game. If you aren't familiar with actual world history or the game's new mechanics it will behoove you to look a few things up ahead of time like what technologies/resources and trade will be available in future eras so you can plan accordingly.- Check the trade routes before you designate farms/ranches/mines. You can profit more with something in demand.- Send out the squad from your palace to open up other areas of the island. (Costs $1000)- Don't be afraid/panic if you go into the negative in your treasury a bit. You have a -$10,000 Defincit allowance.- If you have 51% love of your people, I don't recommend doing an election if you can't improve in 12 months. I've literally lost an election like that hitting 49% by 12 months. And when in doubt if you've already agreed or suddenly lost a lot of support dont be afraid to call Martial Law to stop the election!- Always expect the unexpected.

												Great game. Definite improvements in this instalment. It still has that quirkyness that I know many have enjoyed in the previous games. The eras are a great Idea though personally I wish you didn't just jump immediately from one to the other. There should have been some sort of grace period or perhaps just have the occur naturally as the years tick by. With the later being my preference. It's harder. It's much more difficult than Tropico 4. I have yet to be able to make it out of the world wars era in one piece. I find the axis especially difficult to keep from wanting to slaughter me. I'll add more to this in the future.

content:
5, 2015
												I personally am new to the Tropico series and have heard of the complaints that this game is lazy, overpriced, doesn't improve upon the past titles, and is a DLC fiasco. I believe these arguments are probably true, but I cannot deny that I've had a lot of fun with this game. The content within the game is comparable to that of city builders like SimCity, but is quite unique with its castro style setting, including a corrupt government, constant foreign aid, and an island atmosphere. Although this may be the case for the other Tropico games, I can say that it was an enjoyable experience for me personally as a first time Tropico player. That said, I do not think that the game is worth $40 at all, and that it should certainly be bought while on sale. Also note that the game has decent graphics requirements, so don't try and play it on a scrub PC or else it won't work.

content:
, 2014
												A singleplayer game worth your money. Tropico 5 is a fair game for a fair price, an enjoyable Dictator simulator that while borrows many visual assets from previous games, has gameplay rebuilt from ground up. As a player who never touched campaign mode, the focus on a deep and richer sandbox mode is exactly what I wanted. Here are some ups and downs from my experience.-DON'T BUY FOR MULTIPLAYERAnyone buying Tropico 5 for multiplayer should definitely wait a long time, its a half-baked feature that may very well need an entire expansion (or two) to get right.-ALMANACThe new Almanac technically has most of the information you could get from 4, but its not very intuitive.  It takes a long itme to figure out where the important info is scurried away. Sometimes you need to scroll down, sometimes its behind an inconspicious word button. You have to explore every nook and cranny to find what you need. +DYNASTYThe Dynasty mechanic was kind of a letdown. Its an upgrade from T4, where each skill doesn't go into a massive pool, but is tied to a specific character (who can potentially die in certain circumstances.)+ERAS AND MISSION STRUCTUREThe Era system is the real game changer. If you've seen TotalBuscuit's T5 preview, you'll know the game has a very rigid, formulaic mission structure at the start, the Colonial Era. This is the most defining and brilliant of changes made to the Tropico series.These Colonial missions are guide you to very specific objectives, ignoring these usually  results in a premature ending. This is done to prevent you from falling into a routine which in prior games, would kill the fun of these games after awhile. These mission chains will seem binding, that you HAVE to do exactly what these missions tell you or fail. However, as your understanding of the game mechanics come together, you can figure out how much breathing space you have to fulfill the missions while building the Tropico you have in mind. +-COMBATCombat is all about expectations. Its no RTS. Its a little hands off, but for me personally its hard to react to changing circumstances. Your firepower comes only from three sources: guard towers, soldiers and tanks. If all of these sources of attack power are gone, you're effectively done. The most depth I've found with the system is grouping Guard Towers, so that the tankiness of the towers are complemented by consistent firepower which can kill enemy units and actually turn battles around. There should be ways to react to a bad situation, by cutting deals or accepting demands.

content:
, 2014
												I give Tropico 5 4.5 pairs of fancy El Presidente Brand Sunglasses out of 5. The other one got broke when El Presidente single handedly broke the noses of the Premier of the USSR and President of the USA with a swing of his beard. Seriously, this game gets a 4.5 out of 5. Another of the great series of city-building dictator sims that made me fall in love with city-building sims again in the first place and have a personality that makes it so few people can turn away after beginning to play with them, it delivers much of what it promises, but there's tarantulas in those crates of bananas. The first and foremost is that the voice acting has degraded, and things are less funny, than its predecessor Tropico 4. The storyline shares some mirrors to that game, ultimately, but is enjoyable despite this fact. The addition of tech research and a static continual build of your islands throughout the campaign (Which is something I greatly greatly missed in the Tropico 4 game, wishing it existed) provides a cohesive story and more believability, while keeping things humorous. Add in options like crafting your nation's constitution and it has plenty of playability, eve if your fun per minute might be lessened and ther's less commentary about your actions.Sandbox mode remains solid, especially with the addition of a random generator for islands. The multiplayer is a GREAT GREAT GREAT addition to the game, but that crate of bananas has a tarantula in it, too. What is that, you say? There is absolutely no save mode at all in it. So if you and your friends play 2 hours playing a multiplayer game? YOu'd better finish it because you won't be able to come back to it, you either have to devote a large chunk of time to it or play on small maps, in the end.Finally, there are plenty of bugs and glitches, even now, including things like the menu stuttering (at least 30 people including myself had this problem, which was because an intromovie playing in the background had horrible frame rate issues) but there are easy enough fixes of these until official fixes from Kalypso come forward.Over all? The game is a solid addition to the genre and the Tropico family. IT could have sailed higher, and it might still with DLC, but it's already far more enjoyable and far more playable for computers with lesser capabilities than its competitors in the city building genre, especially with very real trade, invasion, and competitive options in the multiplayer making an already deep game deeper.

You can make the choices, but there aren't really that many to make. It has some nice new ideas, but they are executed in clumsy and simplistic ways that take away from the gameplay rather than adding to it.And Tropico 4 is cheaper too.

content:
30, 2015
												Tropico 5 is a fun city builder type game. It is not the same as Sim Cities or similar games so don't expect it to be.You get to play as an oppressive dictator, what else could you want? Stalin 2.0The main difference aside from some parts of gameplay is the single player story mode which ties together a large portion of the game.You might be wondering how a city builder can have a story mode, which is exactly what I asked myself.Oddly enough it was not horrible, mildly confusing, but it brought out a lot of game play mechanics you might have otherwise avoided or missed in sandbox.I have yet to try out the multiplayer and probably wont so nothing to say there.The game play is similar to Sim Cities, but it is in no way the same. It's hard to explain, there are a lot of similarities and differences at the same time so you'll have to see for yourself.It's a fun alternative to any other city building game because you have more control over the region and less people (WHO STILL HATE YOUR GUTS) to worry about.I have not played the DLC, but from what I know it adds more story to play which is probably the only part you'll touch so you'll enjoy that and more buildings if you liked the original.8/10Pros:- You get to be a dictator.- Resources are more prevalent and important than in other city building games.- Trading is a fun and important aspect of the game.- Sandbox is fun to play with infinite money.- Graphics are good, no texture popups, and generally polished all around.Cons:-  An oppressive government doesn't work, who knew.- Riots everywhere, not the good kind either, so much murder.- Combat is garbage.- No way to pre-plan your city.

Wonderful, lost in my own fish bowl and in the middle of a world war. Alright, I can deal with that. "Oh by the way, Rebels want to raid your Sh*t. Good luck with that." Okay, not bad but- "Hold on there, don't forget about your elections!." Oh yeah! Nice not bad. "Okay age over time to make peace with the axis and allies! Even if you were not at war and they both like you F*CK IT, make peace of stay there." Right.. and I'm assumeing if I tell them to shove it up their respective bums I can expect invasion. At this point things are getting a little strange but hey lets advance. "Welcome to the cold war! Now, get your economy working and move forward." Alright, well I expected worse but I get it now. At this point I looked up a tutorial on how the hell the economy works. With about an hour of researched I got it down and now I'm not having to much trouble. Again its a good game but the fact that the tutorials teach you 10% of everything is a little trashy. They are not called "Tutorials" for nothing.If you need a break from Sim city or Skylines, its a good buy. However the extensive DLC for the game. (DLC which is little things for 4$ each.. Seriously?) Seems interesting but I personally will not waste my money on the DLC unless its offered as a good priced bundle.7/10 Decent Buy. I'd recomend it. LONG LIVE TROPICO

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
9, 2015
												One does not settle for silver after being used to gold. Yeah, it's Tropico allright...not. They tried to re-invent the wheel and came up with a square. It's a bit dumbed down and usable elements from the previous games were left out. Also it would seem that the studio got into taste of dlc industry with million billion different dlcs. Also I can't help but to wonder if they had some legal problems with the used soundtracks on tropico 3 and 4. I enjoyed the vocal music on the previous games. As far as I remember in tropico 5 there is just one soundtrack with voice and that is lyricless. Or maybe it costs more to produce music like that.The humour is of the same brand as so far. But It's tired wannabe funny, whereas tropico 3 and 4 had genuinely fun moments. In essence there is nothing wrong with the game mechanics. But the previous installments put the bar too high for tropico 5  and they failed to meet the high standards. However it is for that I am still giving this game thumbs up. There is nothing wrong in the game, but it is NOT it's predecessors.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
3, 2015
												Now THIS is a fun game. In my opinion, this simply is the best city builder out there. Why is that? Mostly because of the style. It feels great to be El Presidente of your own little Carribean island. Your entire island looks exactly like you would expect from a Latino-American country. Yes, in the beginning that does look quite a bit like shacks, but if you do well that will change soon enough. And then there's the fact that you are El Presidente: this means that you can do whatever you want, provided you keep the people under control by either being popular or repressing them. The latter is my personal favorite. But El Presidente does not rule alone. He also has a number of trustworthy advisors to help him out and keep him busy. And your number one advisor is the one and only, brilliant Penultimo!Also, there are multiple ways to build up your island: you could build farms everywhere, industrialize or be the dream island of every tourist. Though I've got to be honest: this can get a little bit dull in your 50th game.Up until now, this might have seemed alright but not hugely convincing. So let me tell you what is.It is: the humour. This game is absolutely hilarious and happens quite often that I find myself laughing at yet another brilliant remark by Penultimo, though he is not your only source of fun.So if you want to rule your own little banana-republic and laugh a lot doing so, this game is a must.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
8, 2015
												I am a latecomer to kalypso's Tropico titles, so my perspective is that of someone who isn't all too experienced with city-builders in general. Keep that in mind.I always read reviews before I buy stuff, and the majority for this game said to buy Tropico 4 instead. So, that's what I did. I bought tropico 4 and played quite a bit, and then I bought tropico 5, and I've played them within days of each other.I think Tropico 5 is the better game. The graphics upgrade is... substantial. I don't know if people say to play Tropico 4 instead because they've been long time followers of the game and weren't impressed with the new mechanics or what, but Tropico 4 is just too easy. Time consuming, but easy. Tropico 5 is hard. Much, much more challenging than Tropico 4, and it adds in some new elements and removes others. The "Faction" system seems to take less of a precedence, and foreign politics and a trade system seemed to have taken it's place. The trade system, the rebel system, the edicts, and the constitution all make Tropico 5 the more challenging and worthwhile title, in my opinion.Now, don't get me wrong, I didn't dislike Tropico 4 even when compared to Tropico 5. I've played more hours of Tropico 4 to date, but I believe I'll play more Tropico 5 in the long run because it's just kicking my ♥♥♥ even on low difficulty. That's why I reccomend Tropico 5 over 4.The DLC mess the company does I won't comment on, because it doesn't effect me negatively too much especially since the game was on sale and I definitely feel like I got my moneys worth. But if you have a problem with the DLC scheme, I'd just go with another game. :)

content:
, 2015
												Let me start out by saying this is a pretty good quality game before I criticize everything about it...I've played Tropico 3, 4 (on xbox) , and now 5. This game has amazing graphics, BUT YOU DONT SACRAFICE CONTENT FOR GRAPHICS. I use to be able to play the other Tropicos for days and never feel bored, this game however is contentless. It feels like they cut out 50% of the potential buildings to add multiplayer and better graphics, just to sell it as DLC. I will admit I like the new soldiers, and tanks, and research function, but that means nothing if I can't keep my people happy because (unlike past Tropicos) the almanac is near pointless, also I can't keep my cities looking good if it looks like some communist utopia where every house is exactly the same. I liked in Tropico 4 where you could press < or > to get different styled apartments or condos.This game would be 9/10 if it actually HAD MORE CONTENT. But since it doesn't I give it 5/10
